Date:  Tue, 01 Jan 2013 15:39:17 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  C/2012 K5 Linear in two focal lengths
Hi,

The upper three minute image was taken with an SBIG ST10XME camera and an Astrophysics 5" f8 refractor at a focal length of 1,016mm. The bottom 1 minute image was taken with a Nikon D7000 camera at ISO6400 and a Borg 77ED f5.5 refractor at a focal length of 425mm. Both images were taken Jan 1, 2013.

http://stardustobservatory.org/images.php?page=details&id=327

John 

Date:  Tue, 01 Jan 2013 16:28:40 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Your off to a great start with the image. Happy New Year to you sir and all members of Comet Images board.
Mike Holloway
Holloway Comet Observatory
Van Buren, AR

Date:  Tue, 01 Jan 2013 20:11:37 +0100
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hi all

I was a little surprised that absolutely under dark sky, the comet shows now no color. Blue, green and red showed identical appearance. This dusty comet shows only on the processing
with the Larson-Sekanina filter distinct structures. Soon I will post the picture.

To show the comet clearly, I have a total of 10 shots
processed. Before the LS process, i give away most stars with Fitswork
from the single exposures.

After a hacker attack my homepage is of power.
Until PanStarrs emerges in March, I should be back online.

I wish you all clear skies and two super-comet 2013

Michael

----- Original Message -----
From: tricks46
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, January 01, 2013 5:28 PM

Mike Holloway
Holloway Comet Observatory

Date:  Wed, 02 Jan 2013 09:07:25 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  comet C/2012 K5 - 31/12/2012
>I was a little surprised that absolutely under dark sky, the comet shows now no
>color. Blue, green and >red showed identical appearance. This dusty comet shows only
>on the processing
>with the Larson-Sekanina filter distinct structures. Soon I will post the picture.

>Michael

in fact even I as well to saturate the colors as much as possible, what I got is a
pale brown

http://www.astrobin.com/28763/

I think that what we see are only dust, longer tail, dust left on the orbital plane

best regards
Rolando Ligustri

C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it

Date:  Thu, 03 Jan 2013 01:06:56 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Nucleus of C2012 K5
Hi,

This one minute exposure at 1,016mm focal length captures the rapidly moving nucleus of Comet C/2012 K5 Linear which is off center in the coma.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/C2012K5LINEARJan22013AP127f8ST101min2x2_20130102185845.jpg

John

Date:  Thu, 03 Jan 2013 09:22:19 +0100
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Helllo Burkhard

It is a special model for the bright comets: 115/f-4 mirror, 50mm secondary mirror,
aperture to 110mm and ASA-reducer.

Best regards
Michael

Date:  Thu, 03 Jan 2013 16:52:09 -0000
From:  astrogeek_andre 
Subject:  C/2012 K5
Howdy,

Here is a monochrome image of C/2012 K5 from last night.
http://www.astrobin.com/28881

Taken with Celestron Edge HD 14" and Apogee U16M.
4x5min subs were used.

Andre 

Date:  Fri, 04 Jan 2013 20:32:52 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Visual Comet Observations January 3, 2013

Visual Comet Observations January 3, 2013
Tycho 2 VT photometry as comparison.
images of these comets can be found on my website.
http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

C/2012 K5 LINEAR
Morris format
2013 Jan 03.50 UT; m1=8.2, Dia= 5', DC=6...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
ICQ format
2013 Jan 3.50, 8.2, 5' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm binoculars);
[Coma not enhanced with a Swan Band filter. Short dust tail in PA 20. Makes
a pretty picture with M36,M37 and M38 in the vicinity]

C/2012 F6 Lemmon
Morris format
2013 Jan 3.52 UT: m1=8.1, Dia.=6', DC=4...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
ICQ format
2013 Jan 3.52, 8.1, 6' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm binoculars);
[large coma strongly enhanced with a SWAN band filter]

cheers,
Michael

Date:  Sat, 05 Jan 2013 07:03:57 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  C/2012 K5 animations, 04 Jan 2013
First a widefield with the tiny wanderer in a big field of stars:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/C2012K54Jan2013wideanim.gif 2.35MB.

Second, close-up with crops at actual pixel size (Canon 400D at 200mm, 3888x2592px):
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/C2012K54Jan2013closeanim.gif

Represents movement in about 13 mins, centered on 11:42, 04 Jan 2013 UT. Movement is approximately 2.8 arcminutes if I've measured correctly (not guaranteed!).

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Victoria, Australia

> http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/web/index.html
> Regards,
>
> schmidtcamera2500

Date:  Sat, 05 Jan 2013 15:49:24 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Comet Linear tonight
Hi,

C/2012 K5 Linear is starting to fade and can no longer be visually seen through 10x50 binoculars like it could five nights ago. Here is a 16 minute exposure of the comet at a focal length of 1,016mm.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/C2012K5LINEARJan52013AP127f8D7000iso640016x1min_20130105094105.jpg

John 

Date:  Sat, 05 Jan 2013 22:33:26 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Fastest Comet in the Sky
By that I mean fastest relative motion. C/2012 K5 LINEAR was racing through Taurus on December 31st at 13.89 arc seconds per minute, relative to the star field. Maybe it was celebrating New Year's Eve?

I think this is the fastest relative motion of any comet I've imaged in the past decade. It is much faster than almost all asteroids. I imaged it for two and a half hours taking 60 second subframes. That was as long an exposure as I could take without comet blur.

The fast relative motion allowed me to compose an animated GIF -- take a look at the link below.

Please take a look at my web page -- images, isophotes, orbit diagram, light curve, movie -- all kinds of data.

http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm .

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Hampshire, IL

Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
New Images http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm
Daily Bread Inspirational Page (Helicopter Parable) http://users.foxvalley.net/~dpersyk/DailyBread/ 

Date:  Sat, 05 Jan 2013 13:23:07 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Fastest Comet in the Sky

The orbital diagram you have the page is for comet Garradd.

Carey

Date:  Thu, 10 Jan 2013 10:33:22 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Vis Obs: C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS)
Hi,

I visually observed C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) in the pre-dawn sky this morning (in Scorpius). I also took some images through a 41cm f5.2 Newtonian with an STL11000M CCD – 15 x 1 minute subs, clear filter, 1x1.

OBSERVATION -
CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )

C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) -
2013 Jan. 09.62 UT: m1 = 8.1, Dia.= 3', DC = 5, Tail = 2' in PA of 283˚, 41cm L (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Comet PANSTARRS easy to see. Nice coma and short tail. Comparison stars - TYC 7889197 (7.95), TYC 789365 (8.55). Comet 13 degrees altitude in the SE. Clear, no Moon, dark sky.]

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( icq@cfa.harvard.edu )
Jan 09.62, 8.1, 3' (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm L (59x));

PHOTO -
The photo of C/2011 L4 can be seen here -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2012L4-PANSTARRS-41cm-f5,2_Newtonian-Paramount_ME-STL11000M-15x1min-clear-1x1-130109UT-web-cropped.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/bka6b2n

Regards

==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

Date:  Thu, 10 Jan 2013 23:31:02 +0800
From:  amar sharma 
Subject:  10 Jan '13:: K5 LINEAR, F6 Lemmon, 29P/SW1, S1 ISON
Hello All,
Last month I could image 7 comets in one night, something unimaginable for me and the current equipment's calibrated status.
However I got a shot yester-night at the 4 comets above between 18:30 UT and 23:00 UT. Dark frames applied and no flat fielding done (have attempted it couple times only). All images unfiltered. So you may have a look at the basic images taken with a C-14 @ f/6.9 with focal reducer, and SBIG ST-8XME, unguided shots of around a minute multiple exposure each. Skies were bad and light polluted at the
observatory site, because we suffer from eternal haze!

Please note, there was an unpredictable COM port error and the laptop could not read Cartes du Ciel with the mount. I had to do visual star hopping of the C-14
through the finderscope and center fields for all of them!!! Hard work & being a visual observer helps considerably.

And I did experience some anomaly with stacking. It doesnt happen right for me always. Will raise a question in the next email.
1) C/2012 K5 (LINEAR)
https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5831795433074824930
This one obviously showed movement after each exposure. I find there is some tiny protrusion between "7 and 8 'o' clock" position in the image. It caught my eye in every sub exposure (and I had a slight feeling of a jet?). I dont officially request for it. However can anyone follow up in your usual image routine if it is just a hallucination?
2) C/2012 F6 (Lemmon)
https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5831794722540563298
Lemmon showed movement after each exposure. And it emerged out of an occultation over a background star.
3) C/2012 S1
(ISON)
https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5831794932382030482
4) ISON and DSS comparison
https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5831795185452312082
5) 29/P Schwassmann-Wachmann-1
https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5831795960114751586
(Got reminded of this after Juan Gonzalez's visual observation post)
Have so much to imbibe from the experts here in CCD imaging etiquettes. Looking forward, Thanks,
Amar A. SharmaBangalore, India+12* 36' / E77 30'Nikaya Observatoryhttps://picasaweb.google.com/nikayaobservatory
Date:  Thu, 10 Jan 2013 21:00:44 +0100

- 63P Wild

- 78P Gehrels

- 168P Hergenrother

- 175P Hergenrother

- 242P Spahr

- 244P Scotti

- 262P McNaught-Russell

- 274P Tombaugh-Tenagra

- C2009 P1 Garradd

- C2010 S1 LINEAR

- C2011 J2 LINEAR

- C2012 J1 Catalina

- C2012 K5 LINEAR

- C2012 K5 LINEAR - Larson-Sekanina filter

- C2012 L1 LINEAR

- C2012 S1 ISON

- C2012 V2 LINEAR

- C2012 X1 LINEAR

- C2012 X2 PANSTARRS

with a direct link to the image:
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/index.html

Alfons Diepvens

Subject:  Two-frame Animation of C/2012 S1

Date:  Wed, 16 Jan 2013 14:07:58 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  C/2012 F6 nearing Southern Cross
Widefield from tonight showing C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) nearing the Southern Cross (Canon 400D on Vixen Polarie, 134mm, 5 x 1 min, ISO 1600, F/5.0 - 12:44, 16 Jan 2013 UT). The comet is the green spot at left. It will move through the Cross over the next few nights. This is full frame, reduced size:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/F6SC16Jan2013lge.jpg

Here's the 'key index' shot!!
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/F6SC16Jan2013smtext.jpg

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Victoria, Australia 

Date:  Wed, 16 Jan 2013 18:14:16 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando

http://www.astrobin.com/30015/

best regards
Rolando Ligustri

CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete 

Date:  Wed, 16 Jan 2013 14:49:53 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] comet C/2012 S1 Ison today with Rc filter
We have also been watching as this comet develops and have seen some major
enlargement of a nearly circular coma/nucleus area without any pronounced outer
nebulosity. One interesting aspect is an irregularity that has begun to form on
the eastern side of the coma, appearing as slight striations, perhaps the
beginning of a tail feature.

The progress of this comet and all other current comets is updated nearly
nightly on the Arkansas Sky Observatories (ASO) website Comet Data Catalog at:
http://www.arksky.org/php/ctable.php
which currently lists over 14 updated entries for some of the major comets in
the sky at this time.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Comet observations January 16, 2013
Visual Comet Observations January 16, 2013

Tycho 2 VT photometry as comparison.
images of these comets can be found on my website.
http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

C/2012 F6 Lemmon
Morris format
2013 Jan 16.50 UT: m1=7.1, Dia.=8', DC=4...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
ICQ format
2013 Jan 16.50, 7.1, 8' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm binoculars);

C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS
Morris format
2013 Jan 16.73 UT; m1=7.9, Dia= 2', DC=7...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
ICQ format
2013 Jan 16.73, 7.9, 2' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm binoculars);
[well condensed with a short dust tail in PA 280. Globular cluster NGC 6541
in same field of view appeared significantly brighter]

cheers,
Michael

Date:  Tue, 22 Jan 2013 06:44:56 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  C/2011L4 (PANSTARRS) imaged this morning (20130121)
Hi,

I managed to get 20 x 10 second images of PANSTARRS with the 41cm f5.2 Meade Starfinder and Canon 500D DSLR (1600 ISO) this morning. Astronomical twilight was unfortunately kicking in – I lost some imaging time with equipment problems. North is roughly down and east is roughly right. Note the tail that extends for about 11’ in a PA of 284. The images can be seen at -

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2011L4-PANSTARRS-41CM-F5,2-10x60SEC-1600ASA-20130121UT-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/aedgjya

Regards

==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

From:  Josef Müller 
Subject:  C/2012 S1 (ISON)
Here's a shot of comet C/2012 S1 (ISON).
30x180s; FWHM: 2.25; Air Mass 1.067
Looks like a near by asteroide.
I can not see any coma or tail!

http://www.westerwald-astro.de/jjm/kometen/c-2012-s1-ison_invers-hp.php?BackPath=kometen

Date:  Tue, 22 Jan 2013 14:23:49 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) imaged this morning - 2013 Jan 21
Hi again,

here’s an image of C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) taken ~10 hours ago (2013 Jan 21.62UT). I used a 41cm f5.2 Meade Starfinder Newtonian and Canon 500D DSLR. 20 x 1 minute subs were used. Note that the dark patch to the lower right of Lemmon is dark nebula GN12.32.5 (Maximum diameter: 1200 arcseconds, Emission nebula (questionable), Brightness level: 5 (1=brightest, ... 6=faintest), Brightness level extremely approximate, Alternative designations for this object: GN 12.32.5, MRSL 218) (from GUIDE 9.0).

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2012F6-LEMMON-41CM-F52-8x60SEC-1600ASA-1600iso-20130121,64UT-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/bhf4pbw

I must admit, it’s been fun watching Lemmon roll through Crux at a star party/camp over the last few nights...

Regards

==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287
Date:  Tue, 22 Jan 2013 10:58:34 -0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  The Comet Tale
Hello all,
I would like to announce the publication of the 2013 issue of The Comet Tale published by Jon
Shanklin on behalf of the BAA Comet Section. It can be freely downloaded at the following link.

http://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/~jds/tail32.pdf

Enjoy the read, any comments can be made via these lists or directly to Jon at his email address
which is published inside the issue.

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) and C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) images - 23.62 Jan 2012 (UT)
Hi John,
Well done with these images and for posting them. PanStarrs 2011 L4 is looking a lot like an active comet in your shot. I hope you can still access it in your sky as it approaches perihelion. Regular images posted from southern hemisphere observers will be most appreciated. It also helps to build the whole story of the apparition. Great work.
Denis

Date:  Sun, 27 Jan 2013 01:29:28 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  C/2012 T5 (Bressi), 26 Jan 2013
Bad, bad shots with a basic DSLR in very poor bright skies but this comet appears to be of some interest because of a reported recent major outburst. Stars to around mid mag 12s are showing in the image:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/C2012T5Bressi26Jan2013textc.jpg

I had two sets of shots about 3/4 of an hour apart and here's a rough animation of the comet's movement:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/C2012T5anim26Jan2013.gif

By contrast I tried to image the comet in dark skies a couple of weeks ago and despite getting stars down into the mag 14s there wasn't the slightest sign of the comet:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/C2012T5position07Jan2013text.jpg

The comet should be in dark skies in a couple of days.

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Victoria, Australia 

Date:  Mon, 28 Jan 2013 11:42:31 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Comet images Jan 27 2013, 2012 T5, 2012 F6, 2012 L4
Hi Folks,

I imaged C/2012 T5 Bressi last night in full moonlight.
This small comet is probably having a last gasp before it completely vapourises.
I could not get a visual estimate but it is probably around mag 10-11.
Also 2012 F6 Lemmon is mag 6.1 and bordering on naked eye visibility
Both should be interesting to watch starting this Thursday when moon is out of the way.
and 2011 L4 PANSTARRS at mag 7.2.
Should still put on a fine show as it is very dusty with a bright stellar core.

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo
Date:  Mon, 28 Jan 2013 16:14:52 +1100

Date:  Tue, 29 Jan 2013 20:46:38 -0000
From:  chergen 
Subject:  Comets from the VATT (Jan 20-21 2013 UT)
On the nights of January 20 and 21 UT I was observing on the Vatican
Observatory's VATT 1.8-m telescope on Mount Graham, Arizona. I was
able to image a number of comets even with a rather bright Moon in
the sky for much of the night.

Images for the following comets:

C/2009 P1 (Garradd)
C/2011 UF305 (LINEAR)
C/2012 K1 (PANSTARRS)
C/2012 S1 (ISON)
C/2012 T5 (Bressi)
C/2012 V2 (LINEAR)
C/2012 X1 (LINEAR)
C/2013 A1 (Siding Spring)

can be found here:

http://transientsky.wordpress.com/2013/01/28/vatt-comets/

- Carl Hergenrother 

Date:  Tue, 29 Jan 2013 15:02:16 -0800
From:  "Dr S. Aguirre"

From:  Rob 
Subject:  Re: C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) & C/2012 T5 (Bressi), 02 Feb 2013
Thanks Al. I need a fast lens to really get the tail - shooting a rapidly-moving comet at F/5.6 is a difficult ask. There are lots of magnificent shots of the long tail appearing round the (southern) web, just not from me! Good luck with your efforts.

Cheers -

Rob

Date:  Sun, 03 Feb 2013 18:50:02 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comet Lemmon (C/2012 F6) imaged last night (2013 Feb 2)
Hi,

I got two images of C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) last night (2013 Feb 02.41 UT) before the Moon rose. One was with a SBIG STL11000M CCD through a 41cm f5.2 Meade Newtonian and the other was with a Canon 500D DSLR and 200mm Sigma lens @ f2.8. The 200mm lens has a FOV of 6.5 x 4.5 degrees and the tail is about 5 degrees long.

The images are:
41cm -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2012f6-lemmon-41cm@f5,2-30x1min-Clear-1x1-130202-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/a7puzwh

200mm lens -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2012F6-Lemmon-200mm_sigma_lens-f2,8-Canon_500D-20x3min-130202-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/b3vrw3w

Regards
==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287
Date:  Sun, 03 Feb 2013 07:01:40 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lemmon (C/2012 F6) imaged last night (2013 Feb 2)

Rolando

rose. One was with a SBIG STL11000M CCD through a 41cm f5.2 Meade Newtonian and the
other was with a Canon 500D DSLR and 200mm Sigma lens @ f2.8. The 200mm lens has a

Date:  Mon, 04 Feb 2013 22:24:29 +0100
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Image of C/2012 F6 Lemmon
> I grabbed a remote image of Lemmon using iTelescope's Siding Spring
> T30 CDK an hour ago....

Can't decide what impresses me more: the comet's structure-rich plasma
tail - or the fact that the iTelescope at Siding Spring Observatory (which
is still under safety shutdown and cannot be entered even by professional
astronomers) started taking pictures again just days after the great fire:
http://www.itelescope.net/home/2013/1/18/itelescopenet-siding-spring-opens-4-days-after-bush-fire-hit.html
...

Daniel 

Date:  Mon, 04 Feb 2013 16:56:59 -0600

Date:  Mon, 04 Feb 2013 23:50:19 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comet Carving
Hello. 2 years ago I started collecting ancient mammoth tusk and other ancient bone carvings by an artist named Eddie Lee. He is considered a master at hand carving single one of a kind pieces. I tried to get an idea I had out to whoever could relay it to Mr. Lee. After about one year I kind of gave up not hearing back anything. Then one month ago an email from Skagway ,Alaska came telling me Mr. Lee was not only impressed with the idea but that my sculpture was 85% finished. The idea was what would it look like to an ancient person and even the anamils of the time if one morning above a mountain in the distance a comet appeared. 2 days ago I received an image of the finished piece of art. Made of Mammoth tusk and bone with a chrystal for the comet it is about 12" tall. I wanted to share this with others in the comet imaging community. I hope you can appreciate this comet art as I do.
Mike H.
http://fototime.com/46714ADB6BCB172/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 05 Feb 2013 00:52:22 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Re: Comet Carving
Neat! It's a nice looking piece.

Dave

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Hello. 2 years ago I started collecting ancient mammoth tusk and other ancient bone carvings by an artist named Eddie Lee. He is considered a master at hand carving single one of a kind pieces. I tried to get an idea I had out to whoever could relay it to Mr. Lee. After about one year I kind of gave up not hearing back anything. Then one month ago an email from Skagway ,Alaska came telling me Mr. Lee was not only impressed with the idea but that my sculpture was 85% finished. The idea was what would it look like to an ancient person and even the anamils of the time if one morning above a mountain in the distance a comet appeared. 2 days ago I received an image of the finished piece of art. Made of Mammoth tusk and bone with a chrystal for the comet it is about 12" tall. I wanted to share this with others in the comet imaging community. I hope you can appreciate this comet art as I do.
> Mike H.
> http://fototime.com/46714ADB6BCB172/orig.jpg

Date:  Tue, 05 Feb 2013 20:15:21 -0000
From:  Jaicoa 
Subject:  Comet ISON - 02/04/2013, Animation
Hi Group!, Uploaded my latest session on Comet ISON. An Animation of 4 frames at 15 minute subs for a total of 1 hour time lapse. Having difficulties on the minor planet site on trying to ID the Asteroid or if its a lensing effect on the object right of the comet path. If anyone has taken an image at this time frame would appreciate it much.
Efrain
(Equipment: WO ED80II,F6.8,P/B CGE mount, ST2000xm, AO8, CFW9, Image Croped)

Animation: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1050174766/pic/1641529462/view?picmode=original&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=1&dir=asc 

Date:  Sat, 09 Feb 2013 10:55:52 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  comet observations 2013 Feb 8
Hi Folks,

I have uploaded photos of Lemmon and PANSTARRS taken this am to my website.

C/2012 F6 Lemmon
2013 Feb 8.74 UT
Canon 60Da, 5x2 minute stack. 300mm zoom lens, cropped. Visual estimate 5.5
The ion tail is at least 3 degrees long in PA 165.

C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS
2013 Feb 8.75 UT
Canon 60Da, 5x2 minute stack. 300mm zoom lens, cropped. Visual estimate 5.9.
The ion tail is nearly 1 degree in PA 210 whilst the leading edge of the
dust tail is 30' in PA 250.
Notice the broad dust fan.

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

cheers,
Michael 

Date:  Sat, 09 Feb 2013 03:00:56 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-02-08   63P 272P 274P C2011J2 C2012L1 C2012V2 C2012X1
Dear all,

The comets of this evening, with some winds sometimes:

63P Wild
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/63P_Wild.html

272P NEAT
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/272P_NEAT.html

274P Tombaugh-Tenagra

Date:  Sun, 10 Feb 2013 16:05:27 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comet Lemmon imaged over the last two nights (Feb 8-9)
Hi,

I imaged C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) over the last two nights (as well as C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS)).

The first is with a CCD through a 41cm f5.2 Meade Newtonian – 2013 Feb 9.42 UT. Note the wavy tail...
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2012F6-Lemmon-41cm@f5,2-10x1min-25c-130209-drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/av3m95r

The other is with a 500D Canon DSLR through a 130mm f3.3 Takahashi Epsilon - 2013 Feb 8.42 UT. FOV is about 4.8 x 3.2 degrees.
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2012F6-Lemmon-130mm_f3,3_Takahashi-500D_DSLR-59x1-3min-130208drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/anjt34j

I also did a visual estimate of Lemmon on the 8th Feb and estimate it to be mag 5.8 with a DC of 4. Tail easily seen in 20 x 80 binoculars.

Regards

==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

From:  John 
Subject:  Bogus emails


Hi,

on our New Zealand Astronomers Yahoo group we have been having a number of people's email accounts used for these dashed bogus emails - and it looks like they just got mine. Please DON'T open the link below (I've also altered it if you try).

My apologies for this.

Regards

John D

From: John Drummond

Sent: Sunday, February 10, 2013 11:19 AM

http://www.jppabogados.com/gkphkkpz/bj6pgek4dafsp1siwqmf5wj5u1.v?n=i6v5 


Date:  Sun, 10 Feb 2013 12:30:32 -0800
From:  Bill MacIntosh 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Bogus emails
This is going on all over Yahoo.   It's not from an original sender.   The baddies
are using a SESSION COOKIE to access email accounts.   First, change password,
then be sure to LOGOUT after each Yahoo visit.   This destroys the session cookie
they use.

you can check your account access log to see if your password is compromised

start at the upper left on the CometImagesYahooGroupsPage
drop down the menu where it say Hi ( whomever you are )
select Account Info
sign in
Under Sign-In and Security
click on View your recent sign-in activity
and look for any suspicious locations

more likely it was some JavaScript - Session
Cookie exploit that has supposedly recently
been addressed by Yahoo, please see:
Yahoo plugs hole that allowed hijacking of email accounts
http://www.pcworld.com/article/2026848/yahoo-plugs-hole-that-allowed-hijacking-of-email-accounts.html

Bill
Oakland Astronomy Club USA

________________________________

To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

Date:  Thu, 14 Feb 2013 16:57:59 -0000
From:  Jaicoa 
Subject:  Comet C/2013S1 ISON - February 13th, 03:46ut
Comet ISON C/2012S1 Up-Close on February 13th, 03:46ut 2013. The tail of the comet could be seen now and the comet coma has brighten to a small degree. Top image is a LRGB (color) of a total of 8 min. Equipment: LX200ACF 12 in. OTA, F10 at Prime (3050mm), CGE mount, ST2000xm Ccd, AO8, CFW9, Astronomik LRGB filter set.

At: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1050174766/pic/136793018/view?picmode=&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=1&count=20&dir=asc

Animation: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1050174766/pic/949660727/view?picmode=original&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=1&dir=asc

Date:  Sat, 16 Feb 2013 11:19:15 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comet Lemmon and 47 Tucanae - 14Feb2013
Hi,

C/2012 F6 (Comet Lemmon) has been lurking around the Small Magellanic Cloud and 47 Tucanae over the last few nights. Here’s an image taken on 2013 Feb 14 with a Canon 500D DSLR and 200mm Sigma lens. 2 x 2 minute exposures @ 1600iso -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2012F6-LEMMON-47TUC_2x2min_1600iso_20130214-23h59m27s269ms-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/dyb6chv

Here’s a YouTube link to it moving across the FOV (Canon 500D, 200mm Sigma lens. Time span = ~ 3hours)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RMi28iAYQKM&feature=youtu.be

Regards

Date:  Sat, 16 Feb 2013 12:53:10 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Asteroid 2012 DA14 video clip - 2013 Feb 15
Hi,

Asteroid 2012 DA14 came within a cat's whisker of Earth on the 14/15 February 2013. Here's a video clip of two second images of the asteroid taken with a 41cm f5.2 Meade Newtonian and SBIG STL11000M CCD. The asteroid is seen to travel diagonally from upper right to lower left. The field of view is 1.0 x 0.7 degrees. It was really cool looking at it travel amongst the stars visually in real time with another 16” Newtonian.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Cm-PbBJFLk&feature=youtu.be

Regards

==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand

Subject:  2012DA14 Video
Hello everybody,

This is the result from tonight taken with the ASA (Astrosysteme Austria)
Remote Observatory in Spain. I found no time for image calibration, thus
there are some hot pixels moving with - anyway the object is clearly

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Sat, 16 Feb 2013 19:22:40 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Asteroid 2012 DA14, comets Lemmon and PANSTARRS images 2013 Feb 15 UT
Hi all,

I had a very busy morning observing 2 bright comets plus keeping track of
asteroid 2012 DA14.
This asteroid was moving at a cracking pace, in real time.
Using 25x100 mm binoculars I first spotted it crossing through the southern
pleiades (IC 2602) at 04:45 AEDT on the 16th,
then skirting the eastern edge of the Eta Carinae nebula at 05:00. It
appeared as predicted at about mag 9.
Moving on to C/2012 F6 Lemmon, the comet made a beautiful conjunction with
47 Tuc and the SMC.
Visually the comet was about mag 5.2 with the unaided eye and a degree of
ion tail was visible through the binoculars. My photos capture 5 degrees of
tail.
Then on to C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS, which is looking visually more impressive as
the dust tail forms a broad V shaped fan.
PANSTARRS was more difficult to estimate as I was looking over Melbourne
light pollution, but it was at least mag 5.0 but not observable with the
unaided eye.
The dust fan is approaching 1 degree in length whilst the fainter ion tail
is 2 degrees through the 25x100's
Returning to 2012 DA14, I recovered it in Vela at 05:33 AEDT and tracked it
for another 10 minutes.
It travelled 7 degrees during this time and appeared brighter at
approximately magnitude 8 before twilight and cloud finally ended the show.
I have posted photos of all 3 objects on my homepage:
http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo
Castlemaine Vic 

Date:  Sat, 16 Feb 2013 08:39:50 -0000
From:  Helder G 
Subject:  Cometa Lemmon
Olá amigos,

Uma foto do Lemmon feita com a minha Canon 300D, na cidade da Matola, Maputo, Moçambique, no meu observatório. Tenho alguma poluição luminosa, mas consegui esta foto com um empilhamento de 6 fotos com 25seg de exposição + 5 fotos com 35seg e 10 Darks. Usei um ISO 400 e uma lente de 135mm F=2.8 instalada em GEM1. Oconjunto foi tratado no DSS.

A foto está colocada na secção de fotos no álbum: geraldes.helder

Espero que gostem.

Céus limpos,
Helder Geraldes 

Date:  Sun, 17 Feb 2013 01:12:08 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comet PANSTARRS image - 8 Feb 2013 (not spam)
Hi,

Here’s an image of Comet PANSTARRS taken through a 41cm f5.2 Meade Newtonian with an SBIG STL11000M CCD on the 8th February 2013. The FOV is slightly cropped – but still nearly 1.0 x 0.7 degrees. Note the possible upper ion tail.

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2011L4-PANSTARRS-41cm@f5,2-30x1min-1x1_clear-20c-8Feb1013-John_Drummond-web.jpg

Regards

==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand

--- On Sat, 2/16/13, john_drummond@xtra.co.nz wrote:

From: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet PANSTARRS image - 8 Feb 2013 (not spam) [1 Attachment]
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Saturday, February 16, 2013, 12:12 PM

[Attachment(s) from john_drummond@xtra.co.nz included below]

Hi,

Here’s an image of Comet PANSTARRS taken through a 41cm f5.2
Meade Newtonian with an SBIG STL11000M CCD on the 8th February 2013. The FOV is
slightly cropped – but still nearly 1.0 x 0.7 degrees. Note the possible upper
ion tail.

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/C-2011L4-PANSTARRS-41cm@f5,2-30x1min-1x1_clear-20c-8Feb1013-John_Drummond-web.jpg

Regards

Date:  Sat, 16 Feb 2013 13:17:17 -0800
From:  lydia macokatic 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Asteroid 2012 DA14, comets Lemmon and PANSTARRS images 2013 Feb 15 UT

--- On Sat, 16/2/13, Michael Mattiazzo wrote:

From: Michael Mattiazzo
Subject: [Comet-Images] Asteroid 2012 DA14, comets Lemmon and PANSTARRS images 2013 Feb 15 UT
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Received: Saturday, 16 February, 2013, 7:22 PM

Hi all,

I had a very busy morning observing 2 bright comets plus keeping track of

asteroid 2012 DA14.

This asteroid was moving at a cracking pace, in real time.

Using 25x100 mm binoculars I first spotted it crossing through the southern

pleiades (IC 2602) at 04:45 AEDT on the 16th,

then skirting the eastern edge of the Eta Carinae nebula at 05:00. It

appeared as predicted at about mag 9.

Moving on to C/2012 F6 Lemmon, the comet made a beautiful conjunction with

47 Tuc and the SMC.

Visually the comet was about mag 5.2 with the unaided eye and a degree of

ion tail was visible through the binoculars. My photos capture 5 degrees of

tail.

Then on to C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS, which is looking visually more impressive as

the dust tail forms a broad V shaped fan.

PANSTARRS was more difficult to estimate as I was looking over Melbourne

light pollution, but it was at least mag 5.0 but not observable with the

unaided eye.

The dust fan is approaching 1 degree in length whilst the fainter ion tail

is 2 degrees through the 25x100's

Returning to 2012 DA14, I recovered it in Vela at 05:33 AEDT and tracked it

for another 10 minutes.

It travelled 7 degrees during this time and appeared brighter at

approximately magnitude 8 before twilight and cloud finally ended the show.

I have posted photos of all 3 objects on my homepage:

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

cheers,

Michael Mattiazzo

Castlemaine Vic 

Date:  Sun, 17 Feb 2013 02:11:44 +0100

et enfin C/2012 X2 PANSTARRS

Date:  Sun, 17 Feb 2013 18:45:17 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Comet PANSTARRS image - 8 Feb 2013 (not spam) [1 Attachment]
Hello John. On dark frames I would not tell anyone how to image but will say that if the darks are not taken from about the same altitude as the comet with similar light being the comet is so close to the horizion these gradients will show. Dark skys and better height of the comet is not as hard to do. I am sure I will have to take new darks of where the comet is just before I image the comet itself. I know you knew so don't take offence. Would appreciate all images you can manage. This will be in my sky in a couple of weeks and I have all new setup to start out imaging this comet.
Mike

Date:  Mon, 18 Feb 2013 07:45:55 +0800
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Comet PANSTARRS image - 8 Feb 2013 (not spam)
John,

Yes, flats have to be kept fresh to work well. Also expose them at the proper ADU level specified for your camera, at the same orientation, and focus as that of the object you are imaging.

John.

Date:  Mon, 18 Feb 2013 21:47:08 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comet Lemmon's six degree tail - 2013Feb16
Hi,

Here’s an image of C/2012 F6 (Lemmon) from two nights ago (2013 Feb 16.41 UT – not 13 Feb as stated in image sorry) when it was close to 47 Tucanae and the Small Magellanic Cloud. I used a 500D DSLR and 200mm Sigma lens @ f2.8. 32 x 2 minute exposures were combined and heavily stretched to bring out Lemmon’s 6 degree tail (in the image).

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_Lemmon-47_Tuc-500d-200mm-36x2min-130216-drummond-web-text.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/bkw737b

Regards

Date:  Wed, 20 Feb 2013 23:05:35 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comets Lemmon and PANSTARRS greet each other in the evening sky
Hi,

Finally, Comets Lemmon and PANSTARRS are in the same evening sky together! Attached is a wide angle photo (10 x 15 second exposures @ 400 iso) taken with a 20mm lens and 500D DSLR just over an hour after sunset on Wednesday 20th (20.35 UT) February 2013 (tonight). The two comets are 29 degrees apart.

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/Comets_Lemmon_and_PANSTARRS-500D_DSLR-20mm_Canon_Lens@f2,8-10x15sec@400iso-130220-drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/a9tlejl

Cheers

C 2012 S1 Ison, filter Ir. Moon elongation 14°(!).
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012S1Isonfrance.htm

C 2009 P1 Garradd, filter Ir.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2009P1Garradfrance.htm

63P Wild, filter Ir, (with aster 679).
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image63PWildfrance.htm

C 2013 D1 Holvorcem
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013D1Holvorcemfrance.htm

C 2012 F3 Panstarrs
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012F3Panstarrsfrance.htm

C 2012 K1 Panstarrs
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012K1Panstarrsfrance.htm

273P Pons-Gambart (zoom and field).
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image273PPonsGambartfrance.html

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France

Subject:  Comet 63P/ Wild 1 (Feb 27th, 2013.)
Hi all,

Here is an image from earlier today of 63P/Wild 1 currently located between Leo/Leo Minor. Near full moon ~45deg away made things difficult though the comet itself is clear. The bright star alongside the comet is mag 9.5.

Feb 27th, 2013. 08:29 UTC.

Date:  Fri, 01 Mar 2013 04:27:58 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  L4 PANSTARRS and F6 LEMMON images
Hi all,

I have been taking photo's of both these comets on a regular basis since early January. There has been a recent break due to the position of both comets and weather.

Last night I had a good evening photographing both with my DSLR (as opposed to the usuall CCD images I have been taking) and was quite happy with the results, as well as it being an wonderful way to spend a balmy evening by the lake:

http://blog.astrophotography.com.au/2013/02/comets-l4-panstarrs-and-f6-lemmon-in.html

The above were taken using a Canon 7D @1600 ISO with Canon 100-400L lens @ 400mm and F/5.6.

Other images going back to January of both the comets are here:

http://rogergroom.com/astro-photography/comet-photography/photographs-of-comet-c2011-l4-pannstarrs/

and

http://rogergroom.com/astro-photography/comet-photography/photographs-of-comet-c2012-f6-lemmon/

Enjoy!

Regards,
Roger.
=====================================================
Roger Groom roger[AT]RogerGroom.com
http://www.RogerGroom.com/

Date:  Fri, 01 Mar 2013 22:14:35 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 20130226 C/2012 T5 Bressi in STEREO HI1A
Gidday J.J. ,
The sequence is for the full day of 20130226. The HI1A imager has FOV of
approx 20 degrees.
This comet entered the centre of lower edge which is approx 20 degrees from
the sun.
As it was a few days ago, the comet should now be about 30 degrees from the
sun with respect to STEREO FOV.

It did not have a very bright coma or a pixel I could call a nucleus, so
may be a challenge to detect coming out of twilight.

kind regards, Alan

Date:  Sat, 02 Mar 2013 16:04:26 +1100
From:  Rob Kaufman 
Subject:  C/2011 L4, 01 March 2013
A grab-bag of images of PANSTARRS from last night are attached, taken with
a Canon 650D from a mountaintop location in NE Victoria, Australia. Also a
'journey' through my images of PANSTARRS from May 2012 to March 2013, what
a transformation! The comet was a very nice naked-eye sight last night and
beautiful through binoculars. Quite sad as we in the south are rapidly
losing this comet, but I'm looking forward to seeing all the marvellous
images when it reveals itself in the north!

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Victoria, Australia

Subject:  C/2012 L2 (LINEAR) Mar 2nd, 2013.
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained of L2 Linear earlier today. Currently located in Perseus at around mag 11. Quite a prominent coma but no real tail visible. Note the faint background star located close to the comet nucleus.

Date:  Mon, 04 Mar 2013 00:02:02 +1100
From:  Rob Kaufman 
Subject:  C/2012 F6 (Lemmon), 03 March 2013
Yesterday C/2012 F6 experienced a tail disconnection event, and tonight it
is showing big bright tail streamers. I think I also got a trace of the
remnants of the DE in my shot. Here's a link to an animation of the
positive and inverted images:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/C2012F603Mar2013anim.gif

Attached is a crop showing the tail, very different to a couple of nights
ago.

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Vic

Date:  Mon, 04 Mar 2013 23:34:57 +1100
From:  Rob Kaufman 
Subject:  PANSTARRS, webcam view of head, 04 Mar 2013
Thought I'd give webcamming a crack tonight seeing as the comet sets behind
hills too early in twilight to get deeper, wider images. Middling result
only in my opinion and not as good as some around the web, but I was using
a basic webcam through a basic telescope. Anyway, it probably gives a
better idea of the small intense false nucleus that is burnt out to a
streak in most of the images being posted, and also a clearer idea of the
visual view for those who haven't seen it yet.

Frame width is 14 arcminutes, and a scale is included. Attached are the
image, and a composite with the image and one taken on 01 March showing the
FOV.

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Victoria, Australia 
Date:  Mon, 04 Mar 2013 14:13:42 +0100

Date:  Tue, 05 Mar 2013 09:24:24 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-03-04 C/2012 Y1 LINEAR
Just time yesterday evening for an image of C/2012 Y1 while cirrus were
already arriving and the seeing was degrading significantly (image 5"
FWHM at secz about 1.5).

http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2012Y1_LINEAR.html

Luc
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/Welcome.html 
Date:  Tue, 05 Mar 2013 10:48:48 -0000
From:  Carey 
Subject:  Comet PANSTARRS from Waikiki
I spotted the comet in 20x70 binoculars this evening.
It took a while to get it in the camera, meanwhile it was setting into the muck on the horizon. The sky was still too bright for a long exposure.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/8531108386/in/photostream

Carey Johnson
Waikiki, Hawaii

Date:  Tue, 05 Mar 2013 20:53:15 +0900
From:  "S.Funamoto" 
Subject:  C/2011L4 images in New Zealand
Hello everyone! Nice to meet you.

I'm a Japanese amateur astro photographer.
Please call me "Funa-san".

I'm visiting to New Zealand for sightseeing from last week, and I was able
to catch comet C/2011L4 four times.

1st March, in Whakamaru Dam of north island
(300mm F4 lens & APS-C DSLR)
http://www.stargaze.co.jp/news/COMET2/C2011L4/11L4_0301.jpg
** the orange background by the illumination of the dam

2nd March, in Kaikoura of south island
(300mm F4 lens & APS-C DSLR)
http://www.stargaze.co.jp/news/COMET2/C2011L4/11L4_0302.jpg
** It was in the cloud after this.

3rd March, in Lake Tekapo of south island
(300mm F4 lens & APS-C DSLR)
http://www.stargaze.co.jp/news/COMET2/C2011L4/11L4_0303.jpg
(85mm F2.8 lens & APS-C DSLR)
http://www.stargaze.co.jp/news/COMET2/C2011L4/11L4tekapo.jpg
** In this time, it was best condition. But, I forgot C/2012F6......

5th March, near Te Anau of south island
(135mm F2.8 lens & APS-C DSLR)
http://www.stargaze.co.jp/news/COMET2/C2011L4/11L4_0305.jpg
** I saw only for several minutes because it's between a cloud and clouds.

I will go back to Japan tomorrow, but intend to chase it afterwards in
Japan!

-------------------------------
Shigekatsu Funamoto
Hidaka, Saitama Japan
E-Mail : funa@stargaze.co.jp
-------------------------------

From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Observation of comet 20130302 of 04
Good afternoon.

In a not very transparent sky (mist plain) and seeing poor (wind N/E) ...

C 2012 S1 Ison, 03/02, 03/03, IR filter and without filter
tail : +/- 31", coma : +/- 20".
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012S1Isonfrance.htm

63P Wild, IR filter.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image63PWildfrance.htm

P 2013 CE31 Moss, 03/02, 03/03, tail : +/- 43", coma : +/- 6".
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageP2013CE31Mossfrance.htm

C 2011 J2 Linear, red filter, tail : +/- 2', coma : +/- 45".
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2011J2Linearfrance.htm

P 2012 B1 Panstarrs, red filter.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageP2012B1Panstarrsfrance.htm

273P Pons-Gambart, red filter, coma : +/- 3'.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image273PPonsGambartfrance.html

C 2010 S1 Linear, red filter.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2010S1Linearfrance.htm

274P Tombaugh-Tenagra, with MCG +06-15-005 resembling the N.P.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image274PTombaughTenagrafrance.htm

10P Tempel 2
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image10Ptempelfrance.htm

280P Larsen
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image280PLarsenfrance.htm

C 2012 Panstarrs K1, red filter.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012K1Panstarrsfrance.htm

Date:  Thu, 07 Mar 2013 19:52:52 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2011 L4 Panstarrs
Some more close images of L4 Panstars at my blog page. Taken with Orion
ED80mm and DMK51As.

This one is interesting to me, the vertical differences are likely to be
equipment vibration.
The intensity changes are likely to be atmospheric fluctuations. Not
rotation of nucleus??
Panstarrs 20130305 - 4 60sec avi's, each bead is 1 sec
apart.

Does any one know the rotation period of the nucleus?

May be some Stereo images in the next few days....

kind regards, Alan.

Date:  Thu, 07 Mar 2013 18:39:34 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2012 K5 (LINEAR) infront of PGC 14768
Hi all,

Here is a shot of K5 linear taken earlier today. The comet was directly infront of the spiral galaxy PGC 14768. The comet nucleus is just below and right of the galaxy nucleus with the faint tail projecting out of the galaxy rather like the aftermath of a galaxy collision!

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_k5_linear_mar7th.jpg

March 7th, 2013. 09:48 UTC.

20" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E camera. 4x2mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Fri, 08 Mar 2013 09:55:05 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  c2013 S1 ISON from ASO March 8 showing tail development
Showing Comet ISON (c/2013 S1) from this morning at 03:37 UT (March 8); north is up in this image and tail is showing some possible development nearly due east of comet.
Comet was a bit brighter (m1=15.8ccd) but otherwise unchanged.

http://www.arksky.org/php/cdata_admin.php?object=c2012xxxS1xxxISON
or
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/Com18CCC436.jpg

Scale of image is 14' x 11'. Skies were bright with high intermittent cirrus.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/ 
Date:  Fri, 08 Mar 2013 18:02:43 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 246P/NEAT (March 7th, 2013.)
Hi all,

Here is a shot from yesterday taken of 246P/NEAT currently located in Sagittarius. A nice little tail is seen amongst the fair dense star field. I'd estimate it at around mag 14.5 comparing it with neighboring stars.

March 7th, 2013. 18:48 UTC.
20" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E camera. 4x2mins unfiltered. Crescent moon only 15deg away. Sun alt -15deg.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/246p_neat_2013_03_07dp.jpg

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Sun, 10 Mar 2013 18:59:52 +0000
From:  Μanos Kardasis 
Subject:  Comet 2011L4 from Athens-Greece (38 North)
Ηello,  I've been experimenting for days on the comet, even in daylight, but the weather didn't cooperate. Today I managed to find and capture the comet digitally with a DMK attached on SWED80 with FL600mm.I firstly managed to see the comet on my screen a few  minutes before sunset and followed it till it set.

Here is an image I processed from a video with all obs data on it. In that time the comet was just 3 deg. above horizon! It must be really bright now maybe near 0. Even Jupiter is hard  at that altitude:

http://www.astrovox.gr/forum/album_pic.php?pic_id=16133

I followed the comet till 1.45 deg till its lost in the W horizon clouds.Here is a video with all the data below:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hUA3IVv-M-A

more will follow...

Manos Kardasis

Date:  Mon, 11 Mar 2013 12:16:43 -0700
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] PABSTARRS [2 Attachments]
Dear Mike,

I hate to say it, but these look like images of a contrail. I saw the comet
visually last night; the central condensation is very bright relative to the
tail, and the tail is oriented more vertically with respect to that
condensation.

Sincerely,

Alan 

Date:  Mon, 11 Mar 2013 19:04:44 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: PABSTARRS [2 Attachments]
Alan. I am afraid I must agree with the contrail. I have received a lot of pictures from people asking me if they saw the comet. In every case I simply ask them to send me two images taken of the same place in the sky or on the horizion. Each case when blinked showed the contrail moving across the sky quickly. Would be good for anyone when in doubt to take two or three say 5 sec exp and see if the area is moving. The comet like Alan said will show a bright false nuk and only move towards the horizion over a few minutes.
Mike

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Alan Hale wrote:
>
> Dear Mike,
>
> I hate to say it, but these look like images of a contrail. I saw the comet
> visually last night; the central condensation is very bright relative to the
> tail, and the tail is oriented more vertically with respect to that
> condensation.
>
> Sincerely,
>
> Alan
>

From:  Mike Mattei 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] PABSTARRS
Hi Alan

We were looking with a print out of the location of the comet from Guide 9
and we were seeing contrails but they all moved to our south this did not
move with them.

Unfortunately we were clouded out last night when we could have checked it.

I have a question about my comet images of which I have many years of do you
have a repository for images? If so I would like to know if I can summit
mine.

Mike

Date:  Tue, 12 Mar 2013 08:30:43 -0400
From:  Mike Mattei 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] PABSTARRS
Alan

I intend to agree with you it is a contrail, would you believe it is in the
right place and nearly at the same angle, what luck but it's not the comet.

Any comet images I have taken in the 1970s are in the Harvard Observatory
plate stacks archives, my current images start around 2000 and up.

Mike

_____

From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Alan Hale
Sent: Monday, March 11, 2013 6:29 PM
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] PABSTARRS

Dear Mike,

I don't have anything "official," but I do maintain a fairly large
collection of comet images that I've gathered up over the years. I'd be
especially interested in images of comets from the 1970s and 1980s.

Probably best to contact me off-list.

Sincerely,

Alan

Date:  Tue, 12 Mar 2013 21:44:59 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2012 T5 Bressi (March 12th, 2013.)
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained earlier today of C/2012 T5 Bressi. It was quite a bit fainter than i expected appearing as only a small fuzzy patch.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_t5_2013_03_12dp.jpg

25cm reflector @F3.4. SBIG ST10-XME. Single 60sec exposure unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Wed, 13 Mar 2013 01:13:58 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-03-11 P2013CE31 C2013D1 280P (98P not found)
Dear all

Here are the observations from yesterday evening, 11/3

P/2013 CE31 MOSS
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/P2013CE31_MOSS.html

C/2013 D1 Holvorcem
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013D1_Holvorcem.html

280P Larsen
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/280P_Larson.html

98P: at 2013 03 12.03UT, the comet was not visible, fainter that
mag=19.5 after a
search within a circle of radius 5 arcmin around the expected position.
Unfiltered CCD ST8XME. Blink of 3 images, each 8x120s recentered with
Astrometrica.

Best

Luc
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/Welcome.html 
Date:  Tue, 12 Mar 2013 20:55:01 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  PanSTARRS on 2013-03-12
Here is a view of Comet 2012 L4 PanStarrs from the Arkansas Sky Observatories on
the west edge of Petit Jean Mountain tonight, March 12 at about 8:15 p.m. local
time. The thin crescent moon is seen above distant Mount Magazine to the west.
This is a 4 second exposure with a simple digital camera.

Note that at no time was the comet conspicuous to the naked eye, but could be
easily spotted, clouds permitting, with 10 x 50 binoculars.

Photo by Clay and Patsy Sherrod, Petit Jean Mountain

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2117.0.html

Date:  Wed, 13 Mar 2013 14:19:18 -0000
From:  James 
Subject:  Comet PanSTARRS from Arches National Park
Clouds nearly ruined the photo op but was able to capture PanSTARRS
C/2011 L4 and the moon through a thin gap above the horizon in Arches
National Park, Utah, USA. The silhouette of Balanced Rock can be seen in
the right of the frame:

PanSTARRS, Moon, and Balanced Rock


Canon Xti, 124 mm f/6.3, 8 sec. exposure, ISO 1600, 3 panel mosaic

James Champagne

Date:  Wed, 13 Mar 2013 20:17:27 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 Pan-STARRS (March 13th, 2013.)
Hi all,

My first sighting of this now much photographed comet. Through 10x50s the head appeared starlike with a very faint tail discernible tail. The nearby Moon made a nice pairing.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_03_13dp

Canon 450D with 55mm lens. 10x0.6secs @ ISO3200 shot through my upstairs window!

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************
Date:  Wed, 13 Mar 2013 20:37:11 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Panstarrs snapshot from Suffolk UK
Endless hail and rain here in the UK this evening, but a brief gap
in the clouds enabled me to grab a snapshot through an upstairs
window, with a fixed 300mm mirror lens I first used on
Iras-Araki-Alcock in 1983! This is a half second exposure in strong
twilight, through a cloud gap lasting a few seconds......

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2011l4_20130313_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

Comet page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html 

Date:  Wed, 13 Mar 2013 22:21:31 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comets C/2011 J1 and C/2006 S3
Hi all,

Here are two more comets obtained today. C/2011 J1 LINEAR and C/2006 S3 (LONEOS) located in Ursa Major and Libra respectively and both showing short tails.

Both 17" CDK @F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 4x2mins unfiltered.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_j2_linear_2013_03_13dp.jpg

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2006_s3_loneos_2013_03_13dp.jpg

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Thu, 14 Mar 2013 19:01:52 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Comet PANSTARRS visible to naked eye at sunset
I got a heads-up from my astronomy mentor that comet C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS was visible to the naked eye. I grabbed my DLSLR camera and tripod and ran outside. It was quite a sight!

Please take a look at my web page -- images, isophotes, orbit diagram, light curve -- all kinds of data.

http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm .

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Hampshire, IL

Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
New Images http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
Pier Design http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm
Daily Bread Inspirational Page (Helicopter Parable) http://users.foxvalley.net/~dpersyk/DailyBread/

Date:  Fri, 15 Mar 2013 15:41:06 -0000
From:  amar10sharmaa 
Subject:  117P, 246P, C/2011 R1, C/2006 S3, 273P
Hello comet imagers,

I could lay my hand on capturing some comets after 2 months. Ofcourse I am hindered with very bad weather (always hazy or cloudy) and observing conditions (increasing light pollution).

All images taken with SBIG ST8XME unguided and unfiltered, on C-14 Edge HD working at f/6.9 (with focal reducer). The following images were taken over few hours of few nights in this week, not on one night. The simple images are produced below:

1) 117P/Helin-Roman-Alu:

https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5855542091238648290

2) 246P/NEAT

https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5855548669269040434

3) C/2011 R1 McNaught:

https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5855552199421994258

4) C/2006 S3 LONEOS:

https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5855552714554894482

5) 273P/Pons-Gambart: Somehow this image seemed to reject being stacked. So I use only 2 subs.

https://picasaweb.google.com/100263423283309558687/FaintCometsAndSupernovae#5855591022403945234

6) I also captured 63/P Wild but its come out bad due to excessive haze and light pollution.

Wanted to shoot more comets from my list, but sadly could not. Thanks, Amar A. Sharma. Bangalore, India.

Date:  Fri, 15 Mar 2013 21:25:22 -0000
From:  "Luca B." 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 Panstarrs from Italy
>From the beach 30km from Rome, from 18.58 to 19.19h LT.
Clear sky, windy and cold.
Seen with naked eye, estimation somewhat between 1.5 and 2 mag.

First is stack of 20 frames at various ISO and times, starting with 1s 800iso closing at 1.3s 6400iso, stack to comet core with Registax 2.
Canon 5DmkIII mod + Nikon 180/2.8 @ f/5.6, crop&resize.

Second is one of the 20 frames, 1.3s 5000iso. Cropped, not processd, only some denoise and saturation.

Third has been done with a Tamron 24-135 f/3.5-5.6 @ 67mm f/5.6 8s 3200iso, flatted, rebalanced in colours, and light curves.

http://img850.imageshack.us/img850/7084/megastack1res80noise50.jpg

http://img543.imageshack.us/img543/1135/img3234res.jpg

http://img62.imageshack.us/img62/3900/img3251res.jpg

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 - Tail So Close
Hello. I was look at a post by Martin McKenna at the ml board and it got me going back over some images from a couple of days ago. There is so much more of this comet tail out there. I haven found maybe the best image to process this on. It will take just the right exposure and height to get the faint stuff. All I can say is stand back from the screen and look at the entire image. It is reaching but----
Mike H.

Date:  Sat, 16 Mar 2013 22:35:15 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs LRGB image march 16
Hello

This image is from march 16 UT 18.15

Leica Apo 180/f-4.0 CCD Sigma 6303

L 3x 120 sec RGB 90/90/90sec

Michael Jäger
Stixendorf, Austria

https://ofncpa.bay.livefilestore.com/y1phiAMYEMj9JxkutUpr_hxwh_ijFTNRRc40-iotYzMeIN6EMpuWDIQxqchp-FqqjhkHLkP7mp0__Szre4uAwwqyvSWS0Tiu1YN/2011l420130316telelrgbweb.jpg?psid=1 

Date:  Sat, 16 Mar 2013 18:10:32 -0500

Subject:  comet Panstarrs March 16th
Hello everybody,

This was comet Panstarrs last evening with CCD. Unfortunately my filter
wheel gave up and therefore I had only the Luminance filter available.
Anyway Michael send me his color data and I´ll try to finally make an LRGB.

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/135_Panstarrs.jpg

Stixendorf/Austria where Michael is living nearby.

/137_Panstarrs_tele.jpg

Subject:  Just after comet Panstarrs Set
Just after Panstarrs set on the 12th, I waited to see if I could capture the magical evening lights..Zodiacal Lights

Here is the image I capture that night using a canon T2i, 18mm Lens, 800 iso, 25 sec..

Photo was taken over looking Marana, Arizona..

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1553827235/pic/2052648339/view?picmode=&mode=tn&order=ordinal&start=1&count=20&dir=asc

Joe

Date:  Sun, 17 Mar 2013 12:42:52 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2011 L4 Panstarrs
My go at making a Panstarrs STEREO data movie. Image data courtesy of
STEREO/SECCHI/NASA/NNRL.

STEREO HI1b 20130312-panstarrs AVI 35mb

Processed a little differently from Karl Battam's movies. I have registered
the images too the stars, then done the differencing between frames. This
brings out the dynamic Ion tail, that shows regular lumps being ejected
from the nucleus area(rotation aspect?). The fan of the dust tail seems to
be expanding slowly. The first spike tail(?) that ends up almost horizontal
in the last frames seems very consistent no dynamic variations.

I see that many are trying to get ground based images of the details shown
by STEREO. Try to use the technique that Rob Kaufman had used for Comet
Lovejoy's fading dust tail. Which was seen in DSLR images at many degrees.

Rob, perhaps you could elaborate on the process details.

Kind regards, Alan Watson.

On Fri, Mar 15, 2013 at 9:38 AM, Alan Watson wrote:

> Here is my processing of the Stereo data available to the public.
>
> STEREO HI1b 20130312-panstarrs.png
>
> Compare to images of McNaught at the blog....
>
> http://cometal-comets.blogspot.com.au/2013/02/comet-c2011-l4-panstarrs.html
>
> Kind regards, Alan Watson
>

--
Kind regards, Alan Watson

Date:  Sun, 17 Mar 2013 22:05:14 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 (Pan-STARRS) March 17th, 2013.
Hi all,

By far my best view of this comet so far this evening. A miracle it was clear given it had been raining all day. Much easier to see now that its gained altitude and elongation from the Sun. Easily visible with the naked eye with a faint short tail just discernible.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_03_17dp.jpg

20 x 5secs for the comet and sky around it. 2x5secs for the horizon/scenery etc. Canon 500D @ ISO800 with 60mm lens.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

From:  akhen3sir 
Subject:  Pan-Starrs over Stonehenge, March 17
Very lucky to have had clear skies to the west of Stonehenge after a day
that started with a blizzard, continued with rain but ended with a
spectacular sunset.

These images were taken with a Canon 1100D.

Pan-Starrs over Stonehenge
ist>

Simon

Date:  Mon, 18 Mar 2013 21:27:57 +0100
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  A lesson in PANSTARRS-o-graphy for small cameras
Having finally been lucky with PANSTARRS from the ground as well (what a
different experience to that observing flight - 20 meters walking to the
left instead of rising 12.5 km up :-) I've prepared the album
http://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10200105476014579.1073741826.1080556720&type=1&l=71ee26fb1e
(or http://t.co/9s1n7dgHBx for short) with 16 images taken with a rather
simple camera, with captions fully documenting the technical data and also
comet elevation and solar depression at each instant. May be helpful for
planning your own efforts.

Daniel

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2011 L4 tails of Comet Panstarrs - march 19
Great work Michael,
Tail structure becoming apparent with longer exposures, the spike vertical
tail and the more dynamic tail just next to it then the larger dust fan.
well done, kind regards, Alan Watson.

Date:  Thu, 21 Mar 2013 00:27:39 +0100
From:  Gerhard Dangl 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS shining through trees
Hello all,

on March 19, 2013 I made an image sequence of C/2011 L4 in Nonndorf -
C47. In the created video one can see the comet shining through trees
during the set.

Comet page with data, images, video and reports (sorry German only)
http://www.dangl.at/2013/comet/c2011l4.htm

Direct link to the video (8.9MB)
http://www.dangl.at/2013/comet/c2011l4_20130319.avi

Best regards
Gerhard
www.dangl.at

Date:  Thu, 21 Mar 2013 19:52:50 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2011 L4 - structure in the dust tail
Gidday Michael,

Sorry to be a dissenting voice here, as I don't fully appreciate what
the Larson-Sekanina
does?
The vertical striations don't seem to relate to striations seen in STEREO
at an orientation of 90 degrees to those in your image.
I don't think it adds to the base image, which with further exposure
duration and stacking of similar images should push out more structure.

kind reagrds, Alan Watson
Melbourne, Australia
( see Ellen...)

Date:  Thu, 21 Mar 2013 11:17:19 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Re: 2011 L4 - structure in the dust tail
Hi Alan

Interesting note. Fact is, my image does not show the outer
Tail sections like Stereo.

In my image the tails are also good to see without LS-filtering. I can post the picture today or tomorrow. How it works:
The LS-filter suppresses the diffuse part of the dust tail. So that the rays are even more visible. Ask for additional comment

Michael

Date:  Fri, 22 Mar 2013 00:37:26 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Pan-STARRS with striations
Dear all,
here is a fresh image of this evening, showing striations in the dust tail. Also a small hint of the sodium tail (tbc) is visible;
this one seems to have decreased the visibility respect to 15 March.
The first link is a "natural" processing, while the second one had been enhanced with Larson-Sekanina algorithm.

Tech data: TEC 140, SBIG STL-11000 CCD, luminance filter, 7x120 s exp. Guiding on the comet.
Approx field: 2x1.3 21 March 2013, 18.56 UT
Location: Tradate, Italy.

Links:
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-Comet_mar21_TEC14011k_L_7x120s_average_el5_ddpps_1200pix_1363905300.jpg
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-Comet_mar21_TEC14011k_L_7x120s_median-gradient_el4_ddpLSoverlay_1200pix_1363905300.jpg

Lorenzo

--
____________________________________________________________
Lorenzo Comolli
Internet: http://astrosurf.com/comolli/
E-mail: mailto:comolli@libero.it

Gruppo Astronomico Tradatese
http://www.gruppoastronomicotradatese.it/
Gruppo Astrofili G. e A. Bernasconi di Saronno
http://astrosurf.com/saronno/

Date:  Fri, 22 Mar 2013 09:56:34 -0000
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Comet Pan Starrs 3/21, Kofa National Wildlife Refuge
http://www.astrophoto.us/ps/321/321.html

After 3 days of "clouded out", finally got a look at Comet Pan Starrs

All of my previous posts of comet images (1000mm, 610mm, 400mm, 300m) are raw images, ZERO enhancement. I started playing with the tone curve adjustment (& brightness adjustment) in Canon's DPP (Digital Photo Professional). Followed by "Preview" on Mac. I.e., no Photoshop.

See te 610mm shot (enhanced) from 3/16 at

http://www.astrophoto.us/ps/ps.html

There are some enhanced images from deep shots (on the Web), which shot extensive "fan" dust tail, plus faint ion tail (fan shape).

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2006 S3 LONEOS passes NGC5796
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained today showing 2006 S3 passing a couple of distant galaxies in Libra. The comet is showing a very faint dust tail best seen in the negative image.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2006_s3_loneos_2013_03_24dp.jpg

March 24th, 2013. 10:37 UTC.
17"CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 5x2mins unfiltered. Gibbous Moon ~80deg away.

Best Wishes

Damian

Il 22/03/2013 00:37, Lorenzo Comolli ha scritto:
> Dear all,
> here is a fresh image of this evening, showing striations in the dust tail. Also a small hint of the sodium tail (tbc) is visible;
> this one seems to have decreased the visibility respect to 15 March.
> The first link is a "natural" processing, while the second one had been enhanced with Larson-Sekanina algorithm.
>
> Tech data: TEC 140, SBIG STL-11000 CCD, luminance filter, 7x120 s exp. Guiding on the comet.
> Approx field: 2x1.3 21 March 2013, 18.56 UT
> Location: Tradate, Italy.
>
> Links:
> http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-Comet_mar21_TEC14011k_L_7x120s_average_el5_ddpps_1200pix_1363905300.jpg
> http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-Comet_mar21_TEC14011k_L_7x120s_median-gradient_el4_ddpLSoverlay_1200pix_1363905300.jpg

http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/com39.htm

Lorenzo

Il 22/03/2013 00:37, Lorenzo Comolli ha scritto:
Dear all,
here is a fresh image of this evening, showing striations in the dust tail. Also a small hint of the sodium tail (tbc) is visible;
this one seems to have decreased the visibility respect to 15 March.
The first link is a "natural" processing, while the second one had been enhanced with Larson-Sekanina algorithm.

Tech data: TEC 140, SBIG STL-11000 CCD, luminance filter, 7x120 s exp. Guiding on the comet.
Approx field: 2°x1.3° 21 March 2013, 18.56 UT
Location: Tradate, Italy.

Links:
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-Comet_mar21_TEC14011k_L_7x120s_average_el5_ddpps_1200pix_1363905300.jpg
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-Comet_mar21_TEC14011k_L_7x120s_median-gradient_el4_ddpLSoverlay_1200pix_1363905300.jpg

Lorenzo

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2013 E2 (Iwamoto) - March 24th, 2013.
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained yesterday of newly discovered comet E2 Iwamoto which is currently located in Aquarius. Its looking quite bright at around mag 11 and a faint tenuous dust tail is detected.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_e2_iwamoto_2013_03_24dp.jpg

March 24th, 2013. 19:01 UTC.
20" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 4x2mins unfiltered. Sun at -15deg alt.

Best Wishes

Date:  Thu, 28 Mar 2013 12:36:51 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Image of comet C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) with red tail...

C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) @ 2013-03-15Reflector GSO 20cm f/4 + Canon EOS-350D (8×1 + 20x2 + 24x3 + 6×4 sec. at ISO 800)The comet C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) imaged during twilight on March 15 2013 before hide behind trees of Sierra Enguera, Spain. Besides of wide and curved dust tail of 1 deg. long, the comet shows a straight and narrow redish tail of unconfirmed nature: a sodium tail?
If as seen have not been detected sodium in this tail, then how could explain a red tail? There are several images taken with DSLR showing this reddish tail...
Image link:http://astrob.in/full/37238/
Post link:http://cometografia.es/2013/03/cola-roja-panstarrs/

Saludos.

José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 
Date:  Thu, 28 Mar 2013 21:20:50 -0000

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2011l4_20130328_mpm.jpg

Martin

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

Date:  Thu, 28 Mar 2013 23:23:12 -0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  2011l4 March 28

Hello all
Comet observed in near perfect conditions at dusk here in Highland Scotland evening, Just before
moon rose I could see the
comet with my naked eye and trace the tail (also naked eye) for about a degree. The comet was easily
seen with the naked eye and it must be still around mag 3. It is a lovely looking comet, broad fan
tail with one edge sharply defined and the other edge diffuse. Bright yellowy colour central
condensation, which is small and sharp. Great view.Perfectly framed in binoculars and low power
telescope. If I dont get another view of this comet, I will be well satisfied with this one. Image
attached (slightly trailed as I let the EQ6 track with out any guiding. 20:41 UT 73s exposure ISO
800 Canon 1000d. 80mm ED Apo f/6.

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=959&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association 

Date:  Fri, 29 Mar 2013 18:00:17 -0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  C/2011l4 PanSTARRS  20130328 IMAGES
Hello all,
I imaged this comet last night with a C14 and SBIG ST9XE from Highland Scotland in good conditions
and transparency. This was the first night with some dark sky and no interference from moonlight at
dusk. The comet was easily seen with the naked eye and the tail stretching around 1 degree was also
comfortably seen without averted vision. Images are placed on the British Astronomical Association
Comet Gallery at the following links:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=967&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=968&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Best wishes and clear skies
Denis Buczynski

Date:  Sun, 31 Mar 2013 18:17:55 +0200
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Panstarrs in the Easter's morning
This morning, together with friends Cesare, Paolo and my father, we've challenged the cold and the very early rising to observe
the Easter's comet. The "surprise in the egg" was expected: M31 was at 6 from the comet.

Another surprise was noting the disappearance of the sodium and ion tails, as also the synchronic bands are no more visible.

Images:
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-IMG_6085_v1_RES1024_1364745081.jpg
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-5D200mm-f5.6_11x60s_tot11min_el2_RES1024_1364719990.jpg
http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-PanStarrs_P7511k_13x180s_tot39min_L_average_el5_pscrop_RES1024_1364744569.jpg

Tech data:
http://spaceweather.com/gallery/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=80155
http://spaceweather.com/gallery/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=80128
http://spaceweather.com/gallery/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=80153

Happy Easter to all!
Lorenzo

Date:  Mon, 01 Apr 2013 17:26:32 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2012 L2 (LINEAR) - April 1st, 2013.
Hi all,

Here is a shot of L2 Linear obtained last night. Currently located in Taurus at 12th mag and having recently passed M45. No discernible tail is detected. Perihelion is on May 9th but it will only come very slightly closer to the Sun by then and will be poorly placed in the northern hemisphere.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_L2_linear_2013_04_01dp.jpg

20" CDK@F4.5 PL11002M camera. 5x2mins unfiltered. Comet at 21deg altitude.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Mon, 01 Apr 2013 17:27:34 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  2011PanSTARRS March 31 images
Hello/all
Links to my images of this comet taken with instruments of focal lengths 300mm, 500mm, 2000mm on
March 31 are here.

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=980&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=981&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=983&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association 

Date:  Mon, 01 Apr 2013 22:07:50 +0200
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Panstarrs in the Easter's evening
After having sent the images of the Easter's morning, here are the ones from the evening. After 10 days raining, and looking at 10
days of rain in the weather forecasts, I've gained the maximum from Easter good weather.

Here are the evening images with TEC 140

Immagine

http://spaceweather.com/gallery/indiv_u ... d_id=80235

Immagine


Immagine

I add to the ones in the morning a color version:
Immagine

http://spaceweather.com/gallery/indiv_u ... d_id=80233

Regards,
Lorenzo

Date:  Tue, 02 Apr 2013 00:36:29 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  2011L4 Panstarrs widefield from last april 1
Hello

Bad weather in Austria for a long time too.
Last evening i decide to go to the alps.
Near Hohe Tauern i found dark and clear sky.

This is the result(after 6 hours in the car)

Leica-Apo 180/4.0 and Sigma 6303

2x 150sec bin 2x2
2x 210sec bin 2x2

LRGB follows

Best regards
Michael Jäger

https://ofncpa.bay.livefilestore.com/y1phN7drSEuueVgKIEU9iWZ2-iO7KQHaBCxQgkOXXSePhY6nLVfNmjQUziFPEg_eK0Egf-Btj8Yq8FjnigtGiQhrYD2uTOzD9OH/2011L420130401teleweb.jpg?psid=1

Date:  Tue, 02 Apr 2013 18:33:16 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2012 L4 (Pan-STARRS) - April 1st, 2013.
Hi all,

I trekked over to a dark site last night around 30 miles away to see the comet. Its certainly faded allot since my last view of it on March 17th but still a lovely object in binoculars and with M31 close-by they make a nice pairing. Both Canon 550d with 50mm lens @ ISO3200. 24x10secs and 6x10secs.

Close-up:  http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_04_01dp.jpg

Scenic view: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_04_01dp2.jpg

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

You should be proud and I can't wait to see it in publication.
Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 03 Apr 2013 18:43:18 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 (Pan-STARRS) - April 2nd, 2013.
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained last night. Very good conditions with low humidity and good transparency. A group of us headed over to the dark sky site again. I also include a negative view which helps to see the dust tail.

35 x 10secs @ ISO800. Canon 550d on static camera tripod. 50mm prime lens.

RGB: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_04_02dp.jpg

Negative: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_04_02neg_dp.jpg

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/

Date:  Thu, 04 Apr 2013 18:09:05 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  P/2012 B1 Pan-STARRS (April 4th, 2013.)
Hi all,

Here is a shot of P/2012 B1 taken today. 15th magnitude and located in Virgo. It looks quite interesting as it shows a faint dust tail but also an short anti-tail pointing ahead of the nucleus.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/p2012_b1_panstarrs_2013_04_04dp.jpg

17"CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 8x2mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian
