Date:  Fri, 05 Apr 2013 00:25:17 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  C/2011L4 PanSTARRS near M31 April 04
Hello all,
A late clearance tonight enabled me to get the attached image of the comet (at the link below) as
it continues it's
passage past M31. The comet is fading but is still a naked eye view and slightly brighter than M31
to the naked eye. It has been a good comet to view and has been very photogenic to image post
perihelion for northern hemisphere observers. It has not come close to being a "Great Comet", but to
be able to see a naked eye comet close to M31 in the sky means to me that we cannot be disappointed
with its "performance".
Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=998&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200 

Date:  Fri, 05 Apr 2013 01:31:33 -0000
From:  josephbrimacombe 
Subject:  Comet C/2011 L4 Panstarrs Narrowfield L from New Mexico Skies - April 4, 2013
Hi All

18 x 1 min frames in quite a dark sky with a 51-cm RCOS and STL11K camera. Getting easier and easier to image.

Joe

Joseph Brimacombe

Date:  Mon, 08 Apr 2013 00:38:38 +0200
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  Comet C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) - 2013, April 07.5
Hi All

Our image of Comet C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) taken on 2013, April 07.5
remotely from H06 New Mexico.

Details are on the caption:

http://bit.ly/Y70hxW

In the last enlargement it was subtracted a median coma model to the
original coma of the comet. A bright shell toward the sun direction is
clearly visible (the brightest central pixel represents the false
nucleus). Each pixel image at the projected distance of the comet
represents about 800 km.

Ciao,
Ernesto Guido, Nick Howes & Martino Nicolini
http://remanzacco.blogspot.com
http://twitter.com/comets77

Date:  Mon, 08 Apr 2013 14:19:17 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  memory lane with anti-tails
Hello all,
Whilst we are all observing C/2011L4 PanSTARRS as it moves it way northwards, one of the most
striking aspects of its appearance is the apparent anti-tail it

displays.

It is worth remembering that a "Great Comet" with the most famous of anti-tails was observed 56
years ago in April 1957, C/1956 R1 (Arend-Roland).The

anti-tail on this comet, although well recorded and remembered was only visible for a very short
time. It was first seen on April 22 1957 on images made by

R.Fogelquist at Uppsala in Sweden, when the comet was around magnitude 1.5. The anti-tail was then
well recorded by many other observatories around the world

but was not visible on images taken after May 2 1957. So only 11 days elapsed when this famous
feature was visible, but the interest and impact that that

feature had amongst comet observers was intense.

We are more used to seeing anti-tails in comet images these days, comets C/2007N3 Lulin and C/2009P1
Garrrad are some most recent examples. C/2011L4

PanSTARRS being the latest.Is this because of better imaging techniques? The first image I have seen
the anti-tail on C/2011L4 was on around 2013 April 16 and it is still visible on images taken last

night on 2013 May 7. So this feature has endured longer than the anti-tail of C/1956R1. I expect the
visibility of these anti-tails is all due to observing geometry

and perspective. They are very striking features of a comet when seen at their most prominent.

A read through the description of the apparition of C/1957R1 in Gary Kronk's Cometography Vol 4
pages 508-520 is well worth it.

Below are links to images of C/1956 R1(Arend-Roland)taken by R.L Waterfield, with a 6 inch Cooke
Triplet lens in England scanning the period when the anti-tail

was visible. The dates of these images are as follows: 1957April 24.9 , 1957April 28.8, 1957April
29.9. 1957May 2.9.

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1029&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1030&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1031&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1032&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1033&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Enjoy this trip down memory lane.

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

Date:  Tue, 09 Apr 2013 23:17:31 +0200
From:  Josef Müller 
Subject:  C/2013 L4 (Panstarrs) am 07.April 2013
Wenn auch verspätet (ich war fast 3 Wochen "nichtastronomisch"
unterwegs), so will ich dennoch
mein Panstarrs-Foto zeigen. Ja, die Brennweite meines Newtons ist mit
1447mm zu groß! Eigentlich
hätte ich das Fotografieren bei einem FWHM-Wert von 3,8" einstellen
müssen; hinzu kommt die
gewaltige Luftmasse - der Komet stand nur wenig über dem Horizont.
ich wollte aber unbedingt ein Foto von diesem außergewöhnlichen Kometen!
(Ich hoffe, dass ich diesen Schweifstern noch einmal ablichten kann;
dann mit geringerer Brennweite!)

http://www.westerwald-astro.de/jjm/kometen/c-2011l4-panstarrs_hp.php?BackPath=kometen

Gruß Josef Müller

Date:  Thu, 11 Apr 2013 18:51:42 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2011 R1 McNaught  - April 11th, 2013.
Hi all,

A much deeper image was captured of this comet today. I'd estimate the dust tail extends to around 15' in length. A lovely comet for larger telescopes.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_r1_mcnaught_2013_04_11dp.jpg

17" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 8 x 2mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

, "sigarro@btinternet.com" , "Callum Potter" , "jds@ast.cam.ac.uk" , "buczynski8166@btinternet.com" , "Nick Howes" , "Richard Miles" , "Guy Hurst" , "Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com" , "Tom Kerss" , "comet@aerith.net"
Date: Thursday, April 11, 2013, 5:51 PM

[Attachment(s) from Damian Peach included below]

Hi all,
A much deeper image was captured of this comet today. I'd estimate the dust tail extends to around 15' in length. A lovely comet for larger telescopes.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_r1_mcnaught_2013_04_11dp.jpg

17" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 8 x 2mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Date:  Sun, 14 Apr 2013 22:23:44 +0200
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Panstarrs April 14, from Italy
Dear list,
here is my latest image of Panstarrs, made this morning in the Appenines (at Pian dell'Arm, Italy).

TEC 140 (f.l. 1011 mm), SBIG STL-11000, LRGB filters, tracking on the comet. Exposure 50-10-10-10 minutes (total 1h20min).

Immagine

http://spaceweather.com/submissions/pics/l/Lorenzo-Comolli-vc_panstarrs_TEC14011k_LRGB_50-10-10-10_tot1h20min_el1_RES1024_1365969416.jpg

Regards,
Lorenzo

Date:  Mon, 15 Apr 2013 12:40:35 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  2011L4 wide field images 20130415
Hello all,
I was able to image this comet in transparent skies combined with warm gale force winds in Highland
Scotland.
Temperature at 01:00 UT was +12 degrees Centigrade as opposed to -12 degrees Centigrade last week!
The comet is fading and I could not see it with the naked eye. However it is still an impressive
comet to image. Links below.
Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1067&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1068&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1069&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

From:  "Luca B." 
Subject:  Last C/2011 L4 Panstarrs
14 and 15 april 2013 . Comet estimation mag. 6-6.2 .
First super wide: Canon 5D mkIII mod + Tamron 24-135 @ 89mm f6.3 single 3.2s 25600iso 14apr2013 21.08h LT (note M31 and top right NGC7789)
Second: Canon 5D mkIII mod + Nikon 180mm @ f5.6 25x1m 3200iso 15apr2013 4.30h LT (note NGC281 and NGC7789)
Third: Canon 5D mkIII mod + Nikon 300mm @ f5.6 7x30s 5000iso 14apr2013 21.30h LT

Date:  Thu, 18 Apr 2013 22:33:58 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-04-14 & 17 : 78P, P2012B1, C2012F3

Dear all,

My observations from April 14 and 17: 3 comets observed at
both nights

C/2012 F3
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2012F3_PANSTARRS.html


P/2012 B1, mag 16, bright, tail well visible
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/P2012B1_PANSTARRS.html


78P Gerhels - well visible the 14th, but too much Moon the
17th, I posted the image 'for the record'
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/78P_Gehrels.html


Best

Luc

Date:  Fri, 19 Apr 2013 00:23:35 -0000
From:  hiro 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) on April 13, 2013 UTC
Hi,

Here is a frame of the comet:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/8658955049/

Dust and gas in the area are visible in the lower half of this frame taken with 105mm lens August 2011.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/6202846967/

There is a huge ring-shaped red emission in the area.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/6224453705/

Thank you for looking.

hiro 

Date:  Fri, 19 Apr 2013 15:12:37 +0200

Date:  Sun, 21 Apr 2013 20:54:57 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  comet C/2012 F6 an active  bright comet
Hello everybody,

I used the opportunity to use a new installed remote observatory in Namibia
by a friend of mine and imaged comet C/2012 F6 over several nights. The
object was pretty law in altitude and zodiacal light disturbed the
observation but anyway here are some of the images:

This one from this morning is my favorite:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/146_Lemmoncolor_21_04.jpg

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/145_Lemmon_21_04.jpg

And here are the other ones:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/147_Lemmoncolor_19_04.jpg

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/148_Lemmon_20_04.jpg

best regards

Gerald

From:  David Strange 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 PanSTARRS images 19th April
C/2011 L4 PanSTARRS images taken 2013-04-19 with a Celestron 8" Hyperstar @ f/2
from the Norman Lockyer Observatory, Sidmouth, east Devon.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/39492103@N03/8667848649/in/photostream/
http://www.flickr.com/photos/39492103@N03/8667854409/in/photostream/
http://www.flickr.com/photos/39492103@N03/8667859997/in/photostream/
http://www.flickr.com/photos/39492103@N03/8668968218/in/photostream/
http://www.flickr.com/photos/39492103@N03/8669180210/in/photostream/

David 

Date:  Sun, 21 Apr 2013 20:36:26 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2011 L4 PanSTARRS images 19th April
Hi David,
Great images of this comet. It shows how good and powerful a fast corrected system can perform. I want to put these images on the BAA Comet Gallery but I cannot save the images form within Flicker (they are copyrighted and download blocked). Can you copy them to cmailto:cometobs@baa.org of to my personal email address. Many thanks.
Denis
PS will you be able to make it to the Comet Section Meeting in Northampton on May 18?

From: Gerald Rhemann

Sent: Sunday, April 21, 2013 7:54 PM

Subject: [Comet-Images] comet C/2012 F6 an active bright comet

Hello everybody,

I used the opportunity to use a new installed remote observatory in Namibia by a friend of mine and imaged comet C/2012 F6 over several nights. The object was pretty law in altitude and zodiacal light disturbed the observation but anyway here are some of the images:

This one from this morning is my favorite:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/146_Lemmoncolor_21_04.jpg

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/145_Lemmon_21_04.jpg

And here are the other ones:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/147_Lemmoncolor_19_04.jpg

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/148_Lemmon_20_04.jpg

best regards

Gerald

Michael Jäger

Date:  Tue, 23 Apr 2013 02:26:05 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  Re: comet Lemmon 2012 F6


--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Beautiful image Gerald. I am in the dark as how a comet showing off like this one is, even if it has been down south could go without an image here or somewhere I visit. This is the most beautiful comet in the sky now.
> Mike

It certainly is an exquisite image Gerald, congratulations! Mike, this comet has been massively photographed at all scales from the south for several months, although images have dried up a bit recently because it is now low in early morning skies. There have been some great time series done on the tail dynamics.

You really need to check southern websites for southern comets, you're not going to see much on sites like Cloudy Nights, or even comet-images for that matter. Better going for popular forums such as Ice In Space, Oort Cloud etc. Sites like Michael Mattiazzo's (Southern Comets), ASV Comet Section etc have a lot on F6 and people like Dave Herald have done a huge amount of work on it too. I'm sure a lot of South American, New Zealand & southern African based sites have abundant material posted too.

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman
Bright, Victoria, Australia

>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Gerald Rhemann" wrote:

Date:  Wed, 24 Apr 2013 15:05:35 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  C/2012F6 on April 23 and April 24
Hello everybody,

The comet is still very active. On the four luminance images taken this
morning I cannot stack without lose of resolution in the tail. Thus I only
used one image for the upload. I´ll make a video on that. Anyway here are
the b&w shots. The LRGB will follow asap:

April 23rd:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/149_Lemmon_23_04.jpg

April 24th:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/150_Lemmon_24_04.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Thu, 25 Apr 2013 18:46:31 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Image Processing for Comets
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi list,

I wrote a book about the different aspects, methods and technics of
imaging comets and how to process the images.

I think it is good for beginners but also interesting for advanced
comet photographers.

You can read more at http://www.cometchaser.de/imageprocessingcomets.html

Feel free to send me your feedback.

- --
Best regards,

Stefan Beck

"All comet observers of the world"
http://www.cometchaser.de/observers/names.html

"Google map of known comet observers:"
http://www.cometchaser.de/observers/map.html

http://www.cometchaser.de
"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

http://www.cometchaser.de/d_index.html
"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch"

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----

Comment: Using GnuPG with Thunderbird - http://www.enigmail.net/

Date:  Mon, 29 Apr 2013 12:24:25 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  2011l4 April 28 images
Hello all,
I was able to image this comet for the first time for a while, just in the gap between the onset of
dark and the moon rising. The sky was a little hazy at the time of the exposures. This comet has
hardly changed it appearance in the last month or so. The fan tail is still very evident as is the
eastward pointing tail feature. It is fading but only slowly.
Images taken at 3 different focal lengths from last night are placed at the links below
Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1112&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1113&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1114&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Date:  Tue, 30 Apr 2013 14:13:49 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] comet C/2012 S1 ISON today
An interesting (and continuing) aspect of c2012 S1 is that it is not changing much at
all, morphologically speaking.
At close to the same time this image was taken we measured (12 measurements, April 29
and April 30 UT) the comet (Arkansas Sky Observatories, H45), using diaphragm
adjusted aperture via CCD and UCAC-4 star calibration, at still only 15.9-16.0 (m1);
the measurements were slightly variable since the comet is now so low in the NW skies
and subject to refractive interference from moment to moment.

Thus, in terms of brightness, the comet reached a plateau back in early March of 15.8
to 16.0 and pretty much remains there. Likewise the overall diameter and tail extent
remains unchanged as well.

The coma overall is still measured at a fairly consistent 10-11" arc with about an
18" length tail, these measurements virtually unchanged and non-increasing during the
past five weeks or more. A more pronounced stellar condensation is now seen within
the small coma, but other than that the tail, coma and brightness characteristics
remain unchanged in a very long period of time.

Based on current elements, the comet should have a total brightness of about 14.9;
This lack of physical development can be only partially attributable to orbital angle
and phase considerations.....the comet is simply not developing as hoped at this
time.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Thu, 02 May 2013 20:04:29 +1000
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2012 L2 image 2013 May 2.4UT
Hi Folks,

C/2012 L2 LINEAR is running 2 magnitudes brighter than anticipated.
I observed it tonight for the first time and made a visual estimate of 10.0.
The comet is of long period, hence another example of better than expected
performance.(2012 F6 the first example)
I have posted an image on my webpage.
http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

cheers,
Michael M

Hi all,

Subject:  C/2011 L4 widefield - May 9th

Hello all,
Please find links below to 2 images of this comet taken last night from my observatory in Highland
Scotland. The presence of permanent twilight at my 58d N latitude at this time of the year is
problematic for imaging and produces noisy images.
Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1168&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1167&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

PS The BAA Comet Section is holding a meeting in Northampton next Saturday May 18, everyone is
welcome. Details are at the following link

http://www.britastro.org/cometmeeting2013 

Date:  Mon, 13 May 2013 21:04:36 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  Panstarrs color version May 11
Hello all,

Here is the color version of the images taken on May 11:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/157_Panstarrs_11_05.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Mon, 13 May 2013 21:26:18 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comets today (May 13th, 2013.)
Hi all,

Here are some comet images taken earlier today. The data on Lemmon was poor quality but something was salvageable.

117P/Helin-Roman-Alu: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/117p_2013_05_13dp.jpg
17" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 5 x 3mins unfiltered.

C/2010 S1 (LINEAR): http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2010_s1_2013_05_13dp.jpg
17" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 5 x 3mins unfiltered.

C/2012 F6 (Lemmon): http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_05_13dp.jpg
25cm F3.6 Newt. SBIG-ST10XME. 8 x 2mins unfiltered.

117P looks quite interesting with a bright coma surrounding the nucleus and a faint narrow tail.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Date:  Tue, 14 May 2013 09:59:09 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  L4 Panstarrs on May 14th from New Mexico
This morning's image of L4 Panstarrs is attached, taken from New Mexico
one hour ago. The glow from gamma Cephei, half a degree to the SE, is
obvious in the lower left corner.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2011l4_20130514_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

Comet page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

Date:  Wed, 15 May 2013 11:36:16 -0400
From:  Paul Mortfield 
Subject:  Comet Lemmon - Tail event
Shot Comet Lemmon this morning again (May 15), still into morning twilight
at 11:23UT. Was able to run longer exposures (5x2minutes) and caught what
looks like some sort of disconnection or a section of gas blown out in the
comet's ion tail.

Using RCOS 16"f/8.9 and STL11K CCD from Sierra Remote Observatories,
California. North is Up.

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130515a.jpg

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130515a_inv.jpg

waiting to see if the European comet imagers caught it with their wide field
cameras.

It wasn't there a two days ago (may 13)

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130513a_inv.jpg

Hoping that some of our usual comet imagers caught this with their wide
field setups.

Gotta love comets.!

Cheers,

..paul. 

Date:  Wed, 15 May 2013 17:45:06 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando

Date: Wed, 15 May 2013 11:36:16 -0400
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Lemmon - Tail event

Shot Comet Lemmon this morning again (May 15), still into morning twilight at 11:23UT. Was able to run longer exposures (5x2minutes) and caught what looks like some sort of disconnection or a section of gas blown out in the comet’s ion tail.
Using RCOS 16”f/8.9 and STL11K CCD from Sierra Remote Observatories, California. North is Up. http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130515a.jpghttp://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130515a_inv.jpg waiting to see if the European comet imagers caught it with their wide field cameras. It wasn’t there a two days ago (may 13)http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130513a_inv.jpg Hoping that some of our usual comet imagers caught this with their wide field setups.Gotta love comets.! Date:  Wed, 15 May 2013 18:51:44 +0200
From:  jjchambo@hotmail.com
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lemmon - Tail event
Really impressive disconnection!

----- Mensaje original -----
De: Paul Mortfield
Enviado: 15-05-13 17:36
Para: comet-images@yahoogroups.com
Asunto: [Comet-Images] Comet Lemmon - Tail event

Shot Comet Lemmon this morning again (May 15), still into morning twilight at 11:23UT. Was able to run longer exposures (5x2minutes) and caught what looks like some sort of disconnection or a section of gas blown out in the comets ion tail.
Using RCOS 16f/8.9 and STL11K CCD from Sierra Remote Observatories, California. North is Up.
http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130515a.jpg
http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130515a_inv.jpg
waiting to see if the European comet imagers caught it with their wide field cameras.
It wasnt there a two days ago (may 13)
http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/C2012F6_Lemmon_20130513a_inv.jpg
Hoping that some of our usual comet imagers caught this with their wide field setups.
Gotta love comets.!
Cheers,
..paul. 

Date:  Wed, 15 May 2013 18:36:33 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2012 F6 Lemmon - May 15th
Hi all,

Two colour images taken earlier today in the twilight (making processing the data quite challenging as it was quite noisy.) None the less the tail disconnection event is captured nicely.

Close-up:  http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_05_15dp.jpg
20" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL1102M. RGB each 3mins.

Wide field:  http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_05_15wide.jpg
FSQ106 with STL-11000M. RGB each 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 17 May 2013 15:26:04 -0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Panstarrs and Lemmon both in one morning...
Hi All,

Yesterday morning was clear and transparent and I rose early to image perhaps for one last time (yeah, right...) Two binocular visible comets in the morning twilight. Currently, Comet Panstarrs is around magnitude 7.3 and is very near the pole star making it circumpolar for the whole night. Best viewing is however later in the morning just before the start of dawn. It can be seen in the 11x80 binoculars as a low brightness fan shaped object moving slowly from night to night across the starry backdrop of Cepheus.
Comet Lemmon is much harder to image. It is around magnitude 5.3 and only 10 degrees up in the Eastern sky just before the sun comes up. This too is easy in the binoculars, and shows a round ball for a head which images as bright blue/green in color.
you can see both images from yesterdays session here. Thanks for looking!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Panstarrs051613.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Tue, 21 May 2013 09:06:59 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-05-20  C/2011 L4, C/2011 R1, 63P
3 comets observed yesterday evening, with the moon inducing strong stray
light in the tube for 63P and C2011R1.
But C2011L4 is near Polaris these days, almost 90 from the moon, so the
images were very nice.

C/2011 L4
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2011L4_PANSTARRS.html


C/2011 R1
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2011R1_McNaught.html


63P/Wild
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/63P_Wild.html

Luc

Date:  Thu, 23 May 2013 06:46:39 -0000
From:  hiro 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 PANSTARRS near Sh2-174 May 21, 2013UTC
Hi all,

I could image the comet during the short dark window after the moonset before the beginning of the twilight at the night. The tail looked sharper and longer than before, though the background was not dark enough due to IFN, integrated flux nebula in the field.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/8797651188/

Thank you for looking.

hiro

Date:  Thu, 23 May 2013 10:52:07 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  L4 Panstarrs on May 23rd from New Mexico
Another image of part of the ludicrously long orbital plane spike,
taken in near full moonlight a few hours ago:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2011l4_20130523_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

Comet page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html 

Date:  Thu, 23 May 2013 12:20:54 -0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Panstarrs: 30 minutes of darkness May 22
Hello all,

This was the last chance to get the comet and its magnificent anti tail in a dark sky. We set up at 2am, and finally the moon set at 3:10am. A set of 1 min subs with our 80mm f/4.6 Stellarvue SV80s with Ziess optics worked well with the DSLR to frame the comet. This set of images, along with Damian Peaches photos appear in the latest pages of Universe Today.

Web link my site:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrs052213.html

Universe Today Article with our photos:

http://www.universetoday.com/102299/what-do-comet-panstarrs-and-pinocchio-have-in-common/#more-102299

Thanks for looking!

Chris 

Date:  Thu, 23 May 2013 19:11:41 -0000
From:  Martin Gembec 
Subject:  PanSTARRS March to May mosaic
Hi all.

Rolando's images inspired me to make mosaic of my images through telescope, which I made between March 16th and May 16th, nearly two months apart.

Here is the result.

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/c2011l4_20130316-0516.jpg

Martin Gembec

Date:  Sun, 26 May 2013 18:51:39 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs - May 26th
Hi all,

Here is a colour image of this much imaged comet taken this morning. Conditions were far from ideal.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_05_26dp.jpg

FSQ106 with STL-11000M. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins. High cloud and full moon present.

Damian

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 184P/ Lovas 2
Hi all,

Here is an image of 184P taken this evening. This appears to be much fainter than the predicted magnitude of ~17.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/184p_lovas_2013_05_26dp.jpg

20" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 4x3mins unfiltered.

From:  Chris Schur

Chris Schur

Date:  Wed, 29 May 2013 00:04:20 -0000
From:  hiro 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS) on May 24, 2013UTC
Dear members,

I tried imaging of the comet with circular polar filter under 14.7 days old moon.
The anti-tail looked to be longer than 11 degrees at the moment.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/8838395391/

You can download the original frame.
Click ... near right lower corner and select View all sizes.

Best Regards,

hiro

From:  w_vollmann 
Subject:  C/2011 L4 (PANSTARRS), widefield f=50mm, 2013 May 28, 21:28 UT
Hello all,

the antitail can be traced for 14 degrees towards PA 40 deg on this image taken with 1:2.8 f=50mm camera lens, 30 x 30sec exposure with Canon 600D:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/wolfgang_vollmann/8876489898/

Wolfgang Vollmann

From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Superb Anti Tail on Panstarrs for the 27th - Orbital Plane crossing Day
Hi all,

careful compostion was the rule on this one, the comets anti tail spanned the entire 15 degree field (diagonally) in the negative image. Hope you can get out to see this one now in a dark evening sky!

http://schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrs052713.html

Chris Schur

Date:  Fri, 31 May 2013 18:59:10 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs and integrated flux nebula
Hello everybody,

I just returned from vacation and admired all the great images taken so far
from the long and sharp antitail of this comet. Luckily I had my iphone with
me. Thus I used this opportunity for remote imaging with the 8"Astrograph in
Spain.

This is one of the three images taken. The turbulent background is the
integrated flux nebulosity which is renowned present in this area:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/158_Panstarrs_27_05.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Fri, 31 May 2013 18:57:00 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs - May 30th
Hi all,

Here is a colour LRGB image from yesterday. Still looking impressive and the fan appearance is starting to returning now that we've passed through the orbital plane.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_05_30dp.jpg

FSQ106 with STL11000M. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Tue, 04 Jun 2013 10:11:24 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  PANSTARRS c2011 L4 June 4
Medium scale image of the comet during an astrometry run.

c/2011 L4, June 4, 05:30 UT, Mag. = 9.4 (ccd), Coma diameter = 127"
South is up, field = 40 x 55'
ASO 11cm f/4.9 APO astrograph with ST2000 XM camera, 2 x 90 sec ea, unbinned; no post
processing.
High thin clouds.
Click on appropriate comet for details and photo.
http://www.arksky.org/php/ctable.php
or

http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2145.0.html

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs - June 6th
Hi all,

Here is colour shot of C/2011 L4 from June 6th.

FSQ106 with STL-11000M. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Date:  Sun, 09 Jun 2013 23:44:45 -0000
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs Last night - the fan tail Returns!
Hi all,

Finally, a dark of the moon weekend to shoot a really deep shot of the comet at our Happy Jack observatory site, located in northern Arizona next to the brand new monster Discovery Channel Telescope. Skies last night were world class dark and transparent, and the comet was still only barely visible in the 8 inch visually! This shot here is a combined 1 hour exposure at ASA800 with a Orion 8 f/4 astrograph with coma corrector and a Canon xti DSLR camera. Images were aligned on the comets head to keep the comet sharp while it moved during the hour long exposure. The comet is now starting to resemble the big fan shape it started out with earlier. The Anti Tail is greatly diminished but still totally huge.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrs060813.html

Cant wait to see what its going to do in the next few weeks!

Chris Schur 

Date:  Mon, 10 Jun 2013 01:28:47 -0000
From:  Roman 
Subject:  Re: Comet Panstarrs Last night - the fan tail Returns!
Hi Chris,
Very nice Images,
Thank you for your time and sharing!
I got the same machine, telescope but no mount rings, and telescope is Astro-Tech, need also dovetail plate,
Pa
Roman
http://www.astro-sky.com
and last images here
http://astro-sky.blogspot.ca
thanks

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lemmon - June 10th.
Hi all,

Here is a colour shot of C/2012 F6 taken this morning. Much better placed in the northern hemisphere now but the ion tail is weakening.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_06_10dp.jpg

17" CDK @ F4.5. FLI-PL6303E camera. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Hi all,

A wide field colour shot of C/2012 F6 Lemmon from this morning. It certainly looks a bit more lack luster in the smaller scope. I included a negative image inset which more clearly shows the faint gas tail.

FSQ106 with ST8300C colour camera. Single 10min exposure.

Date:  Fri, 14 Jun 2013 02:01:11 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-06-13:  29P outburst,   C/2011 L4
Dear all,

Here is an image following Jean-Francois's annoucement of 29P bright
outburst.
I have measured m2 at R=12.7 (through a r' Sloan filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/29P_SchwassmannWachmann.html

And C/2011 L4
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2011L4_PANSTARRS.html

Best

Luc 

Date:  Thu, 13 Jun 2013 22:15:37 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013-06-13:  29P outburst,   C/2011 L4
I think that we must be very careful on magnitude estimates of Schwassmann-Wachmann 29P made from about 23:00 UT June 13 through 04:00 UT June 14 because 29P has been superimposed over the star:
4UC345-068858, Magnitude 15.2 throughout the last few hours, now just barely west of this star. Saturated images will include this star's scattered brightness, even with aperture photometry.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: Luc ARNOLD
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, June 13, 2013 7:01 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013-06-13: 29P outburst, C/2011 L4

Dear all,

Here is an image following Jean-Francois's annoucement of 29P bright outburst.
I have measured m2 at R=12.7 (through a r' Sloan filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/29P_SchwassmannWachmann.html

And C/2011 L4
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2011L4_PANSTARRS.html

Best

Luc 


Date:  Fri, 14 Jun 2013 10:02:42 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013-06-13:  29P outburst,   C/2011 L4
Clay
Yes indeed, r=15.0 (from APASS) for this star and potential mag bias is
about r=-0.16 mag for a comet at r=13.
My observations fortunately were done well before this star potential
contamination on the 29P path.
My aperture radius is 6.6" and the star was still at about 30" on June
13 21:00UT.
Best
L

Date:  Sun, 16 Jun 2013 14:51:14 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-06-15  29P outburst follow-up, C2011L4 C2013F3 C2013L2
Dear all,

4 comets observed yesterday night, good seeing but poor transparency.

29P outburst, coma shell snail shaped, well suggesting a jet from a
rotating nucleus
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/29P_SchwassmannWachmann.html

C/2011 L4 Panstarrs
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2011L4_PANSTARRS.html

C/2013 F3 Mc Naught
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013F3_McNaught.html

C/2013 L2 Catalina
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013L2_Catalina.html

Best
Luc
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/Welcome.html

Date:  Mon, 17 Jun 2013 07:00:44 -0700
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  29P S-W1 "outburst" and observation of comet various.
Good morning.

29P Schwassmann-Wachmann 1 "outburst", 06/13, 14, 15 and 16 in the morning.
The m2 has culminated 12.7 06/13.90 and from 06/15.95, we go back to 13.4.
There is a coma with a changing structure (since 06/14) in the form of drops of water (or said snail) ...
"Jets ?" PA : +/-345° and +/-35°.
Coma : +/- 44"x35" on 06/14.
Images made ​​without filter, Red J/C and Band "I".
The Af(rho) shows a maximum of 06/14.

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image29Pschwassmannwachmannfrance.htm

Automatic session :

C 2013 J5 Boattini
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013J5Boattinifrance.htm

C  2013 J6 Catalina
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013J6Catalinafrance.htm

 C 2013 L2 Catalina
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013L2Catalinafrance.htm

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France
Date:  Mon, 17 Jun 2013 18:38:45 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-06-16  29P outburst   C2013F3  C2013L2
Dear all,

3 comets observed last evening

29P outburst, at r'=13.5/13.6 (SLOAN r' filter), unchanged shape
compared to the 15/6, but FWHM
increased from 5.5" the 13th, to 9" the 15th and 11" the 16th.
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/29P_SchwassmannWachmann.html

C2013F3
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013F3_McNaught.html

C2013L2
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013L2_Catalina.html

Best
Luc 
Date:  Tue, 18 Jun 2013 04:04:39 -0000
From:  josephbrimacombe 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs Mosaic Showing Anti-tail almost bisecting Polaris - June 4
Hi All

Got behind on my processing. This five frame mosaic shows the anti-tail almost bisecting polaris through a haze of integrated flux nebula.

LINK
http://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/9071519489/

Clear, still skies

Joe

Joseph Brimacombe
Coral Towers Observatory
Cairns, Australia 

Date:  Tue, 18 Jun 2013 18:13:32 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 29P/S-W (June 18th.)
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained earlier today of 29P following its recent outburst. A dense looking coma with hints of a darker streak inside about half way out to the edge.

The comet was only 8 degrees away from the moon at the time of the image and i initially thought the data unusable, but the central portion of the field was just about ok.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/29p_2013_06_18dp.jpg

20"CDK @ F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. Single 600sec exposure unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Wed, 19 Jun 2013 20:13:59 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs - June 19th.
Hi all,

Here is C/2011 L4 captured earlier today. An 80% moon really washed out the comet more than i anticipated. The bright star Kochab in Ursa Minor is the bright star in the field.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_06_19dp.jpg

FSQ106 with STL-11000M. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins. 80% illum moon present.

Best Wishes

Date:  Tue, 25 Jun 2013 02:23:31 -0000
From:  twade35 
Subject:  Comet Pan-STARRS and IFN on June 10th
To all,

I've been watching closely the amazing images you all have captured of
this amazing comet over the past several months. I finally got a pretty
good night and captured the comet and a portion of the integrated flux
nebula. I probably could have stretched the image a bit more but
decided this was a nice balance. I used a FLI PL-16803 and a Pentax 67
300mm f/4.0 len wide-open. This is an integration of six 2-minute 2x2
binned exposures tracked on the comet. I only have luminance data since
I don't know how to get pinpoint stars while tracking on the comet (i.e.
acquiring the color data would have resulted in trailed stars).

Low resolution
rrs_ccd_300mm_1012x1012.jpg>

High resolution
rrs_ccd_300mm_2024x2024.jpg>

Thanks for looking,

Wade 

Date:  Tue, 25 Jun 2013 02:30:06 -0000
From:  twade35 
Subject:  Comet Lemmon and M31 on June 10th
To all,

I've been watching the amazing images you all have captured of Comet
Lemmon over the past few months. Although its tail has decreased
significantly, it still looks pretty nice as it passed by M31 in early
June. I used a FLI PL-16803 and a Pentax 67 300mm f/4.0 lens
wide-open. This is an integration of six 2-minute 2x2 binned exposures
tracked on the comet. I only have luminance data since I don't know how
to get pinpoint stars while tracking on the comet (i.e. acquiring the
color data would have resulted in trailed stars).

Low resolution
_ccd_300mm_1012x1012.jpg>

High resolution
_ccd_300mm_2024x2024.jpg>

Thanks for looking,

Wade 

Date:  Tue, 25 Jun 2013 11:12:55 +0800
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lemmon and M31 on June 10th
Wade,

Majestic image!

John

________________________________
From: twade35
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, June 25, 2013 10:30 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Lemmon and M31 on June 10th

To all,

I've been watching the amazing images you all have captured of Comet Lemmon over the past few months.  Although its tail has decreased significantly, it still looks pretty nice as it passed by M31 in early June.   I used a FLI PL-16803 and a Pentax 67 300mm f/4.0 lens wide-open.  This is an integration of six 2-minute 2x2 binned exposures tracked on the comet.  I only have luminance data since I don't know how to get pinpoint stars while tracking on the comet (i.e. acquiring the color data would have resulted in trailed stars).

Low resolution

High resolution

Thanks for looking,

Wade

Date:  Wed, 26 Jun 2013 19:52:57 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs - June 26th
Hi all,

Here is a shot of C/2011 L4 from this morning. The fan of dust is now much wider while a weak "anti-tail" spike is still present that much shortened and faded.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2011_l4_panstarrs_2013_06_26dp.jpg

FSQ106 refractor with STL-11000M. LRGB. L: 15mins. RGB: 3mins. Shot at moonrise.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Thu, 27 Jun 2013 05:57:14 -0700
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Observation of comet
Good morning.

Automatic session.

C 2012 K1 PANSTARRS, R filter
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012K1Panstarrsfrance.htm

C 2013 F3 Mc Naught, R filter
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013F3McNaughtfrance.html

C 2012 F6 Lemmon, R filter
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012F6Lemmonfrance.htm

29P S-W1, unfiltered and R.
His coma increased from +/-17"x 17" 06/18 +/-1.19'x 1' 06/25.
The mag is now over 16 and Afrho shows a peak around the 06/15
now descends very quickly.
I did a little editing on the morphology of 29P, from June 06/16 to 26.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image29Pschwassmannwachmannfrance.htm

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France

From:  Chris Schur

Very nice Damian! we looked at it from northern Arizona last night, and now being far enough from the pole to be not behind our roll off roof on the observatory. Chris Schur

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs movie
Hi all,

Here is a movie showing the tail development of Panstarrs over the last 6 weeks or so. All taken with the same telescope and camera. Putting something watchable together was quite challenging to say the least but it came out quite well.

Image taken between May 6th and June 27th. FSQ106 with STL-11000M camera.

It is good to see this comet developing a bit and thanks Gerald; by any chance can you estimate the magnitude of it?

Date:  Mon, 01 Jul 2013 22:58:26 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 29P/S-W (July 1st.)
Hi all,

Here is an image of 29P obtained earlier today now under a dark sky now that the moon is well away. The coma is looking quite a bit larger and more diffuse than when i last imaged the comet back on June 21st. Rather reminds me of a much smaller and fainter 17P Holmes during its prime....

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/29p_2013_07_01dp.jpg

20" CDK@F4.5. FLI-PL6303E. 4x3mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lemmon with NGC 7789
Hi all,

Comet Lemmon alongside open cluster NGC 7789 from last night. This was actually meant to be a colour image but a cock-up on my part put pay to that. None the less still a pretty pairing among the stars of Cassiopeia.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_07_03dp.jpg

Tak TOA150 with STL-11000M. 7x3mins unfiltered.

Erik Bryssinck

Subject:  Comet 29P/S-W (July 28th.)
Hi all,

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303E. 4x3mins unfiltered.

Date:  Tue, 30 Jul 2013 18:41:09 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 29P/S-W outburst - June to July 2013
Hi all,

Here is a presentation of images obtained of comet 29P during June-July detailing itsrecent outburst event. All images were taken with the same scope/camera. The expanding tenuous coma and fading toward the recent recent images is clearly apparent.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/29p_outburst2013dp.jpg

All with 20"CDk@F4.5 with FLI-PL6303E camera. All 4x3mins unfiltered. Dates on the image.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 29P/S-W outburst - June to July 2013 [1 Attachment]

[Attachment(s) from Damian Peach included below]
Hi all,

Here is a presentation of images obtained of comet 29P during June-July detailing its recent outburst event. All images were taken with the same scope/camera. The expanding tenuous coma and fading toward the recent recent images is clearly apparent.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/29p_outburst2013dp.jpg

All with 20"CDk@F4.5 with FLI-PL6303E camera. All 4x3mins unfiltered. Dates on the image.

Best Wishes

Damian

, almost give me the impression of depth of field!

interesting for professionals but not for us astrophotograf :-(

Date:  Tue, 06 Aug 2013 19:35:50 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lemmon (Aug 5th.)
Hi all,

Here is a colour image of C/2012 F6 from August 5th. The blue glow at the top of the field is from Beta Cephei just out of frame.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_08_05dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI-PL6303E. LRGB. L: 12mins. RGB: 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Tue, 06 Aug 2013 22:50:27 +0200
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet C/2012 F6 Lemmon today
> I followed a little, the workshop on comet ISON, I fear that it will be a
> comet interesting for professionals but not for us astrophotograf :-(

Several speakers explicitly *asked* for amateur astrophotographers to
contribute images of the dust, plasma and perhaps sodium tails; watch
http://www.livestream.com/cometison/video?clipId=pla_cb767a91-10dc-44c9-a3d4-261e6eabf432
from 36:25 and 48:18 and 42:04 - thus many in field still expect the comet
to perform good enough for at least these kinds of observations.

Dan

P.S.: In 2 days observations of ISON will resume when Deep Impact points
an IR spectrograph at the comet - the data should be downlinked on Aug.
10. The show is about to resume ...

Date:  Wed, 14 Aug 2013 20:05:25 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comets - Aug 13th and 14th
Hi all,

Here are images of C/2012 F6 and 29P taken over the last day or so.

Lemmon is developing a weak anti tail and 29P continues to fade with no signs of a new outburst at present.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_08_13dp.jpg

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/29p_2013_08_14dp.jpg

Damian

Date:  Wed, 14 Aug 2013 21:23:32 +0200
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comets - Aug 13th and 14th
> Lemmon is developing a weak anti tail

Are you sure? On recent color images posted here and elsewhere this
'extension' of the coma seemed to have a more blue-greenish tinge than the
dust tail: could that be what remains of Lemmon's once impressive plasma
tail?

Dan 

Date:  Thu, 15 Aug 2013 20:22:45 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lemmon - Aug 15th
Hi all,

Here is a colour image of C/2012 F6 Lemmon obtained last night.Still a fine sight among the stars of Draco and the as with yesterday there looks to be a faint projection pointing ahead of the comet.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_f6_2013_08_15dp.jpg

0.15m f7 with STL-11k camera. LRGB. L: 4x5mins. RGB: 1x3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Ison August 18
John

I start exposure at twilight for 25 minutes. To the end the sky was bright. I would estimate it at 13m5
When the sky was darker 2013 N4 was not much more impressive at the same height tonight (images with UV/IR filter).

Michael

Hi all,

Here is C/2012 F6 taken last night. We cross the comet orbital plane in a couple of days time. A nice tail remains present though not really any different since my last image on August 15th.

Date:  Mon, 26 Aug 2013 23:47:40 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  1949N1 Bappu-Bok-Newkirk
Hello all,
Today I reached a milestone in my stewardship of the British Astronomical Association Comet Gallery.
I placed the number 1000 image on it. Anyone interested in comet images can access this site at the
following link:
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=category&catid=5&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

To mark this event I was lucky to be able to select a comet image, that although being 64 years old
has never been published before. It is the photographic discovery image of C/1949 N1
Bappu-Bok-Newkirk.
Amar Sharma of Nikaya Observatory, Bangalore has been investigating the discovery
circumstances of this comet and the location of the original plate to enter it into his upcoming
Biographies of Worldwide Comet Discoverers. I was pleased to be able to use this unusual image to
remind today's "digital comet observers" how discovery was undertaken "in the olden days" of
photographic glass plates and hour long observer guided exposures. I hope you enjoy seeing this
unusual and unique image.It is available at the following link:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1454&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200 

Date:  Tue, 27 Aug 2013 18:23:34 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-08-27 257P & C3013P3
Dear all

2 comets observed this morning with the 60cm f/3.2 ROTAT telescope at OHP

257P Catalina, tail 68" in PA 260
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/257P_Catalina.html

C/2013 P3 Palomar, tail 18" in PA 340
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013P3_Palomar.html

Best

Luc @ 511 
Date:  Tue, 27 Aug 2013 18:52:54 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  comet C/2012 F6 Lemmon today

Rolando Ligustri 

Date:  Wed, 28 Aug 2013 17:48:13 +0800
From:  amar sharma 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 1949N1 Bappu-Bok-Newkirk
Dear comet-eers,

This is such an honor to have the 1000th image of the BAA comet gallery represented by an image connected to this land, an image which celebrates a historical aspect in the topic of old comet discoveries (an Indo-US connection in this context). This comet was accidentally discovered, back in 1949, at Harvard by one student Vainu Bappu who later became the father of modern Indian professional astronomy. Prof Bappu had even served as the President of the IAU before his unexpected early demise at age 55. Thank you Denis for choosing it, and congrats for your milestone!

Please re-visit this small story on the comet, for those who havent:

http://cs.astronomy.com/asy/b/astronomy/archive/2011/09/22/guest-blog-a-historical-comet-discovery.aspx

Regards,
Amar A. Sharma.
Nikaya Observatory
Bangalore, India
www.picasaweb.google.com/nikayaobservatory

________________________________
From: denis buczynski
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com; COML ; BAA Comets discussion list
Sent: Tuesday, 27 August 2013 4:17 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 1949N1 Bappu-Bok-Newkirk

Hello all,
Today I reached a milestone in my stewardship of the British Astronomical Association Comet Gallery.
I placed the number 1000 image on it. Anyone interested in comet images can access this site at the
following link:
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=category&catid=5&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

To mark this event I was lucky to be able to select a comet image, that although being 64 years old
has never been published before. It is the photographic discovery image of C/1949 N1
Bappu-Bok-Newkirk.
Amar Sharma of Nikaya Observatory, Bangalore has been investigating the discovery
circumstances of this comet and the location of the original plate to enter it into his upcoming
Biographies of Worldwide Comet Discoverers. I was pleased to be able to use this unusual image to
remind today's "digital comet observers" how discovery was undertaken "in the olden days" of
photographic glass plates and hour long observer guided exposures. I hope you enjoy seeing this
unusual and unique image.It is available at the following link:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1454&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200 


Date:  Wed, 28 Aug 2013 16:53:03 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  C/2012  F6 Lemmon
Hello all,
I imaged this comet last night and saw that there continues to be an amount of material forward of
the coma in the form of a forward spike. Is this due to the perspective effect of us passing through
the comet's orbital plane,in the same way that we saw the huge forward tail extension on C/2011 L4
PanSTARRS earlier this year? Are these forward tail spikes the same features as the so called
anti-tails as seen on the famous 1957 comet, C/1957 R1 Arend-Roland? Are we seeing more examples of
this type of feature on comet tails because our digital detectors are much more sensitive than
photographic films and plates were in the past? There was a good deal of interest and surprise in
the phenomena of anti-tails when one was seen in images of C/19657 R1 Arend-Roland, yet we seem less
excited when we see this phenomena on a comet image these days.Is this because we understand all
aspects of comet tail development and viewing perspective?

My image from last night is posted at these links:
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1473&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1474&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

Dear all,

Clear but wet night yesterday evening:

102P Shoemaker 1 , SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/102P_Shoemaker_1.html

154P Brewington, SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/154P_Brewington.html

257P Catalina, comet tail up to 4' long in position angle PA=262, SDSS
r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/257P_Catalina.html

C/2012 F6 Lemmon, tail and antitail, SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2012F6_Lemmon.html

P/2013 J2 McNaught, SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/P2013J2_McNaught.html

C/2013 P3 Palomar, comet tail up to 40'' long in position angle 345,
CLR filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013P3_Palomar.html

Date:  Sat, 31 Aug 2013 14:18:21 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013-08-30 102P 154P 257P C2013P3 P2013J2 C2012F6


considering the solar distance of C/2013 P3 (Palomar) is currently 9 AU, a tail up to 40’’ long at that distance is unusual to me.

________________________________
From: Luc ARNOLD
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, August 31, 2013 5:20 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013-08-30 102P 154P 257P C2013P3 P2013J2 C2012F6

Dear all,

Clear but wet night yesterday evening:

102P Shoemaker 1  , SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/102P_Shoemaker_1.html

154P Brewington, SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/154P_Brewington.html

257P Catalina, comet tail up to 4’ long in position angle PA=262°,
SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/257P_Catalina.html

C/2012 F6 Lemmon,  tail and antitail, SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/C2012F6_Lemmon.html

P/2013 J2 McNaught, SDSS r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/P2013J2_McNaught.html

C/2013 P3 Palomar,  comet tail up to 40’’ long in position angle
345°, CLR filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013P3_Palomar.html

Best
Luc
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/Welcome.html 


Date:  Sat, 31 Aug 2013 16:26:22 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013-08-30 102P 154P 257P C2013P3 P2013J2 C2012F6
I agree with Charles; in fact, if the circle is 9.7 arc minutes, then the tail of the comet appears to be somewhat less than 30 arc seconds.
Nonetheless, this is a very good image and demonstrates that this comet (C/2013 P3) should be watched for rapid development.

Clay
_____

Arkansas Sky Observatories

Date:  Sun, 01 Sep 2013 22:21:11 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 V2 (LINEAR) - Sep 1st
Hi all,

Here is C/2012 V2 (LINEAR) from Sep 1st. This time a much better result in colour. A weak ion tail seems to be present. Currently the brightest comet in the sky at around mag 8 to 9.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_v2_2013_09_01dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303e camera. LRGB. L: 8x2mins. RGB: 1x1mins. Shot during twilight with the Sun at -18 to -14 deg.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/

Date:  Mon, 02 Sep 2013 00:00:54 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-09-01 P2013J2
An second visit to P/2013 J2 McNaught, while cirrus arrived from the
North West
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/P2013J2_McNaught.html
Luc 
Date:  Mon, 02 Sep 2013 00:34:20 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013-08-30 102P 154P 257P C2013P3 P2013J2 C2012F6
Clay and Charles
Thank you for your feedback on my image of C2013P3. I measured around
40" with Astrometrica (Shift + left mouse button). 30" is
conservative and it seems to me that the tail is longer. The tail is
quite long for an object at 9 AU indeed.
Unfortunately I could not image P3 again this evening, cirrus are
arriving and too thick,
but I'll give it a try tomorrow, weather should be better.

(The white circle in my images is always 300px in diameter. With the
0.2m f/5.5 telescope, it corresponds to 8.25 arcmin,
and with the 0.6m f/3.2 telescope, it corresponds to 9.7 arcmin for
bin2x2 images).

Best regards
Luc

Date:  Tue, 03 Sep 2013 20:34:33 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet P/2013 CU129 Pan-STARRS (Sep 2nd.)
Hi all

P/2013 CU129 captured on September 2nd. A lovely little active comet which passed perihelion about a month back. Currently located around 5deg away from Messier 83.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/p2013_cu129_2013_09_02dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303e camera. 7 x 2mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Wed, 04 Sep 2013 05:47:45 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  C/2012s1 20130904
Hello all,
I imaged this comet at dawn from my observatory at Tarbatness in Highland Scotland (MPC Code I81).

Image posted at the following link:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1511&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet looks around mag 12-13 with a small condensed coma and a tail about 8 arc mins. It looked
quite an active comet as the images came onto my computer screen from the ccd camera. It looks to be
developing quite nicely and was an easy object to image even at low altitude in the bright dawn sky.
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

Date:  Thu, 05 Sep 2013 22:16:03 -0700
From:  kodama@alumni.caltech.edu
Subject:  RE: RE: [Comet-Images] RE: Links
[No data] 
Date:  Fri, 06 Sep 2013 07:24:00 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] RE: Links
Hi Dave - I can't see that anything's been fixed, at least from my end. The link in your message is OK but you seem to have (by design or not) used the Rich-Text option and links seem to work in that. Plain text links still aren't active for me on any Yahoo groups. I just highlight the link, right-click, and select the go-to option. If the link extends to two lines, do the same but when the new page opens, amend the URL by removing the inserted backslash. Would be much easier if all links were active, as before.

Cheers -

Rob Kaufman

Date:  Fri, 06 Sep 2013 10:59:36 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-09-04&05 C2013 P3  deep
Dear all

I observed again C/2013 P3 the two last nights, in order to confirm the
relatively long tail detected in a previous image of Aug. 30.
The tail was detected again, about 22" and 37" long, respectively sept.
4th and 5th, at similar PA
around 336-339. 37" are 220 000 km projected on the sky, considering
that the comet is 8.14AU from us.

The images are here
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013P3_Palomar.html

Best
Luc

Mike,

Hmmm... things seem to be working ok now without any special gyrations. As
a test, here's a link to the messages on this group:

http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/conversations/messages

Links in previously posted messages seem OK for me now in my Windows 7
laptop Chrome browser as well as Android tablets and phones.

While *editing* a post like this one via the web interface, I can't
left-click on the link, but in Chrome, I can right-click and open the link
in another tab.

Dave

should turn blue then use CONTROL CLICK to go to the image.

Yahoo has screwed something up when they made the wise decision to add NEO.

Hi all,

Date:  Fri, 06 Sep 2013 22:18:25 -0700
From:  Comet-Images-owner@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  Yahoo alternative?  Anyone interested?
[No data] 
Date:  Sat, 07 Sep 2013 03:08:12 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Yahoo alternative?  Anyone interested?
I am not comfortable with Google and g-mail, even though I am a frequent Google user; I would suggest that we leave it as it is now and see if some corrections are made.
There is a lot of data mining from Google groups.....

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: Comet-Images-owner@yahoogroups.com
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, September 07, 2013 12:18 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Yahoo alternative? Anyone interested?

Yahoo's recent changes to the groups features appear to be causing problems for members, so it has been suggested that perhaps we should consider an alternative service. I'm open to this if the majority of members here don't mind that.

The option I'm most familiar with is a "community" (=group) on Google+. Google+ seems like a good option because there are already similar groups covering general astronomy, photography, and other technical interests. I could set one up pretty quickly to either replace or parallel the operation of this group.

The disadvantages would be:
- disruption to members -- you need to get a gmail account (free) if you don't already have one and it may be a new interface to get used to for you.

- No email interface. You would n eed to use the web interface or mobil device interface to post or read entries and see photos.

Of course, Google is prone to change the interface on us without notice as has happened to us with the Yahoo "neo" change.

Please reply on this thread so we can all see how everyone feels. Alternative suggestions are of course welcome too. If you feel it's best to just wait for Yahoo to fix things, let us know too.

Thanks for your patience,
Dave Kodama 


Date:  Sat, 07 Sep 2013 21:10:54 +0800
From:  James Gifford 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Yahoo alternative?  Anyone interested?
This group sits well with CometObs and CometsMl, please don't split them unless absolutely necessary. The email interface is also important for me.
Regards, Jim Gifford.

Sent from my Windows phone

-----Original Message-----

Date:  Sat, 07 Sep 2013 07:00:13 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2013-09-04&05 C2013 P3  deep
Thank you Luc Arnold for posting this comet image.

I noted that Rolando Ligustri also confirmed tail on comet C/2013 P3 Palomar in his image posted September 1, 2013 on the International Comet group|

He noted a tail of 30" at PA 330 degrees

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=693689517326165&set=gm.538861629500950&type=1&theater

________________________________
From: Luc ARNOLD
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, September 6, 2013 3:59 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2013-09-04&05 C2013 P3 deep

Dear all
I observed again C/2013 P3 the two last nights, in order to confirm the relatively long tail detected in a previous image of Aug. 30.
The tail was detected again,  about 22" and 37" long,
respectively sept. 4th and 5th, at similar PA
around 336-339°.  37" are 220 000 km projected on the sky,
considering that the comet is 8.14AU from us.

The images are here
http://www.obs-hp.fr/%7Elarnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013P3_Palomar.html

Best
Luc

Date:  Sun, 08 Sep 2013 12:52:33 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  C/2012S1 20130908 image
Hello all,
I imaged this comet in good conditions in the dawn sky from Highland Scotland. The comet looks to be
developing very well, and the tail looks to be lengthening and becoming more distinct. An active
comet at this distance, bodes well?
Image at this link

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1521&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

Date:  Sun, 08 Sep 2013 21:47:14 +0200
From:  "M. Gembec" 
Subject:  C/2012 F6 Lemmon 20130906
Hi.

I have imaged comet at night 6./7. September. I was surprised how easy can
I see it through 30cm telescope in Bortle 3/4 sky and also I saw about 10'
of tail.

But even more surprising for me is more then 1 deg long tail on my image.

Celestron ED80/600 + Vixen 0,67x (f402mm), Canon 30Dmod, 20x90s, ISO1600

color 50% version
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2012-F6-Lemmon-20130906-50p.jpg
negative version
http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/wp-content/2012-F6-Lemmon-20130906-neg.jpg

Martin Gembec
Czech Republic

C 2013 R1 Lovejoy
T400RC Remote, SpaceObs., A.Maury, Chile.

Subject:  ASO image C/2013 R1 (LOVEJOY) - 10 sept.13

From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO image C/2013 R1 Lovejoy - 2013 Sep 12th
September 12 2013
Negative image showing outlying faint outer coma extending far from center.

c/2013 R1 Lovejoy, Sept 12 - Taken near twilight (10:13:57 UT); 2x45s exposures, 0.51m astrograph @ f/4.9; CCD binned 2x2, 14.8 micron, south up, field 15x21'
http://www.arksky.org/php/cdata.php?object=c2013xxxR1xxxxxxLovejoy

From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] VATT images from Sept 12

________________________________
From: "chergen@yahoo.com"
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, 13 September 2013, 11:47
Subject: [Comet-Images] VATT images from Sept 12

A few comets observed with the Vatican VATT 1.8-m telescope on Mount Graham. Though the seeing was excellent, clouds were an issue and affected most of the observations.

Photometry was measured for C/2012 S1 (V = 13.4, R = 13.0) and C/2012 K1 (V = 14.8, R = 14.4).
2P/Encke
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5164&g2_serialNumber=2

C/2009 F4 (McNaught)
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5160&g2_serialNumber=2

C/2012 K1 (PANSTARRS)
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5153&g2_serialNumber=2

C/2012 S1 (ISON)
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5151&g2_serialNumber=2\

C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy)
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5156&g2_serialNumber=2

- Carl Hergenrother (Tucson, AZ)

Date:  Fri, 13 Sep 2013 11:27:35 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  OT- e-mail being diverted
This is off topic, but I am hearing from several members of this group that they have sent private messages that are not being received.
My ISP has traced the problem to someone intercepting my mail and they have identified the IP address and are taking action.

Note that this is not a virus issue, only someone actually diverting my e-mail to another account, for whatever reason is unknown.

Nonetheless, please note my correct e-mail address:
drclay@tcworks.net
and it is NOT
sherroddrclay@tcworks.net

Any mail sent to or received by that last address is our hacker and they should be taken care of soon it appears.
The unfortunate thing is that the perpetrator is a member of the astronomical community.

Thank you for watching for any activity on this ficticious account. In addition, I would appreciate receiving mail from anyone who can take the time to do so, simply so that I can see how widespread this issue has become.

Much appreciated....

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Sat, 14 Sep 2013 20:53:31 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2009 F4 McNaught - Sep 14th.
Hi all,

Here is an image taken earlier of C/2009 F4. Currently located in Eridanus. Showing some interesting coma structure and very faint dust tail.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2009_f4_2013_09_14dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303e. 20mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
************************************************* 
Date:  Sat, 14 Sep 2013 23:05:45 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  C/2012 V2 LINEAR LRGB - Sep 14th
Hi all,

Currently the skies brightest and most impressive comet. Showing some nice tail structure in this colour image taken earlier today. Recent mag estimates have the comet at around mag 8.7.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_v2_2013_09_14dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303e. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Sun, 15 Sep 2013 08:08:54 -0700
From:  chergen@yahoo.com
Subject:  More VATT images from Sept 12
[No data] 
Date:  Sun, 15 Sep 2013 16:34:55 +0100
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] More VATT images from Sept 12
Hello Carl,
I was most pleased to see more comet images that you had taken with the VATT 1.8m on this forum. I would like to ask though, for what purpose were they taken? I know that many of this imagers who submit material to this forum take comet images on a regular basis for the purposes of reporting astrometry and photometry and outbursts. Also there are some specific programmes such as the T3 project to ID comets masquerading as asteroids. What is the underlying purpose of the images taken with the VATT 1.8 m? Are they taken as part of a specific programme with a research goal in mimd or are they part of the regular monitoring which myself and others on this forum particiapate in.

Denis Buczynski

________________________________
From: "chergen@yahoo.com"
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, 15 September 2013, 16:08
Subject: [Comet-Images] More VATT images from Sept 12

Here are a few fainter comets that were also observed from the Vatican VATT 1.8-m on Sept 12. The 26P observations were affected by the Moon which was nearby.

4P/Faye
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5183&g2_serialNumber=2

26P/Grigg-Skjellerup
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5176&g2_serialNumber=2

C/2012 K8 (Lemmon)
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_view=core.DownloadItem&g2_itemId=5187&g2_serialNumber=2

- Carl Hergenrother (Tucson, AZ)

Date:  Wed, 18 Sep 2013 13:35:48 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  comet images of night 5/6 sept.
Update of website with images taken in night of 5-6 sept. Now I could find
some time to put the images on my website.

comets that are observed are, 2P, 4P, 102P,119P,257P,290P, C/2010 S1, C/2012
A1, C/2012 K1, C/2012 S1, C/2012 K1, C/2012 S4, C/2013 E2.

Images and data of the observed comets can you find in links below:

comet 2P/Encke -
R-Bessel filter

comet 4P/Faye -
R-Bessel filter

comet 102P/SHOEMAKER
- R-Bessel
filter

comet 119P/PARKER-HARTLEY
- R-Bessel
filter

comet 257P/CATALINA
- R-Bessel
filter

comet 290P/JAGER
- R-Bessel
filter

comet C/2010 S1 (LINEAR)
- R-Bessel
filter

comet
C/2012 A2 (LINEAR) - R-Bessel filter

comet C/2012 K1 (PANSTARRS)
- R-Bessel
filter

comet C/2012 S1 (ISON)
- R-Bessel
filter

comet C/2012 S4 (PANSTARRS)
- R-Bessel
filter

comet C/2013 E2 (IWAMOTO)
- R-Bessel
filter

see also:

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/blog.html

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

Hi all,

Here is C/2012 S1 ISON captured in colour on September 24th.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_s1_2013_09_24rgb.jpg

17"CDK with FLI-PL6303e camera. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins. Moon present. Sun -18 to -14deg.

Date:  Tue, 24 Sep 2013 21:57:50 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  2P 20130922
I slew to 2P and figured to get some quick shots to see how it would show this far out. Took 10x60 sec exp. Processed the images and could not find the comet. I looked for two days and today found a comet very faint. Made a three frame animation. The first image has the information so watch the animation to see it a few times. Never had so many stars in the way. The small star on the left or #3 is not known by me. Watch how it brightens as the comet lands on top of it
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/B2D6073FEF6DDC8/orig.gif

Date:  Thu, 26 Sep 2013 11:59:06 +0100
From:  buczynski8166@btinternet.com
Subject:  20130926 Comets
Hello all, I was able to image C/2012S1 and C/2013R1 in the dawn sky this morning. Sky was hazy and
both comet were low altitude. C/2012s1 seems to show some evidence of gas tail/streamers in my
images north of the head. The comet is beginning to look quite active now. Images are posted on the
BAA Comet Section Gallery at the following links:
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1582&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1583&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1584&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association 

Date:  Thu, 26 Sep 2013 17:45:00 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  P/2013 CU129 (Pan-STARRS) - Sep 26th
Hi all,

Here is P/2013 CU129 Pan-STARRS from earlier today. The change that has occurred since my last image on Sep 2nd is pretty remarkable.

Sep 26th: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/p2013_cu129_2013_09_26dp.jpg

and the previous image

Sep 2nd: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/p2013_cu129_2013_09_02dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303e. Single 120sec exposure. North up. 0.96"/pixel.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************
Date:  Thu, 26 Sep 2013 11:19:19 -0600
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] P/2013 CU129 (Pan-STARRS) - Sep 26th
Hi Damian, and all,

I attempted this comet visually a couple of times earlier this week,
unsuccessfully. Your image is entirely consistent with my not being able to
detect it.

A pity that the comet wasn't accessible from my latitude earlier this month
. . .

Sincerely,

Alan 

Date:  Thu, 26 Sep 2013 19:03:22 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] P/2013 CU129 (Pan-STARRS) - Sep 26th
Interesting Alan. I was kind of disappointed when the images came in....my first thought was actually "where is it!?" It was a lovely little comet at its peak....

Damian

From: Alan Hale
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, 26 September 2013, 17:19
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] P/2013 CU129 (Pan-STARRS) - Sep 26th

Hi Damian, and all,

I attempted this comet visually a couple of times earlier this week, unsuccessfully. Your image is entirely consistent with my not being able to detect it.

A pity that the comet wasn't accessible from my latitude earlier this month . . .

Sincerely,

Alan

close of a 13-mag star.
And bad weather is coming for the next days...

Subject:  Observations of comets 20130929
Good morning.

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs., A. Maury, Chile :

C 2013 G5 Catalina,
Not found (in 55x15s) despite its estimated magnitude m1: 12.6 by MPC
and its apparent speed of 4.75 "/ min !
Is there is any other comments ?
According to the schedule, it has not been seen since last June ...

C 2012 C1 Mc Naught
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012C1McNaughtChile.htm

Date:  Mon, 30 Sep 2013 12:49:12 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet & galaxy meet - Sep 29th.
Hi all,

Yesterday the skies brightest comet C/2012 V2 LINEAR passed by bright spiral galaxy NGC 2997 in Antlia. Here we can see them alongside each other, the comet being 17 light minutes away while NGC 2997 is 38 million light years away.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_v2_2013_09_29dp.jpg

0.11m F5.6 with STL-11k. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins. Moon present. Sun -19 to -15deg.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Josef Müller A21

Subject: [comets-ml] 20130929_30 comet images

Hello all,
I have placed images for the comets listed below on the Comet Gallery of The British
Astronomical Association. They were taken by myself last night (29-30 Sept 2013) at Tarbatness
Observatory in Highland Scotland. Included is an image of C/2012S1 ISON also taken this morning.

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association.

Date:  Mon, 30 Sep 2013 22:59:38 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 2P/Encke - Sep 30th
Hi all,

Here is an image of 2P/Encke from Sep 30th. I was amazed at how bright the comet appeared in the G filter image, whilst being almost invisible in the R filter.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2013_09_30dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI-PL6303e. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
