C2012s1 ISON 20130101
FROM DENIS BUCZYNSKI TO 1 recipient
Show Details

From

DENIS BUCZYNSKI

Hello all, another dawn session on this comet,my image from this morning is on the BAA Comet Gallery
at the following link:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1605&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Also below here is photometry from this morning of this comet produced following the procedures
outlined in the BAA project Alcock at this link:

http://www.britastro.org/projectalcock/CCD%20Astrometry%20and%20Photometry.htm

COD I81
OBS Denis Buczynski
MEA Denis Buczynski
TEL 0.35-m Schmidt-Cassegrain + CCD + f/6 focal reducer
ACK MPCReport file updated 2013.10.01 15:11:27
AC2 buczynski8166@btinternet.com
NET CMC-14
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15035 09 34 54.07 +17 35 34.5 15.1 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15120 09 34 54.17 +17 35 33.7 15.2 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15193 09 34 54.20 +17 35 33.4 14.1 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15266 09 34 54.38 +17 35 32.2 15.1 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15339 09 34 54.47 +17 35 31.3 15.1 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15412 09 34 54.54 +17 35 31.7 15.1 N I81
NET UCAC-4
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15035 09 34 54.06 +17 35 34.5 15.1 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15120 09 34 54.16 +17 35 33.6 15.1 N I81
CK12S010 C2013 10 01.15193 09 34 54.19 +17 35 33.4 14.1 N I81

COD I81
OBS Denis Buczynski
CATALOG: USNO A2.0 / CMC-14 - BAND: R

Subject:  Comets 20130930
Hello all,

Association. They were taken by myself last night (29-30 Sept 2013) at Tarbatness Observatory in
Highland Scotland. Included is an image of C/2012S1 ISON also taken this morning.

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association.

Date:  Thu, 03 Oct 2013 19:26:47 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comets Lovejoy (C/2013 R1) and Brewington (154P) imaged over the last two nights
Hi,

I imaged 154P (Brewington) on 2013 October 01.36 UT with the 41cm (16”) Meade Newtonian @ f5.2 and a 550D DSLR. 25 x 3 minute exposures @ 800 iso were stacked.
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/Comet_Brewington-154p-41cm@f5,2-550d_DSLR-25x3min@800iso-131001-drummond-web.jpg

And here’s an image of C/2013 R1 (Comet Lovejoy) imaged last night (2013 October 02.62) taken with a 41cm (16”) Meade Starfinder Newtonian and 550D DSLR. 20 x 3 minute @ 800iso. The field has been cropped to about 20’ x 12’ to remove some ugly artefacts.
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/Comet_Lovejoy-c2013R1-41cm_Newtonian-550D_DSLR-20x3min@800iso_%2B23C_20131003-web-text.jpg

Regards
==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287

Date:  Fri, 04 Oct 2013 23:41:52 +0200
From:  Hartwig Luethen 
Subject:  C/2012 S1 Ison  Sept 29 and Oct 3
Hi everyone
I just assembled this shot of ISON using a 12.5" Neumann-Astrograph and
a Canon 1100Da

http://www.flickr.com/photos/astrohardy/10083522393/

2013-09-29, 3:01:-3:52 UT, 44 x60s, 12.5" f/4.28 Astrograph, Handeloh,
GvA Hamburg.

On Oct 3 I could take images of the comet with 500mm focal length
showing the comet in the same field as in Michaels and Stefans shots,
but the focal length was a bit too short
http://www.flickr.com/photos/astrohardy/10089894125/
3:01-3:50 UT, 21*120s, Pentax75 SDHF
Slowly appearing as a little great comet out there.

Hartwig

Date:  Sun, 06 Oct 2013 16:44:53 +0200
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  And the real color of Encke is ...?
Dear comet color photographers,

could you please agree on the color of the coma of Encke (and Lovejoy and
ISON, too): is it deeply green as in
http://www.astrostudio.at/3_Faint%20Comets.php?img=images/3_Faint%20Comets/047_Encke_02_10.jpg
from 4 days ago or basically white as
http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=10252 shows it
today? There has always been some variance in how comet color images were
displayed (in print in the past and nowadays on the web) - but *this*
discrepancy is going way too far ...

Thanks,

Daniel 

Date:  Sun, 06 Oct 2013 17:17:37 +0200
From:  Jakub Cerny 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] And the real color of Encke is ...?
Hello Dan,

I am not photographer, but visual observer. Definitively I have to say,
that when I observed comet 3 days ago, with SWAN band filter, coma get
extremely enhanced so most of light going from this spectral band which
is between 494 and 523 nm. The deep green image seems to be correct for me.

Best regards,
Jakub Cerny

On 10/06/2013 04:44 PM, dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de wrote:
>
> Dear comet color photographers,
>
> could you please agree on the color of the coma of Encke (and Lovejoy and
> ISON, too): is it deeply green as in
> http://www.astrostudio.at/3_Faint%20Comets.php?img=images/3_Faint%20Comets/047_Encke_02_10.jpg
> from 4 days ago or basically white as
> http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=10252 shows it
> today? There has always been some variance in how comet color images were
> displayed (in print in the past and nowadays on the web) - but *this*
> discrepancy is going way too far ...
>
> Thanks,

Date:  Sun, 06 Oct 2013 17:26:37 +0200

Date:  Sun, 06 Oct 2013 18:48:34 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] And the real color of Encke is ...?
> Dear comet color photographers,
> Thanks,
> Daniel

I don't understand where he wants to go with this question, however I don't think
anyone has used PS for coloring pictures we do!

try to think about what means and systems today are produced images

1) ccd monochrome
2) ccd color
3) digicam

in the first case the colors change depending on the filters that are used (change
from photometric to no, and from companies who make them)

in the second case the colors change depending on the sensor that is used in ccd

the third case is broader still, why change the sensors and there are also modified
digicam

Finally there is the processing:I generally try to calibrate the colors so that the
brightest spot of the nucleus is white, but honestly, being simple photo, nothing
scientific, not always I lose time doing it and sometimes I leave to the sw I use
:-)

When I want to secure things , do not place pictures, but numbers, obtained from
linear ccd and photometric filters, with appropriate procedures, data can be quite
sure.
the photos are just a photo :-D

best regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete 

Date:  Sun, 06 Oct 2013 22:26:52 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  one more image of comet Lovejoy
Hello everybody,

Here is one more image of this comet. Sorry - coma is again greenish like on
the day before. BTW - all my images are G2 star calibrated and another
note - the images have been taken in Namibia and

skies are pretty dark down there:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/170_Lovejoy_06_10.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Sun, 06 Oct 2013 21:51:22 +0100
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] one more image of comet Lovejoy


Gerald,
This looks a perfect image of a comet to me. The star field is peppered with all clases of stars that are showing their true colours, beautifully focussed and tracked and the comet is seen in the distinctive green which we have seen so many times before. Keep taking them like this and let us keep seeing them!
Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

Date:  Wed, 09 Oct 2013 16:52:22 +0100
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  20131009 images
Hello all,
I imaged three comets in the dawn sky (after a night of intense Auroral displays) here in Highland Scotland. I have placed these images on the Comet Gallery of The British Astronomical Association at the following links:

C/2012 S1 ISON
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1647&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

2P Encke
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1648&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2013 R1 Lovejoy
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1649&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
BAA

Date:  Thu, 10 Oct 2013 08:49:33 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C23 -NEW images 10 Oct. 2013:

Precies meer geluk gehad met het weer. Ik stond hier om 4:30 in de sterrenwacht met heldere hemel, ik deed juist open en de camera op koel ing, dat er langzaam bewolking kwam binnendrijven. Om 5 uur zo goed als d icht en heb maar besloten om het zaakje te sluiten.E nkele minuten later begon de regen te vallen om een kwartiertje later over te gaan in een heuse stortbui ! damned !  Ik heb ook een reservatie lopen voor een telescoop in New Mexico. Helaas is er ene probleem want die telescoop is buiten dienst gen,omen, andere zijn wel beschikbaar, maar heb er geen reservatie op lopen.

volgende keer beter :)

vr groet
erik

From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Opening image links
Hi,

I may be out on a limb here, but it’s getting really frustrating copying and pasting the URLs of photos into Google Chrome to look at each image in the daily digest version of this (and other) group. What happened to the good-ol days of direct links? Is there a better way to look at the fine photos on this forum?

Date:  Thu, 10 Oct 2013 14:21:58 -0400
From:  Michael Mattei 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Opening image links
John

I am using Windows XP and since Yahoo changed things, I do not get some of
the e-mail with a blue link in them, here's what I figured out so far and I
had mentioned this before you can try it to see if it works for you.

In the email, that does not have a link in blue, hit RETURN, in the new page
click on the link line then hit the END key this puts the cursor at the end
of the link line, the link will turn blue, then hold down the CTRL and click
on the line.

This should send you to the link page.

This works for me and I don't have to cut and paste.

I hope this method works for you also.

Mike

_____

From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Sent: Thursday, October 10, 2013 7:24 AM
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Comet-Images] Opening image links

Hi,

I may be out on a limb here, but it's getting really frustrating copying and
pasting the URLs of photos into Google Chrome to look at each image in the
daily digest version of this (and other) group. What happened to the good-ol
days of direct links? Is there a better way to look at the fine photos on
this forum?

Regards
==============================
John Drummond
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287 

Date:  Thu, 10 Oct 2013 12:16:10 -0700
From:  Bill MacIntosh 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Opening image links
This technique works for Windows 7:

1.  Hit Ctrl+N to open a new window (or you will lose your Yahoo page)
2.  Highlight the link line with the mouse (turns blue)
3.  Right click COPY (or Ctrl+C)  then Left click to clear
4.  Then right click again and  Left click "go to copied address" or Ctrl+Shift+L

Should take you directly to the image.

On Thursday, October 10, 2013 2:21 PM, Michael Mattei wrote:

John

I am using
Windows XP and since Yahoo changed things, I do not get some of the e-mail with
a blue link in them, here’s what I figured out so far and I had mentioned
this before you can try it to see if it works for you.

In the email,
that does not have a link in blue, hit RETURN, in the new page click on the
link line then hit the END key this puts the cursor at the end of the link line,
the link will turn blue, then hold down the CTRL and click on the line.
This should
send you to the link page.
This works
for me and I don’t have to cut and paste.

I hope this
method works for you also.

Mike

Date:  Sat, 12 Oct 2013 18:50:41 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Image gallery of the German Comet section
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi,

I'm the maintainer of the image gallery of the German comet section.

I invite every comet photographer to upload your images to
the archive at http://kometen.fg-vds.de/pix/test/up2_e.php

You can browse the images at http://kometen.fg-vds.de/bildere.htm

Old images are welcomed too.

- --
Best regards,

Stefan Beck

"Image processing for Comets"
http://www.cometchaser.de/imageprocessingcomets.html

"All comet observers of the world"
http://www.cometchaser.de/observers/names.html

"Google map of known comet observers:"
http://www.cometchaser.de/observers/map.html

http://www.cometchaser.de
"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

http://www.cometchaser.de/d_index.html
"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch"

Date:  Thu, 17 Oct 2013 14:48:25 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Noisy ISON via New Mexico - Oct 17th
A further image of ISON, taken a few hours ago, has been uploaded.
A horribly noisy image..... the Full Moon was above the horizon but the
main problem was glare from Mars, spreading from the south of the
frame upwards and almost trashing the entire image............

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2012s1_20131017_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

Comet page:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

Date:  Sun, 20 Oct 2013 06:05:53 -0700
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: C/2012  S1 ISON October 16.79, 2013UTC
Dear members again,

I tried astrometrica for the first time today.

The result was V = 8.1 on the second CR2 file, exposure started at 19:13:11 October 16, 2013UTC.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/10372315376/

I could not be confident on my way of the measurement, and I feel the result at higher side.

hiro

Tail length was about 20' at the night.

Best wishes,
hiro

From:  John 
Subject:  ISON by Moonlight
Hi,

Hi,

The sky was very bright early this morning with the moon just two nights past full. FOV is 18.8' x 28' through a 16" f4.5 Newtonian, Nikon D7000, and 16 x 1 minute exposure.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/ISONC2012S1Oct2120132002UT2dayspastfullmoonN16f45D700016x1min-Nassr_20131022083448.jpg

Date:  Tue, 22 Oct 2013 15:00:41 +0100
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Fw: C/2012 X1 in outburst 20131021
Hello all, I posted these messages yesterday to this group but they did not appear. Apologies to anyone who receives them twice.
Denis Buczynski

----- Forwarded Message -----
>From: DENIS BUCZYNSKI
>To: "Comet-Images-owner@yahoogroups.com" ; "comets-ml@yahoogroups.com" ; "comet@britastro.org" ; "comets-disc@britastro.org"
>Sent: Monday, 21 October 2013, 19:39
>Subject: C/2012 X1 in outburst 20131021
>
>Hello all,
>Please find a link below to my image of this comet reported in outburst. Image taken less than 15 minutes ago  at 18:21 UT from Tarbatness Observatory MPC Code I81 in Highland Scotland.
>
>Denis Buczynski
>Secretary Comet Section
>
>British Astronomical Association
>
>http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1703&option=com_joomgallery
>
>Hello all,
>I attach my astrometry/photometry report from measures taken from images I took this evening at Tarbatness Observatory MPC Code I81. The reduction prcedure followed is the one outlined on the BAA Comet Section website
at this link:
>
>http://www.britastro.org/projectalcock/CCD%20Astrometry%20and%20Photometry.htm
>
>The Visual Equivalent magnitude is measured as 8.4
>
>My image from tonight is at the following link:
>
>http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1703&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200
>
> * Comet-Images-owner@yahoogroups.com
> * comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
> * comets-disc@britastro.org
>Hello all,
>
>Richard Miles  (BAA) has undertaken further image processing of images taken
this evening by Denis Buczynski at Tarbatness and comments as follows:
>
>Attached is the result of an analysis of the
structure within the expanding halo reproduced in false colour at twice normal
image size to show the detail present.
> It looks to me more like 29P than 17P.
>
>The reason is in part that the magnitude increase
of the C/2012 X1 outburst is similar to that of the more energetic 29P ones,
viz. some 5-6 magnitudes. That of 17P was a megaoutburst at 13-14
magnitudes!
>
>Fascinating the way somets behave so unexpectedly.
This is especially so given that C/2012 X1 was well before perihelion (to be
precise it was at a true anomaly of about -66 degrees). 17P outburst after
perihelion.
>
>I encourage folk to follow the development of this
present phenomenon taking as many images as poss so they can be stacked for
analysis.
>
>Richard Miles
>The comparison images are located at the following link on the BAA Comet Gallery:
>
> http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1704&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200
>
>Denis Buczynski
>Secretary Comet Section
>British Astronomical Association
>
>

Subject:  Comet ISON C/2012 S1- October 19th, 21st & Lovejoy C2013 R1
Comet ISON C/2012 S1, On October 21st, 08:55-09:16ut. Influence by Moon, Sun, Mars glares. (LX200ACF 12 in. OTA, F6.3, CGE mount, ST402me NAB Ccd, Astronomik Ir/Uv filter.

Comet ISON C/2012 S1, On October 19th, 09:07-09:37ut.

At: http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/1050174766/lightbox/1186669510 http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/1050174766/lightbox/1186669510 
Date:  Tue, 22 Oct 2013 18:51:09 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet P/2013 R3 (October 22nd.)
Hi all,

Here is an image obtained last night of P/2013 R3 (Catalina-Pan-STARRS) which was reported to be fragmenting in images obtained on Oct 11th by the 10.4m GTC telescope on La Palma.

A faint diffuse dust tail can be see and what looks like a slightly brighter condensation near the nucleus. I have performed only minimal processing to minimize potential artefacts.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/p2013_r3_2013_10_22dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI-PL6303E camera. 4x300secs unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Hi all,

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_s1_2013_10_24rgb.jpg

0.11m F5.6 with STL-11k camera. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Date:  Sat, 26 Oct 2013 07:16:06 +0100
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012 X1 Outburst continues
Hello All,
I have imaged this comet within the last hour and find that the outburst continues and the coma grows in diameter to 260 arc sec.
My image from this morning is at the following link:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1736&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Further images showing the development of this outburst can be found at the following link on the Comet Gallery of The British Astronomical Association:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=category&catid=99&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

Date:  Sat, 26 Oct 2013 18:59:51 -0700
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  Three Comets in the Morning sky
Hi all,

In an attempt to take advantage of clear skies before a few days of clouds from an incoming front move in, I was out this morning imaging some comets, all fairly low in the eastern sky just before morning twilght. For me, Comet Lovejoy was the clear winner, bright green in color and high up in the south east allowing longer exposure times. Here are the new images:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/3comets102613.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/3comets102613.html

Thanks for looking!

Chris Schur 
Date:  Sun, 27 Oct 2013 03:28:30 -0700
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  2P/Encke with Tail October 26.8, 2013
Dear members,

I found an image of the comet with lovely tail taken by a Japanese astroimager in Kumamoto 19:46UTC October 21, 2013, and I confirmed it.

Here is an enhanced image of the comet.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/10508427936/

Here is an inverted and enhanced image. The length of the tail looks to be about 14 arcminutes.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/10508413706/

Berst Regards,
hiro
Date:  Sun, 27 Oct 2013 12:07:24 +0100
From:  Alfons Diepvens

I confirm also your observation of this tail on
my images from 24 Oct 2013 to 27 Oct 2013.

It can be seen as a fine tail in PA: 313 °, possibly this is an ion tail?

Date:  Sun, 27 Oct 2013 04:36:44 -0700
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: 2P/Encke with Tail October 26.8, 2013
Hi Alfons,

I feel as you. The shape of the tail looks straight like a plasma tail, though I could not find the color of the tail on my image. I hope to confirm it in imaging without moonlight.

I remember the famous movie by NASA in 2007.
http://science1.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2007/01oct_encke/

A paper was released on the event, interaction between coronal mass ejection and plasma tail of comet.
http://secchi.nrl.navy.mil/Publications/Vourlidas_encke_07.pdf

hiro

Date:  Mon, 28 Oct 2013 15:14:41 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  20131028 comets
Hello all,
>From images taken this morning in Highland Scotland, with the moon close by in the sky I was able to image the comets below.

 C/2012 S1 is only brightening slowly
but the tail length is increasing. C/2012X1 is continuing its outburst,
the coma  is becoming more diffuse and more open at its northern edge but it size has increased to 320 arc secs. C/2013R1 is brightening rapidly
and has now developed a broad tail.

Images available at the links below on the Comet Gallery of The British Astronomical Association

C/2012 S1 ISON
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1760&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2012 X1 Linear
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1761&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2013 R1 Lovejoy
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1762&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
BAA

Date:  Mon, 28 Oct 2013 20:25:52 -0700
From:  Gary Spiers 
Subject:  DSLR image of ISON
My first posting to this group. My first night using this scope/camera combination. Pleasantly surprised at the results.

Nikon D7000, ISO 6400, 30 sec exposure, Celestron C-8 w. f#6.3 reducer. Stack of 10 images.

Location was Mojave National Preserve, Black Canyon Campground, early Sunday 27th. Lots of intermittent cloud.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/toptox/10548554194/in/set-72157637071020685

Gary 
Date:  Mon, 28 Oct 2013 21:26:32 -0700
From:  jaicoa52@yahoo.com

Hello all,

Continuing the series of images of the outburst of C/2012 X1 Linear by members of Comet Section of the BAA , links are given below for images taken this morning (20131029). The outburst is fading but the coma continues to grow in diameter to 350 arc sec today.

Denis Buczynski

Date:  Tue, 29 Oct 2013 12:53:00 -0400
From:  Oleg Vaisberg 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] ISON morning October 29
Hello Gerald,

thank you for great photos. With resolution current pictures provide the tail of ISON look strange to me, it is antisolar, but too smooth and no details, compared to usually structured plasma tails.

Best regards.
Oleg.

Date:  Tue, 29 Oct 2013 17:26:30 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2009 F4 McNaught - Oct 28th
Hi all,

Here is an image of C/2009 F4 captured earlier today. It continues to look quite interesting for such as distant object (7AU from the Sun.)

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2009_f4_2013_10_29dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL4710 camera. 4x2mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Wed, 30 Oct 2013 09:15:12 +1100
From:  mmatti@westnet.com.au
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] ISON morning October 29
Oleg,
in my opinion, this is a dust trail, similar to what 2011 L4 presented to us earlier this year.
There appears to be no ion/plasma activity.
This is a gas poor comet.
cheers,
Michael M

From: Oleg Vaisberg
Sent: Wednesday, October 30, 2013 3:53 AM
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

/173_Lovejoy_Oct29.jpg

Date:  Wed, 30 Oct 2013 11:44:15 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet Lovejoy with disturbed ion tail
Gidday Gerald,
You have the affect, here is the probable cause, recent CME plume.
http://cometal-comets.blogspot.com.au/2013/10/comet-ison.html

Keep a space weather eye on this link for more predicted CME passings. ISON
is near 1AU line due north of Sun in the disc graphic.
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/IswaSystemWebApp/iSWACygnetStreamer?timestamp=2038-01-23+00%3A44%3A00&window=-1&cygnetId=261

Kind regards, Alan.

Date:  Tue, 29 Oct 2013 23:16:40 -0700
From:  amar10sharmaa@yahoo.co.in
Subject:  Comet mega-biography -- ASV's participation
Hello comet-eers,

I've been a follower of ASV's mails for a couple years now, and have even posted twice thrice. It is time that I break the ice, and share with what I had been upto last year. Some of you might have just heard of it sometime on Facebook. But this is where I need your club's participation.

I thank you in advance for having the patience to go through my lengthy post, but that had to be it to convey my message.

By virtue of what my life has been, singularly in this sub-continent, towards everything about comets, I found myself by a very very loud inner voice to be the torch-bearer to go ahead and compile a very large biographical work on comet hunters and discoverers -- for my connection even towards them and the sport of comet hunting.

I started the work in August 2012 and sometime until February this year you would find me many a days sitting 10 hours working on it! I started it from *nothing* and could bring it to a decent preliminary stage.

What turned out as I realized is I'm compiling the largest book - call it an encyclopedia - on comet hunters and discoverers of the 20th century. It is mind boggling how I came to it, when I would least expect I possessed the energy to pursue such a thing. The statistics this encyclopedia is going to feature are exciting:

a) Every living comet hunter and discoverer that I could find out about, I reckon 80-90 (!!!) in number globally [Japan alone vies for 50% ratio!]. Nearly each individual of the 90 forms a separate chapter, big or small !!
b) Spanning the entire 20th century, actually from 1850!!
c) Spread over 9-10 countries!!

This is one of my best gifts to our global cometary family. :-)

Those weeks and months I had been in relentless communication with comet hunters, discoverers, and comet-eers over the world. Some members from few clubs were kind enough to give me contacts to those whom I could not contact. Others especially like Mr Denis Buczynski of BAA helped me out of the way. Finally, I had contacted practically every hunter and discoverer alive, except those dozens of Japanese who are inaccessible, but I could reach out to some of them indirectly. William Bradfield is the only one I could not personally reach out to. Even the then-92 year old Albert Jones did send me 2 emails! ALL those whom I contacted were kind enough to supply me with the information I needed. My entire book rests on searching through online archives and sending private emails. No matter what amount of excruciating work it would appear, I was just in bliss doing this work closest to my heart, so I sailed through those 6 intensive months. I could live those days every day of my life...

If the above biographical treatise seemed a lot to fit in one encyclopedia, let me tell you it is just a major half of the book! I have a second division which is the non-biographical section. This is the miscellaneous section on cometary matters. This book is an encyclopedia, so I would want to not miss it out making an all-round thesis. I have a sub-section in this division where I focus on some of the active cometary clubs over the world. Some clubs are such established that they have their independent Comet Sections, with own council, own newsletters, own routine of only-cometary activity and own historic archives.

This is an innovative chapter. So this is where ASV comes in. I know there has to be a section focusing dedicated cometary working groups. But "what" should come in this chapter is something I am unsure of. The few cometary clubs I could think of are:

BAA comet section
ASV comet section (Association of South Victoria)
ASSA comet section (South Australia - Bill Bradfield member)
ASSA comet section (South Africa)
German comet group
Oriental Association of Astronomy, Japan
ALPO comet section?

I would request all the members here who are much experienced than me with comets, to kindly get together with me on this, and brainstorm on how we can make this non-biographical section worth it. My problem is what I should do or include withing this section given the names of clubs like above to bring out to the world; I request ideas from each one of you.

Any questions you would have about my project for your clarification, kindly shoot at me! Regards,

Amar A. Sharma
Nikaya Observatory
India
www.picasaweb.google.com/nikayaobservatory 
Date:  Wed, 30 Oct 2013 00:43:54 -0700
From:  burkhard@gmx.at
Subject:  C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy) - Oct 29th

Burkhard
Date:  Tue, 29 Oct 2013 20:31:57 -0700
From:  respuestas2013@gmail.com
Subject:  V-R image of comet ISON
Hello:
In the following link you will see 3 visual images minus 3 red images
(V-R) taken by Jose Luis Martin and processed by myself. The images
shows a tail composed of dust (dark) and a coma composed of
gas(white) in the Sun's direction. Here it is:

http://astronomia.udea.edu.co/cometspage/IMAGES.xhtml http://astronomia.udea.edu.co/cometspage/IMAGES.xhtml

Ignacio
ooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo

From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Comets 20131030
Hello all,

Images of comets observed  by me this morning 20131030 at Tarbatness Observatory in Highland Scotland have been placed on the Comet Gallery of the British Astronomical Association at the links below.

Denis Buczynski

C/2012 X1 Linear  outburst continues and coma grows in diameter
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1773&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1772&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

2P Encke Long ion tail now very evident
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1771&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2012 S1 ISON no change
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1770&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

From:  amar sharma 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet mega-biography -- ASV's participation
How can this happen, this is just not possible.

I had gone to the homepage of ASV comet section and typed it out and posted it there. I was gazing at the page of the ASV yahoogroup for this email to appear and it did not. I see it appearing on Comet-Images group! Its bizarre!

Please ignore this email.

On Wednesday, 30 October 2013 1:44 PM, "amar10sharmaa@yahoo.co.in" wrote:

Date:  Wed, 30 Oct 2013 21:28:33 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 2P/Encke & The Virgo Cluster (Oct 30th.)
Hi all,

Here is Comet Encke passing close to the centre of the Virgo cluster of galaxies. M84/86 are off to the right while Encke is at left contrasting starkly in colour with the distant elliptical galaxies. Its also recently developed a faint narrow tail as it contiues to approach perihelion.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_2013_10_30rgb.jpg

0.11m F5.6 with STL-11k camera. LRGB. L: 4x3mins. RGB: 1x3mins. Taken with the comet at 16deg altitude during morning twilight.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Date:  Wed, 30 Oct 2013 23:39:54 -0700
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Oct. 31  2012 S1 and 2012 X1
Hello

My new images from this morning.

S2012 S1

http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/184724334/lightbox/1352107471 http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/184724334/lightbox/1352107471

Date:  Thu, 31 Oct 2013 19:12:57 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 2P/Encke close-up (Oct 30th.)
Hi all,

Here is a colour image of 2P/Encke obtained yesterday, this time with the larger scope. The fine narrow ion tail is very nicely defined which has recently developed. The coma is partially obscuring the small barred spiral galaxy NGC 4371.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2013_10_30dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL11002. LRGB. L: 10x1mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************
Date:  Thu, 31 Oct 2013 12:19:16 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] The tails of comet Lovejoy
The position angle of the ion tail is 281 degrees. The position angle of the extended Sun->target radius vector calculated by JPL Horizons for Oct 31, 2013 is 283.236 UT. The PA of an ion tail is typically within a few degrees of that.

________________________________
From: Gerald Rhemann
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, October 31, 2013 4:41 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] The tails of comet Lovejoy

Hello everybody,

This was Lovejoy morning October 31 – Color version will follow soon:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/174_Lovejoy_Oct31.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Thu, 31 Oct 2013 12:32:35 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 2P/Encke close-up (Oct 30th.) [1 Attachment]
The image is rotated 90 degrees with north on left East down.
After rotating to north up and east left, I measured the position angle of the ion tail is 310 degrees. The position angle of the extended Sun->target radius vector calculated by JPL Horizons for Oct 30, 2013 at 11:46 UT is  is 311.2 deg. The PA of an ion tail is typically within a few degrees of that.

________________________________

[Attachment(s) from Damian Peach included below]
Hi all,

Here is a colour image of 2P/Encke obtained yesterday, this time with the larger scope. The fine narrow ion tail is very nicely defined which has recently developed. The coma is partially obscuring the small barred spiral galaxy NGC 4371.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2013_10_30dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL11002. LRGB. L: 10x1mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Thu, 31 Oct 2013 20:18:37 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012 X1 Linear 20131031 1829 image
Hello all,
I imaged this comet this evening low down in the west just after sunset.
Comet altitude was less than 15 degrees. The outburst seems to be over
now and the surface brightness of the coma is now much less than it was
last week. The coma is still growing in diameter (430 arc sec tonight).
The central condensation looks larger and the central northwards curving jet is looks like the start of a tail structure now. The northwestern
edge of the coma seems less bright and less well defined and looks more
open ended than does the north eastern edge. The edge of the coma from
west around to north is well defined but the western quadrant is poorly
defined. This gives the coma an odd shape compared to the circular form
it took just after the outburst phase began. It will be interesting to
see how the coma and tail structures develop over the next few weeks. It will be something
to take our minds off worrying about the slower than expected
brightening of C/2012 S1 ISON as that comet approaches perihelion. Image is available at the following link on the Comet Gallery of the BAA.
Denis Buczynski
BAA
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1790&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200 
Date:  Thu, 31 Oct 2013 13:47:11 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2P/Encke with Tail October 26.8, 2013
assuming no image rotation, I measured
Alfons Diepvens image of 2P/Encke on  Oct 27 2013 at 0400 UT  ion tail PA = 311 deg    JPL Horizons PsAng = 311.7 deg
Alfons Diepvens image of 2P/Encke on  Oct 30 2013 at 0400 UT  ion tail PA = 308 deg    JPL Horizons PsAng = 311.4 deg
Alfons Diepvens image of 2P/Encke on  Oct 31 2013 at 0405 UT  ion tail PA = 312 deg    JPL Horizons PsAng = 311. deg
The PA of ion tail is typically within a few degrees of PsAng.

________________________________
From: Alfons Diepvens
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, October 27, 2013 6:07 AM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] 2P/Encke with Tail October 26.8, 2013

I confirm also your observation of this tail on
my images from 24 Oct 2013 to 27 Oct 2013.

It can be seen as a fine tail in PA: 313 °, possibly this is an ion tail?

See my images on :

2P Encke
- On 24 Oct 2013 Fine tail in PA: 310°
2P Encke
- On 27 Oct 2013 Fine tail in PA: 313°

Date:  Thu, 31 Oct 2013 23:14:44 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Oct 31st.)
Hi all,

C/2013 R1 from Oct 31st.

Looks as though a disconnection event may have occurred within Lovejoys gas tail. Note the broad fan shaped condensation around half way along the tail.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_10_31dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL4710. 2x3mins unfiltered.

Best Wishes

Damian

Hello all,

My image from this morning seems to show a possible spine like structure in the middle of the tail near the head. Length is about 2 arc mins. Good seeing and moisture at 70% only.

Virtual Telescope, under less than ideal conditions:

Is is part of a collaboration with with Ernesto Guido, Nick Howes and Martino
Nicolini (Remanzacco Observatory and Faulkes Telescopes Project).

Gianluca

Date:  Sat, 02 Nov 2013 11:53:32 -0700
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  C/2013 R1 Lovejoy with train of disconnected plasma tail remnants November 1.64, 2013
Dear members,

A tail disconnection event of the comet was observed by Damian Peach on October 31, 2013 as below.
http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_10_31dp.jpg

I tried a set of long exposure on the comet, and there looked to be a train of disconnected plasma tail remnants following the comet.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/10627189416/

We may be able to recognize the train on this inverted and enhanced image clearly.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/10629070755/

Best Regards,

hiro

Date:  Sat, 02 Nov 2013 17:57:18 -0700
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  Three Glorius Comets in the Morning sky!
Greetings Comet Friends,

This morning was really clear here in northern Arizona and we got up around 2am to start shooting comets. Comet Lovejoy is a real gem! Nice and bright green this object really shows well in both the binoculars and on the CCD chip. It is also quite high in the sky in Monoceros, so you can shoot it for hours if you like.

Comet ISON did not impress. Do you think its getting fainter this week? I sure had that impression. Now I cannot see it in the big 11 x 80 binoculars like last week, and there is no moon now. What is happening to our friend? The tail is like a big strip of light, super dim and low surface brightness. But there is still more green in the coma to see.

Comet Linear X1 was a pain to get in the 12.5" for imaging. When it finally rose high enough to see with about 1/4 my aperture at 5am, I had little time to get a color shot. I kept shooting till 5:30 to get that last B frame. ;) Not only is it hard to see, the seeing is horrendous down there and there are no guide stars! But I found one I could just get PHD guiding to lock on to in a 4 second exposure. whew. So here are my images, I hope you like:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/threecomets110213.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/threecomets110213.html

Chris Schur

Dear members again,

I noticed a streak of bright comet on the third frame and reprocessed. The train disappeared, and I've updated the images in my flickr page. It was my mistake.

Here is a timelapse movie including the frame containing a streak of bright meteor. The position of the streak was very bad or nice...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LOj1EURDfmo

Date:  Sun, 03 Nov 2013 05:48:25 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2012 S1 - 20131101
Hi Mike....I looked carefully at my 12 images from Nov. 2 and then some from this
morning and I am seeing no gradient within the coma of R1; I believe that this
artifact is just what I suspected, something that is showing up because of varying
degrees of density/saturation in each image that you were stacking.....as the comet
gain altitude it became less noisy and the saturation was far better on the comet and
not so much on the sky....each successive image had less sky glow and thus the
gradient appears to shrink as time goes on.

Hope this helps.....by the way, your image of ISON from yesterday is the BEST that I
have seen yet.

----- Original Message -----

Date:  Sun, 03 Nov 2013 17:41:11 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  is there any value in visual drawings of comets

Hello all,
In the (possibly unlikely) event of C/2012 S1 ISON becoming a bright naked eye comet in the next few months, I have been wondering about the value of visual observations( drawings) made at the eyepiece of telescopes and binoculars. The comparison between the eventual spectacle that C/2012 S1 ISON may become, with the actual views that was experienced by observers of Comet Kohoutek 1973f  is being heard more loudly as perihelion approaches for C/2012 S1 ISON. As experienced comet observers, members of this group may remember that Comet Kohoutek 1973f may not have been the Great Comet that was hoped for at the time, but it did reach naked eye visibilty and many observers were able to make succesful observations. Many of these were visual observations. Is there any value in observers today recording what can be seen in their telescopes?
Most observers
are taking images for astrometry/photometry or for pretty/stunning
image purposes. The visual observers are generally making magnitude
determinations and some are adding morphology details such as coma
size/and DC, plus tail lengths and orientations. Nobody actually
draws what they see. I am not the person to advise on drawing
techniques. But I would like to see this practice rekindled amongst
visual observers. The historical record is littered with high resolution
drawings of hoods and jets in inner coma regions of bright comets and of long tail structures. In
the event of a spectacular disintigration of C/2012 S1 at perihelion in a few
weeks time and a visual spectacle such as was seen in Comet Lovejoy C/2011 W3 happens , it would be excellent if we had some visual descriptions
and drawings of what could be seen. Of course the naked eye sees these
events in a differerent way and wavelengths to CCD images, so they would
be a valid and valuable record. One only has to look at the detail
recorded visually in the hoods and shells of Comet C/1995 O1 Hale-Bopp. The recent
outburst of C/2012 X1 Linear had evolving detail in the near nucleus region that
could probably be seen visually. The most recent classic
case of visual studies being important was John Bortle's record of the
break up and identification of the remants of CometC/1975V1.West in 1976. I have placed (for inpiration  purposes) some scans of George Alcock's and
John Bortle's comet sketchs, to show how they recorded their comet
observations at the links below. The details in the tail features have been confirmed by
comparision to photographs taken at the time. There are very few
observers who actually place eye to eyepiece and really see what is
there to be seen in a telescopic view of a comet. Drawing does help
concentration and can render more detail visible than a quick look. As
well as this, the observation is time dependant. Any observation of a
comet is unique as it will never be seen in that exact place in the sky
again, nor will the physical processes which have combined to allow the
comet to be seen at that time and in that way exactly repeat. Once it
has gone it has gone! It is different to the visual observation of a galaxy or nebula where essentially there is no change happening. One can wait for optimal observing conditions
to see a DSO at it's best. Not so with comets, you take what you can
get. That is why the observation is important. The ever changing aspects and physical development of the comet make observations unique. They
cannot be repeated, ever.So my question is this, is there any value in getting out there with your pencil and pad and
recording and reporting what you see?

Denis Buczynski
BAA

Comet Kohoutek 1973f Alcock
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1814&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet Kohoutek 1973f Alcock2
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1815&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet Kohoutek 1973f and Comet Bradfield 1974b Bortle
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1816&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet Bradfield 1974b Alcock and Walton
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1817&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Date:  Tue, 05 Nov 2013 00:44:47 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy C2013 R1
Hi,

C2013 R1 November 5, 2013 through a 16" f4.5 Newtonian and 8x1 minutes exposure at ISO6400.

Date:  Tue, 05 Nov 2013 20:06:47 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Encke  (Nov 4th.)
Hi all,

Here is 2P/Encke from Nov 4th. The Ion tail is very narrow and seems more prominent than back on Oct 30th. The nearby galaxy is NGC 4808. It will be tough to get colour images from now on as its rapidly falling into bright twilight as it continues toward perihelion in a couple of weeks from now.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/2p_encke_2013_11_04dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL11002. LRGB. L: 5x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro

Date:  Tue, 05 Nov 2013 12:08:19 -0800
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Observation of comets 2013 11 05
Good evening.

T300 France :

Re - discovery of 124P Mrkos
Coma : +/- 15"x9", lower extension angle 270/360°.
m2: +/- 20.4, R.o : 11.3", Echant. : 1.64"/pix.
Speed : 1.072"/min, PA : 106°.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image124PMrkosfrance.htm

C 2013 U2 Holvorcem
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013U2Holvorcemfrance.htm

P 2013 T1 PANSTARRS
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageP2013T1Panstarrsfrance.htm

C 2013 S1 Catalina
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013S1Catalinafrance.htm

52P Harrington- Abell, with the pair UGC 3139 and PGC 15892
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image52PHarrigtonAbellfrance.htm

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs, A.Maury, Chile. :

P 2013 CU129 PANSTARRS, secondary condensation seems to be the +
geometry of the dust tail that forms a dense + bead at this level,
only a small solid fragmentation...(?)
New observation :
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageP2013CU129PanstarrsChile.htm

C 2009 F4 Mc Naught
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2009F4McNaughtChile.htm

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013A1SidingSpringChile.htm

Date:  Wed, 06 Nov 2013 05:59:51 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012 S1 IMAGE tail bifurcation?
Hello all,
I imaged this comet an hour ago and suspected that there was a broadening of the tail and a possible bifurcation seen after 5 arc mins of the tail length with a portion seen to the south and the west. On individual frames watched as the images were taken this tail structure was present on all images. The observing conditons were not perfect, there was hazy thin cloud present, but I tried to bring out this detail in the stack of 10x60s frames. The image is at this link below.

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1835&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

I hope I am not crying wolf here, but I honestly believe that there has been some development of the tail stucture of this comet today. It will be interesting if other images from telescopes in better locations and conditions show this feature to be real,

Denis Buczynski 
Date:  Wed, 06 Nov 2013 09:32:08 +0100
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 S1 (ISON) - November 04, 2013

Date:  Wed, 06 Nov 2013 09:01:12 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2012 S1 IMAGE tail bifurcation?
Hi Denis,

This can also be seen in Martin Mobberley's image of Nov 4th. I did mention this to him via email. A very faint curved projection can just be discerned alongside the main tail.

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2012s1_20131104_mpm.jpg

Damian

From: DENIS BUCZYNSKI
To: "Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com" ; "comets-ml@yahoogroups.com" ; "comets-disc@britastro.org" ; "asvcometsection@yahoogroups.com"
Sent: Wednesday, 6 November 2013, 5:59
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2012 S1 IMAGE tail bifurcation?

Hello all,
I imaged this comet an hour ago and suspected that there was a broadening of the tail and a possible bifurcation seen after 5 arc mins of the tail length with a portion seen to the south and the west. On individual frames watched as the images were taken this tail structure was present on all images. The observing conditons were not perfect, there was hazy thin cloud present, but I tried to bring out this detail in the stack of 10x60s frames. The image is at this link below.

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1835&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

I hope I am not crying wolf here, but I honestly believe that there has been some development of the tail stucture of this comet today. It will be interesting if other images from telescopes in better locations and conditions show this feature to be real,

Denis Buczynski

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 X1 LINEAR in colour  (Nov 6th.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2012 X1 in colour from Nov 6th. Very reminiscent of the appearance of 17P/Holmes during its famous outburst (though of course this comet is only ~8th magnitude.)

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_x1_2013_11_06dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL11002. LRGB. L: 3x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins. Obtained during morning twilight.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Fri, 08 Nov 2013 17:22:46 -0800
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  Two Comets JUST over the observatory wall..
Greetings Cometary Friends,

Its getting darn difficult for us to shoot ISON in the morning now, Encke is certainly gone below the trees and Linear X1 just clears the trees at 5:20. This morning I think I may have the last shots for a long while of ISON, when I started shooting with my 12.5" newtonian in our backyard roll off observatory the wall occulted half the aperture, and by the time daylight was nearing at 5:15, I finally got full aperture over the wall. But the good news is that I had plenty of time to shoot Lovejoy, which is up higher and screaming through Cancer toward the sun at a break neck pace.

ISONs head is visible now with the 9 x 63 binoculars, but the tail was still too faint to see. But Lovejoy is killer in the binocs and we really were able to JUST see the comet naked eye this morning - mag 6 for sure!

Here are the results from way too many hours today of processing the images. Glad to share them!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/twocomets110813.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/twocomets110813.html

Chris Schur
Payson , Arizona 
Date:  Sat, 09 Nov 2013 02:17:54 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy brighter than ISON
While the media plays up ISON as being a very bright comet, C/2013 R1 Lovejoy is in fact much brighter at present. It is also higher in the sky, affording better imaging. I imaged it last night and captured a half a degree tail.

Please take a look at my web page -- images, isophotes, orbit diagram, light curve -- all kinds of data.

http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/new.htm .

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Hampshire, IL

Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk
Pier Design Paper http://users.FoxValley.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm
Daily Bread Inspirational Page (Helicopter Parable) http://users.foxvalley.net/~dpersyk/DailyBread/

Date:  Sat, 09 Nov 2013 07:02:26 +0000
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  Comets from this morning Nov. 09
Hello,

Comets this morning :

Ison: Taken just at sunrise, shows a jet in PA 100
applying a rotational gradient (GR30-0)

Lovejoy = With a changing and multiple ion tail (an animation
these jets must be possible?)

The youngest: C/2013 V3 (Nevski) nucleus condensed, low coma
extent, m2 = 16.5 mag, damage, clouds at the time of observation,
but easy to repeat, near Lovejoy.

C/2013 V2 (Borisov) mag. m2 = 17.5 appearance stellar

C/2013 V1 (Boattini): m2 = 15.4 mag well condensed, tail curved
90 "in PA 256

http://comet.observations.free.fr/all-obs-table.php

Francois 

Date:  Sat, 09 Nov 2013 01:34:24 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy brighter than ISON
Yes, at this time Lovejoy IS a brighter comet, but this does not mean that anything has changed with ISON; it happens that the geometry of the comets, both relative to earth and their proximity to the sun are radically different at this time and Lovejoy is remarkably close: less than 1/2 AU from earth to comet, thus it is moving quite rapidly and appears quite large. ISON is still a long ways away and approaching the sun very fast, with a maximum velocity later this month of slightly less than one million miles per hour (!).

So, do not think that Comet Lovejoy is "outperforming ISON".....it is simply getting its respect early because it is first around the sun, so to speak. But we must be careful comparing the two right now: there is simply no relative comparison at this point; when both are the same distance from earth and sun and at the same parameters (i.e., perihelion), THEN comparisons can be made. So in basic terms: Comet Lovejoy is very fine, yes, but NOT "outperforming" ISON as some are suggesting.

Dr. Clay
_____
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

features streaming away from the head are a law unto themselves!

Date:  Sun, 10 Nov 2013 13:27:57 -0800
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  2 comets from the Balcony observing station...
Greetings all,

With ISON now too low to get with the 12 inch, we have a portable setup we usually implement when imaging comets low in the morning eastern sky. The setup includes a medium duty portable german equatorial mount, with a Stellarvue SV80s mounted on it, and for now, a Hutech modified Canon XTi (11 megapixel) camera. Here is the first run on ISON with this setup, and we even had a few minutes in the brightening twilight to get Lovejoy, which shows a neat kink in the tail.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/balcony111013.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/balcony111013.html

Thanks for looking,

Chris Schur
Payson, Az

From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] RE: Comets Ison Nov. 10 LRGB
Chris, I worked with 8"/2.8 ASA which had the same lens/corrector than the Boren-Simen. You can used it
whith Chips up to 22-25mm. You need good flats. The vignetting is strong.

Michael

Date:  Tue, 12 Nov 2013 07:01:17 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012 S1 20131112 gas tail structure
Hello all,

I imaged this comet within the ast two hours and find that there is much more detail in the tail now. Along straight main gas tail and at least one more streamer mixed in the now broad dust tail. In my wide field image the dust tail splits into two sections at the furthest point from the head. The comet is now looking very active and is developing quickly now.
My images from this morning are placed on the Comet Gallery of The British Astronimical Association at the links below.

I am looking forward to seeing the colour images taken later today from the robotic telescopes.
Imaging this comet now is becoming more difficult as it rapidly closes in on its close brush with the Sun in a few days time.

Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness Highland Scotland
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1891&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1892&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200 
Date:  Tue, 12 Nov 2013 00:47:52 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  C/2012 S1 Nov. 12 preview
Hello

As Denis has just written some minutes ago, Comet Ison is more interesting day by the day. This morning, Gerald Rhemann and I were very lucky. 40 minutes before dawn the clouds on Jauerling (900 m above sea level) disappeared.

A preview from this night session.

http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/184724334/lightbox/1158490773 http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/184724334/lightbox/1158490773

Regards
Michael Jäger

Thanks Michael. I didnt know ASA made the same design. Ill look into that model as well, I sure miss the old schmidt camera days!

Chris Schur

---In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, wrote:

﻿ Chris, I worked with 8"/2.8 ASA which had the same lens/corrector than the Boren-Simen. You can used it
whith Chips up to 22-25mm. You need good flats. The vignetting is strong.

Michael

Date:  Tue, 12 Nov 2013 16:20:17 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2013 R1 Lovejoy images 20131112
Hello all,
I imaged this comet with narrow and wide field instruments last night and these images are placed on the BAA Comet Gallery at the links below. This comet is now very well placed for observation from Northern Hemisphere observatories and has developed into a naked eye object with a large coma. Imaging reveals a two distinct straight gas tails. A very nice object for imaging and viewing. Terry certainly lived up to his name and brought us joy when he discovered this comet.

Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness, Highland Scotland

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1894&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1895&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Date:  Tue, 12 Nov 2013 22:29:03 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Flicker Comet Image Board
http://www.flickr.com/groups/comet_images/

At this link is the only comet image board I kept. It is for comet images and there are no problems posting so far. I am telling everyone one this to give another outlet for there images. I even get some images from NASA. Please understand that I am not saying this to take away from this board but if your like me I can't open but about 1 of 5 these days. They gave us a gig to use for free so hell---lets use it.
Mike Holloway

Date:  Thu, 14 Nov 2013 11:25:41 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  visual comet observations between 2013 October 31-Nov 13
Hello all,

find below my visual comet observations on 2013 October 31-Nov 13 in both
Morris and ICQ formats.
Tycho 2 VT mag comparison stars. Sidgwick method
I have updated my website to include photos of the comets.
http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/sc.htm

C/2013 V3 Nevski
2013 Nov 13.73UT: m1=8.9, Dia.=6', DC=4...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
2013 Nov 13.73, 8.9, 6' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm Binoculars);
[Much brighter than anticipated. Comet is clearly in outburst since
discovery]

Comet C/2013 R1 Lovejoy
2013 Oct 31.75UT: m1=7.3, Dia.=8', DC=5...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
2013 Nov 01.75UT: m1=7.0, Dia.=10', DC=5...8x40mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
2013 Nov 03.75UT: m1=6.9, Dia.=10', DC=5...8x40mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
2013 Nov 13.73UT: m1=6.1, Dia.=13', DC=5...8x40mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)

2013 Oct 31.75, 7.3, 8' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm Binoculars);
2013 Nov 01.75, 7.0, 10' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
8x40mm Binoculars);
2013 Nov 03.75, 6.9, 10' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
8x40mm Binoculars);
2013 Nov 13.73, 6.1, 13' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
8x40mm Binoculars);

Comet C/2012 S1 ISON
2013 Nov 03.75UT: m1=9.0:, Dia.=3', DC=3...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
[8 degrees altitude, twilight interference]
2013 Nov 13.75UT: m1=8.0, Dia.=2', DC=6...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
[8 degrees altitude, twilight interference. DC has increased considerably
since last observation but coma still appears quite small]

2013 Nov 03.75, 9.0:, 3' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm Binoculars);

2013 Nov 13.75, 8.0, 3' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm Binoculars);

Comet C/2012 V2 LINEAR
2013 Oct 31.75UT: m1=9.9, Dia.=3', DC=5...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)
2013 Nov 03.75UT: m1=10.2, Dia.=2', DC=4...25x100mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Swan Hill, Victoria)

2013 Oct 31.75, 9.9, 3' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm Binoculars);
2013 Nov 03.75, 10.2, 2' (M. Mattiazzo, Swan Hill, Victoria, Australia,
25x100mm Binoculars);

cheers,
Michael

Dear All,

here it is this comet just imaged via the Virtual Telescope in Italy and showing
a faint tail:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2013/11/14/c2013-v3-nevski-an-image-showing-a-tail-14-nov-2013/

Best
Gianluca

PS: Comet Ison was amazing, too: even if very low, it showed a stunning ion tail! 

Date:  Thu, 14 Nov 2013 07:16:16 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2012 S1 Ison: bright and active
Dear All,

I've just observed this comet, finding it much brighter than last visit, 10 Nov.
While it was at only 18 deg above the horizon, it was showing a stunning ion tail:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2013/11/14/comet-c2012-s1-ison-is-showing-a-stunning-ion-tail-14-nov-2013/

Best
Gianluca

Date:  Thu, 14 Nov 2013 14:06:34 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  High resolution core of C2013 R1 Lovejoy
There has been a very curious "bow shock" feature to the NW of Comet Lovejoy's
nucleus that has been quite evident throughout CCD imagery/astrometry for the last
week.
This morning, in addition to capturing a quick wide-field shot of the comet, I used
the 0.5m ASO astrograph and 1-sec. CCD image to capture this very interesting plume.

Note the slight elongation of the comet's nucleus and the large partial arc-cloud to
the NW; this feature is completely over-saturated in long exposure images, but
clearly evident on every focus frame that we have been seeing since Nov 6.
The link is at the Arkansas Sky Observatorie's website:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2229.msg10272.html#msg10272

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Thu, 14 Nov 2013 15:50:01 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] High resolution core of C2013 R1 Lovejoy
Correction:
Please note that the anomaly noted near the nucleus of this comet is actually to the
SE of the center of the comet, NOT to the NW as originally stated.
South is UP in these photos and east is to the left; field of view on the nucleus
shot is about 11' x 17'; exposure time is 1 sec, binned 2 x 2

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Thu, 14 Nov 2013 13:51:21 -0800
From:  chergen@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: High resolution core of C2013 R1 Lovejoy
Hi Clay,

I have also been following this feature since the beginning of the month. On some of my latest images, a number of jets were imaged within the fame. These were especially apparent on images taken with the VATT 1.8-m on Nov. 12.45 UT.

You can see the relevant images at the ALPO Comet Section gallery:
http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_itemId=5155

- Carl Hergenrother

---In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, wrote:

There has been a very curious "bow shock" feature to the NW of Comet Lovejoy's
nucleus that has been quite evident throughout CCD imagery/astrometry for the last
week.
This morning, in addition to capturing a quick wide-field shot of the comet, I used
the 0.5m ASO astrograph and 1-sec. CCD image to capture this very interesting plume.

Note the slight elongation of the comet's nucleus and the large partial arc-cloud to
the NW; this feature is completely over-saturated in long exposure images, but
clearly evident on every focus frame that we have been seeing since Nov 6.
The link is at the Arkansas Sky Observatorie's website:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2229.msg10272.html#msg10272 http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2229.msg10272.html#msg10272

Date:  Fri, 15 Nov 2013 09:28:44 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] High resolution core of C2013 R1 Lovejoy
The 1s exposure is indeed spectacular. I already saw this plume in my
nov. 12th image (log scale)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013R1_Lovejoy_files/C2013R1.00000001.REDUCED+59average_logIRIS_1.jpg

The same image with a different adjustment brightness scale also shows a
another structure, a large bow, slightly V-shape 'in front' of the comet
- I don't know if it's real, maybe an
artefact from flat + image combining with Astrometrica? it crosses the
CCD from north to south (28arcmin).
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013R1_Lovejoy_files/C2013R1.00000001.REDUCED+59average_logIRIS_DDP_1.jpg

Comments welcome

http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013R1_Lovejoy.html

Luc

Le 14/11/13 21:06, P. Clay Sherrod a crit :
>
> There has been a very curious "bow shock" feature to the NW of Comet
> Lovejoy's
> nucleus that has been quite evident throughout CCD imagery/astrometry
> for the last
> week.
> This morning, in addition to capturing a quick wide-field shot of the
> comet, I used
> the 0.5m ASO astrograph and 1-sec. CCD image to capture this very
> interesting plume.
>
> Note the slight elongation of the comet's nucleus and the large
> partial arc-cloud to
> the NW; this feature is completely over-saturated in long exposure
> images, but
> clearly evident on every focus frame that we have been seeing since Nov 6.
> The link is at the Arkansas Sky Observatorie's website:
> http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php/topic,2229.msg10272.html#msg10272
>
> Clay

Date:  Fri, 15 Nov 2013 06:41:48 -0700
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] ISON in outburst
Hello everyone,

Well, after being clouded out for the past three mornings . . .

I finally get a chance to check out all this recent comet activity I've been
reading about.

ISON is an impressive object in the 10x50 binoculars. I couldn't quite
convince myself I was seeing it with the naked eye, but the fact it's in the
middle of the zodiacal light (not to mention the fairly low elevation)
probably had a lot to do with that. In 10x50s, November 15.50, m1=4.8 (equal
to Psi Virginis), 4' coma, tail 100 arc minutes, rough p.a. 275.

Hard to believe this is the same object that was only faintly visible in
10x50s three mornings earlier . . .

It's also hard to believe that Nevski is the same object I could barely
detect in the 41 cm scope a week ago  now very faintly visible in 10x50s,
and in the scope, large diffuse coma, DC ~2-3. November 15.49, m1 = 9.4, 9'
coma.

Lovejoy is quite impressive: in 10x50s, November 15.47, m1 = 5.7, 17' coma,
tail 1 degree in approximate p.a. 270. Once the moon set I could see it with
the naked eye without too much difficulty; the naked-eye appearance is
roughly similar to that of M33.

Whether this brightness increase in ISON is a true surge in brightness as it
approaches perihelion, or a "last gasp" as it begins to disintegrate, time
will tell . . .

Sincerely,

Alan

Date:  Sat, 16 Nov 2013 19:50:03 +0800
From:  John Nassr 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] ISON C2012 S1
Rolando,

Thank you for the positive words! Coming from a forefront comet imager like you, they are especially appreciated. I love comets too. They are full of surprises and mystery everyday. One does not have to wait eons to observe change in them like most other astronomical objects. ISON started off slowly making many wonder if it would at all live up to its hype. But now it is surprising everyone in very exciting ways. What a wonderful time to be in.

Best regards to all,

John

Date:  Tue, 05 Nov 2013 12:59:15 -0500
From:  Eric Jamison 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] is there any value in visual drawings of comets
Hi Dennis,

Interesting topic.

I have found that there can be value of sketching or drawings at the eyepiece, including comets. This includes training the eye to see more detail.

In addition it provides a permanent record of what I observed. This makes it easier to compare the detail I saw from night to night.

The first comet that I searched for using a telescope was Comet Kohoutek in January 1974. Unfortunately it was fainter than predicted, and not easy to find in my 60mm refractor. Because it had been predicted to be as bright as magnitude -4 (as bright as Venus), and it did not live up to expectations, when Comet

West came along in late 1975 it was largely ignored by the press. So I missed it.

In May 1983 Comet IRAS-Iraki-Alcock passed closer to Earth than any comet since 1770, and because of this I was able to see its motion through a pair of binoculars within seconds. Since 1986 I have tried to observe and sketch as many comets as possible, because each has its own distinct personality and often show changes from hour to hour and night to night. Making a sketch provides a permanent record of how the comet has changed.

The first comet I observed and made sketches of was Comet Halley in 1985 - 1986. It was going to at its best in April 1986, however it was low in the sky for Northern Hemisphere observers. In addition to making a sketch of the comet I also made a diagram of the sky showing the constellations, planets, and Moon if it was up. This shows me how low the comet was at the time of observations. Fortunately at the time I lived in an apartment on the second floor with a good view of the southern sky.

Here are links of two sketches I made of Comet Halley in March and April of 1986:

http://ejamison.net/comet_halley032286.html

Coma and pseudo-nucleus very bright and well defined. Noted faint, almost straight gas tail, with dust tail more feathery.

http://ejamison.net/comet_halley040386.html

Coma seemed larger this morning, very diffuse, with the pseudo-nucleus appearing slightly brighter. Noted faint dust tail, but comet no longer appeared to

have a gas tail that was visible when I observed Comet Halley on March 22, 1986. I found out later that the gas tail had disconnected, which made the comet

much less impressive during its closest approach to earth in late April.

Here is a link to other comets I have observed over the years, including sketches and observing reports of them:

http://ejamison.net/comets.html

This includes sketches I made of Comet Hale Bopp. When looking at drawings that George Phillips Bond had made of Donati's Comet in 1858, I noted that the detail he recorded was similar to what I saw and recorded in sketches I made of Comet Hale-Bopp in 1997, some 139 years later. These included jets coming off of the pseudonucleus that connected to and feed an inner parabolic hood, and several outer parabolic hoods:

http://ejamison.net/comet_halebopp032597.html

Also how detail in Comet Holmes changed over time:

http://ejamison.net/comet_holmes102907.html

http://ejamison.net/comet_holmes111207.html

Other comets that showed interesting detail:

Comet Pojmansk:

http://ejamison.net/comet_pojmanski030806.html

Comet Machholz:

http://ejamison.net/comet_machholz010205.html

Comet Ikeya_zhang:

http://ejamison.net/comet_ikeya_zhang041102.html

Comet Bradfield:

http://ejamison.net/comet_bradfield112287.html

Best,

Eric Jamison

http://ejamison.net/index.html

----- Original Message -----
From: DENIS BUCZYNSKI
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com ; comets-ml@yahoogroups.com ; comets-disc@britastro.org ; asvcometsection@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, November 03, 2013 12:41 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] is there any value in visual drawings of comets

Hello all,
In the (possibly unlikely) event of C/2012 S1 ISON becoming a bright naked eye comet in the next few months, I have been wondering about the value of visual observations( drawings) made at the eyepiece of telescopes and binoculars. The comparison between the eventual spectacle that C/2012 S1 ISON may become, with the actual views that was experienced by observers of Comet Kohoutek 1973f is being heard more loudly as perihelion approaches for C/2012 S1 ISON. As experienced comet observers, members of this group may remember that Comet Kohoutek 1973f may not have been the Great Comet that was hoped for at the time, but it did reach naked eye visibilty and many observers were able to make succesful observations. Many of these were visual observations. Is there any value in observers today recording what can be seen in their telescopes?
Most observers are taking images for astrometry/photometry or for pretty/stunning image purposes. The visual observers are generally making magnitude determinations and some are adding morphology details such as coma size/and DC, plus tail lengths and orientations. Nobody actually draws what they see. I am not the person to advise on drawing techniques. But I would like to see this practice rekindled amongst visual observers. The historical record is littered with high resolution drawings of hoods and jets in inner coma regions of bright comets and of long tail structures. In the event of a spectacular disintigration of C/2012 S1 at perihelion in a few weeks time and a visual spectacle such as was seen in Comet Lovejoy C/2011 W3 happens , it would be excellent if we had some visual descriptions and drawings of what could be seen. Of course the naked eye sees these events in a differerent way and wavelengths to CCD images, so they would be a valid and valuable record. One only has to look at the detail recorded visually in the hoods and shells of Comet C/1995 O1 Hale-Bopp. The recent outburst of C/2012 X1 Linear had evolving detail in the near nucleus region that could probably be seen visually. The most recent classic case of visual studies being important was John Bortle's record of the break up and identification of the remants of Comet C/1975V1.West in 1976. I have placed (for inpiration purposes) some scans of George Alcock's and John Bortle's comet sketchs, to show how they recorded their comet observations at the links below. The details in the tail features have been confirmed by comparision to photographs taken at the time. There are very few observers who actually place eye to eyepiece and really see what is there to be seen in a telescopic view of a comet. Drawing does help concentration and can render more detail visible than a quick look. As well as this, the observation is time dependant. Any observation of a comet is unique as it will never be seen in that exact place in the sky again, nor will the physical processes which have combined to allow the comet to be seen at that time and in that way exactly repeat. Once it has gone it has gone! It is different to the visual observation of a galaxy or nebula where essentially there is no change happening. One can wait for optimal observing conditions to see a DSO at it's best. Not so with comets, you take what you can get. That is why the observation is important. The ever changing aspects and physical development of the comet make observations unique. They cannot be repeated, ever.So my question is this, is there any value in getting out there with your pencil and pad and recording and reporting what you see?

Denis Buczynski
BAA

Comet Kohoutek 1973f Alcock
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1814&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet Kohoutek 1973f Alcock2
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1815&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet Kohoutek 1973f and Comet Bradfield 1974b Bortle
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1816&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Comet Bradfield 1974b Alcock and Walton
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1817&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

----- Original Message -----
From:
To:
Sent: Sunday, November 17, 2013 8:33 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Ison - >7� tail under bright moonlight

> Hello
>

Good morning.

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs., A.Maury, Chile :

C 2012 S1 Ison, Filter I Bessel
R.o. : 20000km = mag 6.4, Afrho : +/- 2800cm
Stationary activity see regress a bit.
G. R. 20°. A. Mass : 6.30
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012S1IsonChile.htm

C 2013 R1 Lovejoy, Filter I Bessel, A. Mass : 5.41
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013R1LovejoyChile.htm

Date:  Sun, 17 Nov 2013 16:54:37 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  comet ISON nov 15.2 UT - binning 1x1
Processing of the images in 1x1 binning reveals more detail near the nucleus
and shape of come (hint of coma wings) (images of nov. 15.2 UT)

Also remarkable differences between Af(rho) versus rho for R-Bessel and
I-Bessel filter (all on the webpage)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2012s1_20131115.html

___________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

Date:  Sun, 17 Nov 2013 17:49:11 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012S1 NOV 17 inner coma
Hello all,
I imaged the comet this morning in fairly poor conditions of thin cloud and full moonlight, however could see the same features that Erik Bryssinck has described as coma wings in his post earlier today seen on his images of Nov 15.These wings seem to emanate from
an area of the pseudo nucleus that is some distance from the furthest
forward point. The brightest point in my images of the inner coma this
morning seem to show a slightly elongated shape. Perhaps this is an
instumental effect. My image taken this morning is at the following link:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1964&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness Highland Scotland 
Date:  Sun, 17 Nov 2013 11:42:54 -0800

Date:  Sun, 17 Nov 2013 22:16:11 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012 S1 20131117 inner coma processing
Hello all,

Images taken this morning of the inner coma region of this comet have now been processed. Details are from Nick James of the BAA.

I have processed Denis Buczynski's images (obtained with a C14 + ST9XE
CCD from Tarbatness) using a rotational gradient filter. Two stacks were processed. One is a stack of 10x30s images where the photocentre is
just saturated and the other is a stack of 58x1s images where the
photocentre was well below saturation. In each case I have used a 15 deg rotation centred on the photcentre pixel. There is an apparent jet in
PA 30deg eminating from the photocentre.

Single frames near the photocentre show an elongated feature which appears to align with the possible jet feature.

Images are placed on the Comet Gallery of the British Astronomical Association at the following links:

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1970&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1971&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
BAA
