Date:  Tue, 19 Nov 2013 14:50:31 +0000
From:  Geraint Jones 
Subject:  A Call for Ion Tail Images
We at University College London's Mullard Space Science Laboratory have
issued a call for images of comets' ion tails to help us learn more about
the interactions between comets and the solar wind, and the structure of
the solar wind itself.

Of course C/2012 S1 (ISON) and C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy) are the main targets of
interest at the moment, but older images of other comets are also very
welcome. Please visit this webpage for details:

http://bit.ly/cometimages

Many thanks,
Geraint Jones and Yudish Ramanjooloo

Mullard Space Science Laboratory
University College London 
Date:  Tue, 19 Nov 2013 16:55:14 +0100

17"CDK with FLI-PL6303E. LRGB. L: 8x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

From:  Vitali Nevski 
Subject:  Re: 2012S1
Comet significantly increased activity, vis. mag. approximately 3.7!

0.4-m Santel f/3, 10x15sec. ISON-Kislovodsk Observatory.

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Vitali-Nevski-2012S1_20131120_1384917872.jpg

Date:  Tue, 19 Nov 2013 21:25:55 -0800
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  Comet ISON, Spica and the Full moon!  11/18/13
Greetings Comet Friends,

Comet ISON is plunging into the sunrise fast, and there will be only a few more days to see it before perihelion. This image was taken at full moon, not the greatest for imaging a faint comet, but the opportunity to capture a nice comet in the same field as a brilliant first magnitude star was irresistable. This image, taken yesterday morning at 5am was a race against the comets altitude above the trees and sunrise. It was about 12 degrees up when I took this shot.

Photo Details:
See caption to the right of image.
Here is the new shot:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/ison111813.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/ison111813.html 

Date:  Tue, 19 Nov 2013 22:09:50 -0800

________________________________
From: "comets133@yahoo.com"
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, 20 November 2013, 5:25
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet ISON, Spica and the Full moon! 11/18/13

Greetings Comet Friends,

Comet ISON is plunging into the sunrise fast, and there will be only a few more days to see it before perihelion.  This image was taken at full moon, not the greatest for imaging a faint comet, but the opportunity to capture a nice comet in the same field as a brilliant first magnitude star was irresistable.  This image, taken yesterday morning at 5am was a race against the comets altitude above the trees and sunrise.  It was about 12 degrees up when I took this shot.

Photo Details:
See caption to the right of image.
Here is the new shot:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/ison111813.html 

Date:  Wed, 20 Nov 2013 09:25:20 +0100

Date:  Thu, 21 Nov 2013 17:16:41 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  color image of ISON from this morning Nov 21
Hello everybody,

Believe it or not this image was taken this morning remotely in Namibia.
Comet was 1 ½ altitude at start of imaging and 5° at the end in twilight.
Location is at -23° (southern hemisphere) So far it is my best image of this
comet:

s/191_ISON_Nov21.jpg>
http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/191_ISON_Nov21.jpg

best regards

Gerald

Subject:  Comet ISON plus Possibe Fragmentation or Disconnect Event Widefield L - Nov 21
Hi All

Taken from New Mexico Skies a few hours ago.
Am not sure how to interpret the event in the tail - I assume a small fragment or disconnect event.

From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet ISON plus Possibe Fragmentation or Disconnect Event Widefield L - Nov 21
Hello all,

Looking at images taken earlier this morning this feature can be seen to move along the length of the tail in this sequence:
Gerald Rehmann 02:49 UT feature not seen
http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/191_ISON_Nov21.jpg

-Juanjo 06:06 UT feature seen

http://cieloprofundo.files.wordpress.com/2013/11/c2012s1-20131121-j01.jpg

David Storey IOM  06:28 UT feature seen
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1984&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Joseph Brimacombe  12:23 UT feature seen
http://www.flickr.com/photos/43846774@N02/10979421326/in/photostream/

The comet is obviously very active.
Denis Buczynski

BAA

s/191_ISON_Nov21.jpg>

/191_ISON_Nov21.jpg

best regards

Gerald 

Date:  Thu, 21 Nov 2013 19:42:41 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] color image of ISON from this morning Nov 21
Dear Damien,

Thank you for your comment and your understanding of the issue. The place there is a really fantastic one. I tried it the night before but gave up because of clouds. But last night it was perfect.

Best regards

Gerald

Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Im Auftrag von Damian Peach
Gesendet: Donnerstag, 21. November 2013 19:36
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: Re: [Comet-Images] color image of ISON from this morning Nov 21

Gerald - thats really impressive for that altitude. A wonder anything is possible below 5deg altitude! The sky quality there must be really excellent.

From: Gerald Rhemann
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, 21 November 2013, 16:16
Subject: [Comet-Images] color image of ISON from this morning Nov 21

Hello everybody,

Believe it or not this image was taken this morning remotely in Namibia. Comet was 1 ½ altitude at start of imaging and 5° at the end in twilight. Location is at -23° (southern hemisphere) So far it is my best image of this comet:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/191_ISON_Nov21.jpg

best regards

Gerald

Date:  Sat, 23 Nov 2013 00:13:28 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Comets 20131122
Hello all,

I  imaged  comets C/2013 R1 and C/2013V3 last night (in moonlight) before cloud arrived at 04:00 UT which prevented me observing C/2012S1. The images of these 2 comets are on the Comet Gallery of The British Astronomical Association  at the following links.
2013v3 Nevski
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1992&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

2013r1 Lovejoy
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1993&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1994&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=1995&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2013r1 continues to be an impressive object with ever changing tail streamers. When the moon is out of the sky and no longer interferring, this comet could be very an excellent target for observation in the pre dawn hours vigil waiting for C/2012S1 to rise.

Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness Highland Scotland

Date:  Mon, 25 Nov 2013 12:44:19 -0800
From:  mitsu@supereva.it
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (from city)(DSLR) 25nov2013
Canon 5D mkIII mod + Nikon 180/2.8 @ f/4 60x2s 12800iso, no filter, crop & resize.
Note M63 and M51. I did not apply any NR. In this, if reduced in size, you can see a bit of the artifact made by the flat synthetic.
Presence of high LP, strong humidity, and last quarter of the moon.

Date:  Tue, 26 Nov 2013 19:05:01 +0000
From:  Michael Oates 
Subject:  Comet C/2013 R1 Lovejoy in NIR 2013-11-25
Hi, my first image post to this group.

C/2013 R1 Lovejoy taken in Near InfraRed using a Astrodon L-NIR filter (700nm)
Image and details here:
http://www.astrobin.com/65824/

The only way I am going to be able to contribute any decent images of comets is by using a
filter of some sort. I live in Manchester (UK) so light pollution is a major issue. So
going of past messages about the limitations of filters like CLS or IDAS in this group, I
thought I would try to image in Near InfraRed (NIR) at least that passes all light past
700nm, so there are no parts of the spectrum that are rejected. Well, obviously everything
below 700nm :)

Do please comment on this, as I would like to know if such images are more useful than
those taken with light pollution filters.

Thank you,

Mike

Date:  Wed, 27 Nov 2013 15:05:23 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Ison Nov. 22 image with two CCD-cameras
Hello

Now i had finished my image from nov. 22, when the comet was low and in brighter sky.
For this image i used

L 10x60 sec APO 80/400 and CCD Kai 11002 2x2 bin and RGB 70/70/70sec
and
6x60sec Leica-Apo 180mm/f.4.0 1x1 bin and KAF 6300

Horizon was 1x10sec with APO at 4x4 bin

Best Regards
Michael Jäger

http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/184724334/lightbox/1168691604 http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Comet-Images/photos/albums/184724334/lightbox/1168691604

Sloan r')

CLR)

Sloan r')

Sloan r')

(enormous glare from Jupiter, filter CLR)

Date:  Thu, 28 Nov 2013 19:00:38 +0000
From:  Μanos Kardasis 
Subject:  Negative daylight imaging of ISON

Hello, I spent many hours experimenting today, but I had no results. I managed to capture easy Mercury, Saturn and even the ~2.5 mag star delta Sco but not ISON. During most of the time I had thin clouds but I've tried for 2-3 hours at the MPC coordinates and near-by... but no Comet It must have too low brightness,disintergrated or I had wrong coordinates (but this has never happened before)....so I read now that the game is over....

http://www.astrovox.gr/forum/album_pic.php?pic_id=17290

Manos

Date:  Thu, 28 Nov 2013 16:04:22 -0800
From:  kodama@alumni.caltech.edu
Subject:  ISON visible past perihelion

as posted on Google+ by Jonathan Langdale...

https://plus.google.com/u/0/+JonathanLangdale/posts/M64AsGw3ZgC https://plus.google.com/u/0/+JonathanLangdale/posts/M64AsGw3ZgC 

Date:  Fri, 29 Nov 2013 01:53:06 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2013-11-28: C2012 A2  C2013 P3 V1  V2  V5  P2013 O2
Dear all

Here are the images from this evening:

C/2012 A2 LINEAR (CLR filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2012A2_LINEAR.html

P/2013 O2 PANSTARRS (CLR filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/P2013O2_PANSTARRS.html

C/2013 P3 Palomar (CLR filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013P3_Palomar.html

C/2013 V1 Boattini (r' Sloan filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013V1_Boattini.html

C/2013 V2 Borisov (CLR filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013V2_Borisov.html

C/2013 V5 Oukaimeden (CLR filter)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013V5_Oukaimeden.html

Best

Luc 
Date:  Fri, 29 Nov 2013 07:34:23 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Comet Brewington 154P
Hi,

Comet Brewington 154P is not as bright or newsworthy as fellow comets ISON and Lovejoy but I thought it was never-the-less worth at least a visit. 16" f4.5 and 8 minutes total exposure.

http://stardustobservatory.org/images.php?page=details&id=369

John 

Date:  Fri, 29 Nov 2013 02:24:21 -0800
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Observation of comets
Good morning.

T300:

154P Brewington (in the clouds)
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image154PBrewingtonfrance.htm

P 2013 W1 PanStarrs
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageP2013W1Panstarrsfrance.htm

C 2013 V5 Oukaimeden
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013V5Oukaimedenfrance.htm

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs, A.Maury, Chile :

C 2012 V2 Linear
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012V2LinearChile.htm

C 2009 P1 Garradd, which changed to ...
between 2011 : http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2009P1Garradfrance.htm
and now : http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2009P1GarradChile.htm

C 2013 N4 Borisov, Red Filter
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013N4BorisovChile.htm

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France
Date:  Fri, 29 Nov 2013 06:43:34 -0800
From:  mfborman@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: Negative daylight imaging of ISON
Manos,

I did some solar imaging yesterday, and at the time of ISON's perihelion, I carefully moved the scope to the comet's position and removed the filter. Just like your observation, the camera found nothing there.

Mike Borman
Evansville, Indiana, USA
www.mborman.org

---In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, wrote:

Hello, I spent many hours experimenting today, but I had no results. I managed to capture easy Mercury, Saturn and even the ~2.5 mag star delta Sco but not ISON. During most of the time I had thin clouds but I've tried for 2-3 hours at the MPC coordinates and near-by... but no Comet It must have too low brightness,disintergrated or I had wrong coordinates (but this has never happened before)....so I read now that the game is over....

http://www.astrovox.gr/forum/album_pic.php?pic_id=17290 http://www.astrovox.gr/forum/album_pic.php?pic_id=17290

Manos 

Date:  Fri, 29 Nov 2013 19:10:14 -0000

Subject:  2013 R1  via New Mexico - Nov 29th

Date:  Fri, 29 Nov 2013 20:49:19 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy passes M63 (Nov 25th.)
Hi all,

I captured C/2013 R1 passing the bright spiral galaxy M63 on November 25th.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_11_25dp.jpg

15cm F7 with STL-11k. 2 image mosiac. LRGB. L: 7x2mins. RGB: 1x5mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Date:  Sat, 30 Nov 2013 16:22:52 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  ISON approaches - Sep to Nov.
Hi all,

Here is a montage of images from Sep 24th to Nov 15th. This may well be my final word on it. It now looks to be fading away in the latest SOHO images.

But here it is growing in brightness on approach to its best in mid-late November.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_s1_sep_nov13.jpg

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro

Sent: Saturday, November 30, 2013 5:22 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] ISON approaches - Sep to Nov.

Hi all,

Here is a montage of images from Sep 24th to Nov 15th. This may well be my final word
on it. It now looks to be fading away in the latest SOHO images.

But here it is growing in brightness on approach to its best in mid-late November.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_s1_sep_nov13.jpg

Best Wishes

Damian

Sent: Friday, 29 November 2013, 20:49
Subject: Comet Lovejoy passes M63 (Nov 25th.)

Hi all,

I captured C/2013 R1 passing the bright spiral galaxy M63 on November 25th.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_11_25dp.jpg

15cm F7 with STL-11k. 2 image mosiac. LRGB. L: 7x2mins. RGB: 1x5mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Sun, 01 Dec 2013 01:20:22 -0000
From:  John 
Subject:  Lovejoy Through the Trees
Hi,

The comet is visible to the naked eyes under dark sky and appears greenish with a star-like nucleus through binoculars.

This 7x30 seconds image was taken through an Astrophysics 5" refractor with a reducer at f/5.3 and a Nikon D7000 at ISO6400.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/LovejoyC2013R1Nov3020132130UTAP127f53D7000iso64007x30secFOV80x121-Nassr_20131130191440.jpg

John

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageP2013W1Panstarrsfrance.htm

C 2013 V1 Boattini, tail : +/- 5', coma : +/- 50"
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013V1Boattinifrance.htm

84P Giclas
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image84PGiclasfrance.htm

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image290PJagerfrance.htm

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image124PMrkosfrance.htm

Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 08:51:54 -0800
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: Comet imaging
Hello Jim,

It might be easier as far as options goes to first use the camera software to convert those images to 16 bit Tif format. Then any number of programs can be used to stack them. One popular program which gives excellent results is MaxDSLR which is what I use. I have also had good sucess at registering the nucleus and stacking with Images Plus, which does both CCD and DSLR images as well.

Chris
Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 18:08:08 +0100

Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 10:20:57 -0800
From:  skinn85@yahoo.com
Subject:  Re: Comet imaging
Sure! I use a Pentax K20D with various lenses (300mm zoom particularly with small comets). I mount it on top of my C8 which I use for tracking. I have tried Registar 6 but don't understand how to get the stars lined up. I have also tried Deep Sky Stacker with very limited success. If I get the program to stack more than one image, the picture it gives me looks like an abstract- black, black background with a few color spots for the brighter stars and comet. Also if the comet has moved between frames the program will not stack on the comet. The instructions show a comet stacking application but in use it's not there. Thanks in advance for any help I can get.

Jim
Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 10:27:01 -0800
From:  skinn85@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: Comet imaging
I use a Pentax K20D with various lenses mounted on a C8 for tracking. I have tried Registar 6 but can't get the stars to line up. I have also used Deep Sky Stacker with very limited success. When it allows me to stack more than one image the resulting photo looks like an abstract-- black, black background with color spots for the brightest stars and comet. Also even though the instructions show a comet stacking application, it is not there in actual use. Any help is greatly appreciated. Thanks, Jim
Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 19:50:48 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Comet imaging
I have a Canon 7D which allows the operator to save images as JPG or RAW. Also you can set it to save both JPG and RAW for each shot. Raw is an image with no post processing done by the camera. For software there is a program out there somewhere called "DeepSkyStacker" I have it and have used it. This will process FITS and TIFS. I found it a little complicated but never was good to read the instructions. I think it is free but don't quote me on that.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, wrote:
>
> I do not see that option on my camera. I can use JPEG or RAW. The RAW has PEF or DNG And there is RAW+ which I really have no clue. I will check out those software. Thanks, Jim
> 

Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 20:03:37 -0000

Date:  Wed, 04 Dec 2013 20:48:04 +0000
From:  Stephane GARRO 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet imaging
Hello Jim,

Did you try Nebulosity software ?
It is user-friendly and powerful, and available both for Windows and
Mac OS X.
See :
http://www.stark-labs.com/nebulosity.html
Well documented and fine for RAW images processing !

For stacking, you will have to click on the nucleus for each image, so
good for bright comets but not for faint ones. But DSLR are not
designated for faint comets imaging, are they ?

Best sky to everyone,

Stephane

From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  RE: Comet imaging
Jim,

the sofware disk that came with your camera can covert those file types into Tiffs. EVery DSLR made has this software available. If you bought your camera used you can still download for free the same software from the camera manufacturer.

Chris

Date:  Thu, 05 Dec 2013 15:26:43 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  Lovejoy disconnection event
The great disconnection event shown by the wide field view of Michael have
been taken under very difficult conditions  gust of wind up to 80km/h and
cirrus clouds - I´ve been with him using a longer focal length. Therefore
only one of the disconnection can be recognized but to see how things happen
very fast have a look on this video, which was taken in a timeframe of
approx 15 minutes:

http://www.astrostudio.at/4_Videos.php?img=images/4_Videos/106_Lovejoy_Dec5.
avi

Images will follow soon.

Gerald

Date:  Fri, 06 Dec 2013 16:30:45 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  Color images of Lovejoy December 5
Hello everybody,

Right now I have finished the processing of the imaging session from morning
December 5.

Beside the storm gusts imaging was frequently disabled by clouds. Therefore
the first session was started at UT 2h51. Because of clouds we had to wait
until UT 4h12m before it cleared up again.

The first image clearly shows one of the tail disconnection:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/193_Lovejoy_Dec_05.jpg

On the second image one can´t see anything:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/194_Lovejoy_Dec_05_2.jpg

Have a look at the video of the first session where one can see how fast
this material moved away:

http://www.astrostudio.at/4_Videos.php?img=images/4_Videos/106_Lovejoy_Dec5.
avi

Best regards

Gerald

Date:  Sun, 08 Dec 2013 14:57:12 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Lovejoy 7 Dec 2013
4th consecutive night on comet Lovejoy, with nice details both in the tail and inner coma.
Imaged from 4 to 6 UT, 7 dec 2013
Tot exp 56.5 min (LRGB 35-6-6-6 min + 3.5 min (7x30s) for the core), TEC 140, SBIG STL 11000, Schmidt fork mount.
Tradate (VA), Italy.

http://spaceweathergallery.com/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=91069

Lorenzo

Date:  Mon, 09 Dec 2013 18:37:35 -0800
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  Comet 2013 R1 Lovejoy - Just Barely over the wall...
Greetings All,

As this nice comet makes a plunge toward the eastern horizon, our viewing oppourtunities from our observatory here in northern Arizona are becoming quite limited by the surrounding pine forest! None the less, this shot, taken very low over the trees and observtory eastern wall might be my last on this comet for a while with our 12.5" astrograph. Seeing was horrific, but the comet was stunning to say the least!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Lovejoy120613.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Lovejoy120613.html

Thanks for looking,

Chris Schur
Payson, Az

Date:  Tue, 10 Dec 2013 11:18:17 +0100
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] ISON 10 Dec negative to mag 16
> My observation of this morning. As reported by others, no sign of
> condensation in the forecasted position.

Then again STEREO still got a pretty strong signal from the comet remains
on December 5, a full week after perihelion:
https://fbcdn-sphotos-b-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-prn2/1404680_636905726350449_2080556296_o.jpg
= stack the of HI-1A images
http://stereo-ssc.nascom.nasa.gov/browse/2013/12/05/ahead/hi1/1024/ (where
you can see the dust cloud move behind the word "Ahead" all day).

The situation gives me a strong deja-vu of the hunt for Elenin's remains
two years ago: initial controversial visual sightings, followed by many
imaging failures. Now the question is whether the happy end back then -
http://www.oculum.de/newsletter/astro/100/40/8/148.ln1in.asp#2 - will also
follow this time ...

Daniel

P.S.: As I understand the etiquette here, the *discussion* of imaging
results should take place on the comets-ML - thus the cross-posting

I've seen the images from Stereo, where the comet looks with a dimension similar to M45. But my question is: what shape and dimension we expect from
Earth?

Lorenzo

Date:  Tue, 10 Dec 2013 16:45:02 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2012S1 location image no2
Hello all,
This morning in clear skies in Highland Scotland I was able to take a series of 60s exposures of the ephemeris location of this comet using C14 telescope and a 300mm f/4 Apo lens and SBIG CCD cameras. The field was above 10 degrees altitude at the time of the exposures (06:30UT). I was UNABLE to find any CONDENSED OBJECT at the ephemeris location down to mag 15 when compared to the DSS field image. It seems that no significant nucleus of this comet survived the perihelion passage.
My images are at the following link on the BAA Comet Gallery.

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=2066&option=com_joomgallery

Details of the images are in the text box below the images.

I was not searching for any dust cloud remnant, but for any indication that the nucleus survived. I am sure that it may be possible to image the dust cloud, as Terry Lovejoy has suggested using wide angle fast optics in the same way that the dust cloud remnant of C/2010 X1 was imaged. We know from the spacecraft images that a dust cloud remained but the question of any surviving nucleus was not certain. It was for this purpose that my searches have been made. It would be interesting to examine any deeper images taken in better conditons and at a higher resolution than my imaging set up to be more certain that the nucleus did not survive.
Perhaps we have seen the death of this comet with the SOHO images at perihelion and no more images will be seen. Ah well!

Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness Observatory MPC Code I81 
Date:  Wed, 11 Dec 2013 02:40:57 -0800

Date:  Wed, 11 Dec 2013 13:49:38 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  ISON 11 Dec negative to mag 17.5 (wide+narrow
Dear list, here is my observation of this morning. Another negative one. This time I was able to collect more exposure and make a very accurate flat
field. I cleaned the filters and CCD, I made an accurate flat field with a flat box, and finally I made a flat refinement on a nearby sky field.

This way I was able to dig into the bottom to search for any wide remnant of ISON. Unfortunately I cannot find anything convincing: the faint
brightness patches in the field resemble more flat residuals that a remnant.

I also added all exposures with alignment on the expected position (using Astrometrica), but nothing condensed is visible down to about mag. 17.5, and
in a field of 2.04x1.36.

11 dec 2013, 5.37.01 UT, 9x120s, TEC140+SBIG11k, B39 obs (Tradate, Italy)

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vs_ison_9x120s_AVE_el3_text_1386765706.jpg

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vs_ison_9x120s_Astrometrica_AVE_el2_1386765706.jpg

Lorenzo

Date:  Wed, 11 Dec 2013 19:26:25 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  C/2013 r1 inner coma hoods.
Hello all,
I imaged  this bright comet in the early hours of Dec 10 and upon processing my images taken with a C14 and ST9XE ccd I noticed thas there seemed to be features in the inner coma which look like parabolic hoods. These look like the features seen in images of C/1995 O1 Hale-Bopp. Has anyone else imaged these features in the inner coma of this comet. I cannot remember seeing recent images showing these type of feature. I have seen the swept back curved structures inside the coma but not these hoods. Any comments are welcome. Image is located at :

http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=2067&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness Highland Scotland

Michael Jäger
Date:  Thu, 12 Dec 2013 08:57:37 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] C/2013 r1 inner coma hoods.
Hi Denis,

the inner coma of C/2013 R1 has always been very intriguing. The images below
were shared on comets-images ml:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2013/12/05/comet-c2013-r1-lovejoy-nucleus-and-tail-05-ndec-2013/

In particular, look at the image at the bottom: because of its resolution, shows
the very inner coma pretty well.

Best
Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 13 Dec 2013 15:15:07 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  ISON Dec 13, wide field dust cloud, negative
Other than any condensed remnant (see previous post on Comet-ML), I tried also to search for the dust cloud remnant of comet ISON. According to the
latest STEREO images, this cloud can be very faint and large. So I tried to image with a fast telephoto lens, a Pentax 165 mm f/2.8 with a full frame
CCD (SBIG STL 11000). I was occluded partially by low altitude trees, so I've cropped the field at about 10x7. I've calibrated with dark and skyflat
made immediately after the images, so that I can have the cleanest background. I needed to fight with the strong gradient due to the incoming morning
lights. I've processed to improve the background smoothness.

Unfortunately I cannot see any convincing dust cloud remnant. Only gradient residuals.

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vt_ISON_165mm11k_10x30s_flatok_el4_tirata_dida_1200_1386943635.jpg

13 Dec 2013, 5.44.27 UT (midpoint)
Pentax lens 165 mm f/2.8
SBIG STL 11000 at -35C
field 9.92 x 7.02
limiting mag ~14
10x30s tracked on comet motion
B39 obs (Tradate, Italy)

Lorenzo

--

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

On Fri, 12/13/13, Lorenzo Comolli wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] ISON Dec 13, wide field dust cloud, negative
To: "Comet Images"
Date: Friday, December 13, 2013, 7:15 AM

Other than any condensed remnant (see
previous post on Comet-ML), I tried also to search for the
dust cloud remnant of comet ISON. According to the
latest STEREO images, this cloud can be very faint and
large. So I tried to image with a fast telephoto lens, a
Pentax 165 mm f/2.8 with a full frame
CCD (SBIG STL 11000). I was occluded partially by low
altitude trees, so I've cropped the field at about 10°x7°.
I've calibrated with dark and skyflat
made immediately after the images, so that I can have the
cleanest background. I needed to fight with the strong
gradient due to the incoming morning
lights. I've processed to improve the background
smoothness.

Unfortunately I cannot see any convincing dust cloud
remnant. Only gradient residuals.

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vt_ISON_165mm11k_10x30s_flatok_el4_tirata_dida_1200_1386943635.jpg

13 Dec 2013, 5.44.27 UT (midpoint)
Pentax lens 165 mm f/2.8
SBIG STL 11000 at -35°C
field 9.92° x 7.02°
limiting mag ~14
10x30s tracked on comet motion
B39 obs (Tradate, Italy)

Lorenzo

--
____________________________________________________________
Lorenzo Comolli
Internet: http://astrosurf.com/comolli/
E-mail: mailto:comolli@libero.it

Gruppo Astronomico Tradatese
http://www.gruppoastronomicotradatese.it/
Gruppo Astrofili G. e A. Bernasconi di Saronno

Date:  Sun, 15 Dec 2013 20:16:58 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Lovejoy wide field 15 dec
Wide field image of Lovejoy with M13 globular cluster in Hercules. Not very deep due to humid and polluted sky at my home. Nearly
5 of tail is visible.

Pentax lens 165 mm f/2.8 closed to f/4, SBIG STL 11000, LRGB 8+1+1+1x120s (tot 22 min).
B39 obs, Tradate, Italy
Dec 15, 2013, 5.32 UT

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vv_lovejoy_15dic_LLRGB_tot22min_el1_MIDRES_1387134641.jpg

Lorenzo

Subject: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy wide field 15 dec

Wide field image of Lovejoy with M13
globular cluster in Hercules. Not very deep due to humid and
polluted sky at my home. Nearly
5° of tail is visible.

Pentax lens 165 mm f/2.8 closed to f/4, SBIG STL 11000, LRGB
8+1+1+1x120s (tot 22 min).
B39 obs, Tradate, Italy
Dec 15, 2013, 5.32 UT

Date:  Mon, 16 Dec 2013 22:26:25 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Lovejoy 16 dec
December 16, 2013, 5.33 UT
Tot exp 34.5 min (LRGB 25-2-2-2 min + 3.5 min (7x30s) for the core), TEC 140, SBIG STL 11000, Schmidt fork mount.
B39 obs, Tradate (VA), Italy.

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vz_lovejoy_16dic_LRGB_tot34.5min_el1_MIDRES_1387228580.jpg

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vz_lovejoy_16dic_LRGB_tot34.5min_el1_senzaquadro_MIDRES_1387228580.jpg

Date:  Mon, 16 Dec 2013 16:12:12 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Lovejoy Dec.13 Mosaic  10° tail
Hello

A mosaic two field each 2x450sec filter blue

and three fields (10° tail)

Date:  Tue, 17 Dec 2013 10:29:04 +0000
From:  Michael Oates 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] color mosaic C/2013 R 1 Lovejoy December 13
Gerald,

This has got to be one of the finest comet images I have seen, the detail and length of
the tail is amazing.

So I have to ask, how do you take 5min images and get the stars and comet sharp. I presume
using a composite, but I have tried and had little sucess, perhaps I am doing wrong, can
you share your technique? I realise you have a fast large dia scope, so that will help a
lot, but it must be how you process that gets both stars and comet sharp.

Thanks,

Mike

>
>I´ve just uploaded the color version of the mosaic image December 13:

>http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
>/201_Lovejoy_Dec_13_mosaic_color.jpg
>
>best regards
>
>Gerald

Michael,

Superb deep capture! The tail's length is impressive.

MaxIm by the way has an easy to use and very effective feature to remove hot pixels in their Kernel Filters tab.

Best regards,

John

Date:  Tue, 17 Dec 2013 09:03:15 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy 16 dec
Lorenzo, A very spectacular image indeed. I noticed that the stars are colorless, I presume you added an RGB to the comet only with the stars stripped out. This works very well - I had to look really hard to notice this! Any magazine would publish this image in a heartbeat, superb.

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

On Mon, 12/16/13, Lorenzo Comolli wrote:

Subject: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy 16 dec
To: "Comet Images"
Date: Monday, December 16, 2013, 2:26 PM

December 16, 2013, 5.33 UT
Tot exp 34.5 min (LRGB 25-2-2-2 min + 3.5 min (7x30s) for
the core), TEC 140, SBIG STL 11000, Schmidt fork mount.
B39 obs, Tradate (VA), Italy.

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vz_lovejoy_16dic_LRGB_tot34.5min_el1_MIDRES_1387228580.jpg

http://0e33611cb8e6da737d5c-e13b5a910e105e07f9070866adaae10b.r15.cf1.rackcdn.com/Lorenzo-Comolli-vz_lovejoy_16dic_LRGB_tot34.5min_el1_senzaquadro_MIDRES_1387228580.jpg

Lorenzo

Date:  Tue, 17 Dec 2013 21:08:55 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Dec 17th.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 R1 captured today. Near full moonlight and twilight made processing very difficult.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_12_17dp.jpg

106mm F5 with SLT-11k. LRGB. L: 7x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
************************************************* 
Date:  Tue, 17 Dec 2013 22:54:52 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Comet Lovejoy (Dec 17th.)
Damian nice work. I have a question for you or anyone with an opinion. I watch the pictures come in and they look great showing large structure in the tail. Then the next day they seem to really calm down showing very little tail structure. I know it is full Moon but such a decrease is surprising. Is it all full Moon or is this comet changing that much in just a day. Solar winds could be affecting it also. Thanks
Mike

Date:  Thu, 19 Dec 2013 12:19:28 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy 16 dec
Thanks Cris! Sorry for late reply.
The image, being an LRGB, has (obviously) the color images taken at a different time respect to luminance ones. Thus I cannot reconstruct the star
color of the trails, on the contrary of a single shot color sensor.
So I've simply removed stars from the color channel and composed only the comet color above luminance.

Regards,
Lorenzo

Date:  Thu, 19 Dec 2013 04:23:03 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy 16 dec
Lorenzo, Ive discovered one photoshop method to color the stars correctly when the are trailed from stacking many subs, in which you only take ONE RGB set. To do this, you stack the star registered RGB data with nice round stars in a stack equal to the number of subs, and combine with Lighten. Then move each layer to match the L data and color each of the equivelent L sub stars. You have to layer the RGB data temporarily over the L data to do this then after the stack is done, delete the L data underneath. Now use this colored trails image to color your L data using "color" in a layer stack with the L data. Use this for coloring the star trails. Here is an example of using this process:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrs042313.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

--------------------------------------------
On Thu, 12/19/13, Lorenzo Comolli wrote:

Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Lovejoy 16 dec
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thursday, December 19, 2013, 4:19 AM

Thanks Cris! Sorry for late reply.
The image, being an LRGB, has (obviously) the color images
taken at a different time respect to luminance ones. Thus I
cannot reconstruct the star
color of the trails, on the contrary of a single shot color
sensor.
So I've simply removed stars from the color channel and
composed only the comet color above luminance.

Regards,
Lorenzo

Terry Lovejoy 
Date:  Thu, 19 Dec 2013 21:08:17 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  ICQ article etc
Hello all,
I wonder if any one can point me to an online copy of this issue of ICQ or provide me with a digital copy of the articles on  the history of total visual magnitude methodology and the history of the lives of Mrkos and Vsekhsvyatskii.
Thanks in advance for any help given.
Happy festive period and clear skies to all on these lists.
Denis Buczynski

Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

 October 1996
issue of The International Comet Quarterly

(This was Number 100 in the publication's series (dating back to 1973), and it
contained many pages of observations and images of comets from observers
worldwide, plus articles on the history of total
visual magnitude methodology; on comets for the visual observer in 1997; on
the lives of two well-known comet observers, A. Mrkos and S. K. Vsekhsvyatskii;
and an index for the first 23 years of this publication.)

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Dec 23rd.)
Hi all,

Here is Lovejoy captured yesterday having passed through perihelion around 20hrs previously. Moonlight and twilight interfering.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_12_23dp.jpg

106mm F5 with STL11k. LRGB. L: 7x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Damian

Date:  Thu, 26 Dec 2013 12:37:03 -0800
From:  comets133@yahoo.com
Subject:  8 degrees of tail over the Pines today 12/26
Hello all,

Just finished this montage up, a two part image of comet Lovejoy C/2013 R1 as it was seen just over our pine forest from a 14 foot balcony on the back of our home here in northern Arizona. We built up a special platform out of cinder blocks to elevate the mount just enough to now get the comet for about an hour now. The field is about 8 degrees here, and while the comet appears fainter now, it has a stunning long blue tail.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoy122613.html http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/lovejoy122613.html

Thanks for looking,

Chris Schur

Date:  Fri, 27 Dec 2013 15:13:23 +0000
From:  DENIS BUCZYNSKI 
Subject:  Comet images 2013 Dec 26
Hello all,
In a break between the Atlantic storms experienced here in the UK over the past week there was a brief calm clear period during the evening of Dec 26 when I was able to image C/2013 R1 Lovejoy in the evening sky and just got 290P Jager before cloud arrived again. The images are posted at the links below on the Comet Gallery of the British Astronomical Association. I would like to take ths opportunity to thank all the observers who have contributed images and sketches of comets in 2013 to the BAA Comet Section. Also best wishes and clear skies to all in 2014.
Denis Buczynski
Tarbatness Highland Scotland

290P Jager
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=2165&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2013 R1 Lovejoy
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=2152&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

C/2013 R1 Lovejoy
http://britastro.org/baa/index.php?view=detail&id=2153&option=com_joomgallery&Itemid=200

Date:  Sat, 28 Dec 2013 09:46:35 -0800
From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy Dec. 28 LRGB
Hello

A 5x3° field from Dec. 28 UT 4.40
with Apo 80/400
L-2x500sec RGB 300/300/300 sec 2x2 bin

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2013r120131228lrgbweb2_1388252530.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2013r120131228lrgbweb2_1388252530.jpg

Regards
Michael Jäger 
Date:  Sat, 28 Dec 2013 10:08:02 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Brewington Last night 12/27
Greetings all,

Very cold (low 30s) and damp and near the end my CCD frosted up. Was able however to get a fairly deep shot of this comet, and even a bit of color was recorded! This shot shows a few 15th magnitude galaxies framing the comet, and the background is peppered with many 18th and 19th magnitude ones. Interesting field.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Brewington122713.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Mon, 30 Dec 2013 14:30:16 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Brewington - This time I got it right!
Greeting comet friends,

Yesterdays posting of this comet did not come out as well as I liked, turns out a red light was on "somewhere" during the exposures and I had to remove all the red from the image resulting in an interesting but a less than perfect result. I found the offending light last night after an hour of searching! It was the neon lamp on my electric blanket that i keep the laptop warm with, hiding behind the computer desk. Without delay, I set up and reshot the comet, with one of the longest integration times on any comet Ive done in a long time - 90 minutes. The tracking was perfect, focus spot on, and no red glows. Ive spent this morning producing two versions from the data, one with the conventional trailed stars and tracked comet, and the second version both stationary - with both the comet and stars both auto aligned with the very first frame for reference. I am much more excited with these results! The sharp stars shot is very deep indeed, I have
dozens of 18th and 19th magnitude galaxies all over the background, and stars go down to mag 20 or so. The comet shows a very nice teal color too. Not bad for an 11th mag comet, ay?

So here are the images:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Brewington122813.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Mon, 30 Dec 2013 18:26:36 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lovejoy (Dec 28th.)
Thats still a very nice comet! So short exposures too, and plenty of details.

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

--------------------------------------------
